PARA.TAB: The Senate met at 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I advise the Senate that the President is unavoidably absent and, under standing order 13, the Deputy President will take the chair.

PARA.TAB: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston) thereupon took the chair, and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! As most honourable senators would be aware, the President will not be in the chamber until tomorrow. I advise that, at my request, my normal chamber duties of Deputy President and Chairman of Committees will today be undertaken by Senator Bjelke-Petersen.

PARA.TAB: It may be that on Thursday afternoon of this week I will not be present in the chamber, due to a particular matter I am pursuing for a constituent. If that occurs, Senator Bjelke-Petersen will also perform the chamber duties of Deputy President and Chairman of Committees during my absence.

I also take the opportunity of publicly thanking Senator Teague for his assistance to me by carrying out the duties of Deputy President and Chairman of Committees when the President was overseas some six or seven weeks ago.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That, during Question Time during the sitting weeks commencing on 3 and 9 November 1992:
(a)the asking of each question not exceed 1 minute and the answering of each question not exceed 3 minutes;
(b)the asking of each supplementary question not exceed 1 minute and the answering of each supplementary question not exceed 1 minute; and
(c)the time taken to make and determine points of order not be regarded as part of the time for questions and answers.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy President, this process of reform has at least curbed the abuses by Ministers and we are pleased that the experiment should continue for another fortnight in this slightly amended way. I therefore commend the motion to the Senate, but I indicate that it is our view that it is only a step in the reform process of Question Time; we think that there should also be a minimum number of questions asked and answered during Question Time, and I give notice that that is the next stage of this reform process that we intend to pursue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to check on one aspect of this matter that remains unclear. We have been fiddling around with the time for a long while, and maybe this is the final formula. But I take it that, whilst points of order will not come into the time for the answering of a question—which I think is quite proper—points of order will be taken into account in the one-hour limit for Question Time. Otherwise, we will get into the farcical situation of people disrupting Question Time for 10 minutes. We need a counterbalance to even the whole thing up. I assume that that is part of the interpretation of the motion.

—in reply—The question of the length of Question Time is beyond the scope of this whole discussion. It came up on the last sitting day when there was some confusion, I think, on the Government side on the question that Senator Ray has just raised. I have not dealt with that. That is a matter that may need some further consultation in future. I think the way that the Government interpreted it in the last instance was that the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) got up after one hour and said, `Time's up', and I anticipate that that is what the Government will do again today. We say that when the Government finally agrees to a minimum number of questions that issue will be resolved in a better way than the Government is putting to us today.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the following conditions apply to debate on motions relating to answers given to Questions Without Notice for the weeks beginning 3 and 9 November 1992:
(a) motions shall relate only to answers given that day to Questions Without Notice;
(b) a Senator may speak for not more than 4 minutes on such a motion;
(c) the total time for debate on all motions relating to answers to Questions Without Notice on any day shall not exceed 30 minutes; and
(d) the time taken in raising and determining any points of order during the debate under this order shall not be regarded as part of the time allowed for debate under this order.

SPEECH.PARA: I indicate that those words are exactly the same words as those which operated in the past weeks in which we have had this practice. The intention is not to change it in any way but simply to continue the existing practice.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is still our view that that is unduly restrictive. However, we recognise that the Australian Democrats will support that time restraint and that, therefore, the numbers in this instance are with the Government; and we will not be dividing.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and relates to Labor's Loan Council cover-up. When did the Minister first become aware of Victorian Labor's massive breach of Loan Council borrowing limits? Was the Cabinet ever informed of the breach? If so, when; if not, who was informed of the breach?

—Probably some time in late July, I understood—I was not privy to any detailed discussion about it—that the Treasurer had written to the Victorian Government about this issue. That is all I understood before, in and after July until the recent spate of publicity about this problem following the election in Victoria. As to the matter being reported or discussed in Cabinet, my answer to the first part of the question partly answers that, but I am not in a position to reveal Cabinet discussions in answers to questions in any event.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr Deputy President. Given that the major issue in the recent Victorian election was the financial mismanagement of the Cain-Kirner Government, why did the Federal Government then conspire with the Victorian Labor Government, and the Minister in particular, now that we know that he knew of this matter, to hide the massive borrowing breach from the Victorian electorate?

—These beautiful pejorative words that Senator Hill conjures up in his questions are not appropriate and I do not concede the relevance of any of them. The Commonwealth Government, in its view, was not provided with accurate information about the extent and size of Victorian Government borrowings until yesterday. That information is now in the hands of the Commonwealth, as I understand it. In the period leading up to the Federal Budget—I have a list of the published correspondence—there were meetings between the Federal Treasury and officials in Victoria regarding the borrowings. Those were initiated by the Commonwealth. Just as these sorts of inquiries and discussions have been initiated by the Commonwealth in the case of other States, so they were in this case.
—What about Queensland?
—The Queensland situation was quite different because it was raised publicly at a Loan Council meeting and outside a Loan Council meeting by the Premier of Queensland.
—Order! Senator Button, your time for the answer has expired.

—Mr Deputy President, I ask the Minister to table the papers that he referred to in the answer he has just given, that is, the correspondence between Ministers that he touched or said he had in front of him.
—I understand that those documents are all on the public record. I do not propose to table anything here.

—Is the Minister for Industrial Relations aware of comments by the Opposition spokesperson on industrial relations, John Howard, that the Opposition's policy of forcing many workers onto individual employment contracts will leave no worker worse off? Does the Government have any intention of adopting a similar policy? Can the Minister advise on the effect of such a policy on workers?
—I would remind honourable senators to use proper titles even in Question Time.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course we do not intend to follow the low wage, high cost, low skill, high confrontation policy that has been announced by the Opposition. But let me give the Senate two quotes. The first quote is:

ANSWER.PARA: You can't earn less under the policy but you can earn more.
No person in employment will suffer any loss of award wages and conditions.
I suppose the question is: who said those things?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I take a point of order. It seems appropriate now to settle the rules for Question Time. The Standing Orders provide that a Minister will answer questions in relation to his administration. What he is now doing is seeking to interpret our policy, as he knows that matter is on the agenda for debate later this day. That is when it will be debated. That is the proper time for debate. Now is not the proper time for debate. Now is the time for the Minister to answer for his administration.

—On the point of order, Mr Deputy President: the answer is thus far entirely in order and the whole answer to the question, when it is delivered, will be in order. I am asked whether we will follow this course and, in short, why would we not follow this course? It is entirely appropriate to give reasons why not, since I am invited by the question to do so. If that is uncomfortable for the Opposition, I can certainly understand it, but it is certainly normal practice in this place to be able to answer questions with at least that amount of latitude.

—Mr Deputy President, on the point of order, I draw your attention to rulings given by a previous President that a Minister cannot be responsible for, or comment on, Opposition policies. Further, a President has ruled that it is not in order for a Minister to say what might happen under another administration. I draw your attention to those rulings, and on that basis I say that Senator Cook is out of order.
—My ruling is that Senator Cook is in order at this stage.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. Those were vexatious points of order in order to delay the processes of Question Time. There were two quotes. The first was:

ANSWER.PARA: You can't earn less under this policy but you can earn more.
No person in employment will suffer any loss of award wages and conditions.
Who said those things? The first quote was on 22 October on radio station 2CN by John Howard. The second quote was by Jeff Kennett, the leader of the Government in Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I take a point of order.
—Order! Before the point of order is taken, I would ask the honourable senator to use the correct titles when referring to other members of parliament.

—I rise to speak on a point of order. The Minister is not answering the question as to whether he would adopt the Opposition's policy, which was the guise under which he sought to bring the answer within the Standing Orders. He is seeking to give certain attributions to Mr Kennett and to Mr Howard. That is clearly outside the Standing Orders. The time for debate of policy is after Question Time. We have put the matter on the Notice Paper to enable the Minister to get up and debate it at that time. I therefore ask you to require that Question Time be limited within the terms of the Standing Orders.
—Order! Originally the Minister had three minutes in which to answer the question. In that time he should be able to develop an answer and he was doing so. I ask Senator Cook to continue.

—Mr Kennett said those words, but he did not honour them; he lied to the electorate, that is a matter of record. Mr Howard has said those words and they are not true. There is a very big gap between what the Opposition policy says and how Mr Howard explains it to the electorate. It is not a policy about enterprise or workplace bargaining. It is a policy about reducing workers to individual work contracts or saying, `Sign here and get the sack'. There are a number of so-called guarantees which are laughable in their construction, so-called guarantees that are provided for—

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I put it to you that this can be interpreted in no other way than as a debate on our policy. There can be no interpretation other than that the Minister is seeking to debate the terms of our policy. We are happy to do that because it is a brilliant policy which will give an opportunity to a million Australians who are currently out of work. But the proper time to debate it is after Question Time, not now. I ask you to bring him to order.

—I rise on the same point of order. It is quite clear what Senator Cook is doing. He has been asked why he would or would not adopt a certain policy agenda and he is telling us how the Government is addressing it and what is the Government's position. It is very much within his portfolio responsibility. I think those opposite are running scared of the answer.
—As far as I can see, Senator Cook is answering the question that was put to him. I ask Senator Cook to continue, keeping in mind the question that was originally put.

—I will give a couple of case examples as to why we would not adopt this policy. In the case of a nurse, under this policy she or he would lose 44 per cent of her or his income. In the case of a part time cleaner under this policy, she or he would lose 24 per cent of her or his income. In the case of a retail worker under this policy, he or she would lose 44 per cent of his or her income. In the case of a security guard under this policy, he or she would lose 34 per cent of his or her income.

—On a point of order: I thought the Minister was going to rise to say that we had stolen his policy, as he did the other day, and that therefore these examples applied to him. The examples are a clear misrepresentation, but apart from that the point of order is—
—That is not a point of order. Make it afterwards.
—We will have the debate afterwards. Tell the Minister to stop abusing Question Time. He is abusing Question Time; he is not answering questions within Standing Orders and he should be restrained.
—Order! I clearly heard the Minister say that his Government would not adopt these policies `because. . . ' and he was listing some reasons. In that case he is in order.

—The reason why the case examples are accurate and uncomfortable for the Opposition is that in the Opposition's policy there is no guarantee that annual leave loadings, shift allowances and overtime will be protected; that there will be a normal spread of hours per day or per week; that special payments will be protected; that redundancy payments will be protected; or that superannuation will in fact go on to a reasonable level, as proposed by us.
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate as the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to the fact that table 19 of Budget Paper No. 4 this year did not have a footnote referring to Victoria's breaching of its global borrowing limits. I also refer the Minister to the equivalent table in the 1989-90 Budget Papers, which had a footnote saying:

QUESTION.PARA: VIC borrowings for 1987-88 exceeded the State's global limit for the year by $158 million . . .
I ask the Minister: why was a similar footnote not included with the equivalent table in the 1992-93 Budget Papers?

TALK.START.PARA: —Protect the mates.

—Senator Hill says, `Protect the mates'; of course, he does not understand Senator Short's question. The mates were there in 1989-90, too, so he should not get over-excited about that.The position in respect of the figures which appear in table 19 is that they are figures provided by the States to the Commonwealth. The Treasury, until it assesses aggregate borrowings, cannot vouch for the accuracy entirely of those figures. It could not do so this year because it was not satisfied about the figures which had been provided by Victoria.

—Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister has absolutely refused to answer my question. Let me ask it again in words which perhaps he might understand. Why did the Commonwealth Government deliberately conspire to mislead the electorate and financial markets with its exclusion of that necessary explanatory footnote from its 1992 Budget?

—The answer to that question is that if there had been a publication of figures which were regarded as inaccurate in relation to Victoria at that time, it would probably have had an extraordinary effect on the market. One need only look at the present situation and the discussion which has taken place in the last week or two and market response to that. The rule is that if there is a breach of global borrowings, as was suspected at that time, and no solution in place to that problem—that is, the problem of the State finances in Victoria—that would have had a very adverse effect on market perceptions. The fact of the matter is that that is true, and it is consistent with the behaviour of the Commonwealth in relation to the State Bank of South Australia, for example, and in relation to the State Bank of Victoria. In each case there was a solution in place and the information was then published.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. Is the Minister aware of newspaper reports that the Victorian and New South Wales health Ministers are delaying the signing of Medicare agreements by requiring a clause about private insurance to be incorporated? Are these reports correct? If so, does this mean that the Government would be encouraged to move public health dollars out of the public sector hospitals and into the private sector?

—I have noticed press reports to the effect that the Victorian and New South Wales health Ministers are trying to hold up the implementation of the next phase of the Medicare agreement, which, of course, would provide health care for all Australians on an equitable basis. They are doing this in order to get recognition of the role of private insurance into that Medicare agreement in a way which would simply provide a foundation for the policy of the Federal Opposition. This policy is to require and coerce Australians to take out private health insurance to cover their medical and hospital costs, with some subsidy offered to certain categories of those forced and required to take out that premium for private health insurance, in addition to their ordinary taxation and Medicare levy payments.

PARA.TAB: The question is: where will the money come from for those subsidies which the Opposition says it will offer in respect of some private health insurance premiums? Quite clearly, the $850m required will come because it is slashing $1.3 billion from the public hospital payments which are now made by the Federal Government via the States to the public hospital system.

These moneys have to come from somewhere. The Commonwealth, under the Opposition's Fightback proposals, would take the money direct from the public hospitals—which, of course, provide for the health care and hospital treatment of Australians, whether they are public patients or private patients taking advantage of the public hospital structure—and put it into private health insurance premium subsidies for some categories of some of those forced to take out such private health insurance. It is not the view of the Federal Government that that should be the way in which our public hospital system is supported in this country. We believe that both public and private patients, in certain instances, ought to be able to use our wonderful public hospital system in accordance—

TALK.START.PARA: —We believe that they ought to have freedom of choice.

—Those opposite do not believe in freedom of choice. Under its proposal, the Opposition would coerce people to take out private health insurance in addition to their ordinary payment of taxes and their ordinary payment of the Medicare levy. So much for freedom of choice! As we know, those opposite do not believe in freedom of choice.

PARA.TAB: I believe that the Federal Government's offer of, I think, $1.6 billion over some six years to the States to further strengthen their public hospital system is much to be welcomed. I believe that the Australian people trust this Government to ensure that our public hospital system continues to provide the sorts of medical and hospital services which are essential to those Australians seeking such treatment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister tell us whether reducing funding to the public hospitals will do anything to shorten waiting lists?

—Quite clearly, any slashing of funds that are available to the public hospital system cannot help to shorten waiting lists. Honourable senators will know that this Government proposed in the last Budget to make available some $70m to the States to help reduce waiting lists, and that is being implemented in those States which are cooperating. That will be an extremely important part of our support for the public hospital system.
—A drop in the bedpan.

—Senator Herron has just used the expression that it is just a drop in the bedpan. I must say that that is a more humorous interjection than a previous one, which was that the United States has the best health system in the world. He qualified that interjection with the words, `for those who can afford it'. That is precisely the sort of system that the Opposition wants to impose on Australians. We do not believe in that system. We believe in a system which allows our great public and teaching hospitals to provide care for all Australians, whether public or private patients, based on clinical need.

—My question is directed to Senator Button. I refer to the Treasurer's letter of 30 October to the New South Wales Premier, Mr Fahey, in which he strongly supported the need for improved Loan Council procedures, including greater scrutiny and regular publication of all borrowing by all government bodies, and explicit penalties for any breach of agreed borrowing limits. I ask the Minister: first, does he acknowledge that the Government's position on the Loan Council is totally inconsistent, having claimed at different times that to publicise government borrowings would both undermine and promote market confidence? Secondly, did the Treasurer become aware that at least some of the Victorian Government's $1.3 billion of extra debt had been on-sold to the private sector in time to have that recorded in this year's Budget Papers? Finally, given that the operation of the Loan Council is based entirely on gentlemen's agreements and rubbery figures, does he accept that establishing public confidence in the financial transactions of the public sector must be the top priority, requiring a thorough and public review of the Loan Council operations?

—I might try to work through the three points of the honourable senator's question. First of all, the Government's position on this has been consistent at all times; that is, to act in the national interest. This question was asked in part by Senator Short. At all times we have maintained that it was critically important to Victoria and the nation as a whole that when the extent of the Victorian debt problem became publicly known the Victorian Government had in place a strategy to solve the problem—a strategy that the Commonwealth Government and the other members of the Loan Council could support to ensure that markets had confidence in that strategy; a strategy to solve the problem.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, as I said in answer to Senator Short—and I misled him to this extent—the letter was received today, dated yesterday, from Victoria, which provided the first detailed nature of the Victoria Government's borrowings. That information even in that letter does not extend to the precise extent of how much of the borrowing was on-sold to the private sector after placement in the financial market. That is the second part of the honourable senator's question.

I have to repeat that at the time of the preparation of the Commonwealth Budget the Victorian Government contended that the $1.267 billion was not subject to the authority of the Loan Council. With regard to the third part of the honourable senator's question, the Government believes that confidence has been established in the operation of the Loan Council and also that it is important to maintain that confidence in its operations.

Given recent events, the Treasurer has put forward proposals—and the honourable senator referred to the letter to Mr Fahey—to the other members of the Loan Council to consider in respect of mechanisms to improve monitoring of State and Territory borrowings. It is important to understand that the Loan Council is a cooperative body and relies on agreement amongst the members as to its operations.

TALK.START.PARA: —A lot of secrecy, apparently.
—The Liberal Party's new leader in Victoria, Jeff Kennett, advocated that view this morning, but Senator Kemp would not be on side with him.

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth Government has been instrumental in providing guidance to the States and Territories to adopt a standard approach to the presentation of their Budgets which ensures that they are open and transparent. Further, the Commonwealth has encouraged the States to accept more responsibility for their affairs and to have their activities monitored by the markets, including having rating agencies assigned to credit rating for State and Territory governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I refer the Minister to the first part of my question. He seems to have exacerbated the problem and, if one followed the Treasurer's line in relation to the letter to Mr Fahey, he would indeed exacerbate the concerns of both the public and the market. Does he not concede that there is an inconsistency in there? Secondly, does he not agree that, given the unsatisfactory nature of the operation of the Loan Council with respect to the rubbery figures which have now been revealed, a more public inquiry into this operation is demanded, rather than simply an internal investigation by the Loan Council itself?

—I do not believe in the conclusion which the honourable senator draws at the end of his question. There is to be a Loan Council meeting in December. For its part, the Commonwealth has been quite happy to put the issues on the table for the Loan Council to determine.

PARA.TAB: I think it is important that the discussions and arrangements of the Loan Council be kept in the confidence of the Loan Council until such time as proper solutions are reached in relation to the sorts of problems which arose in Victoria. I said that in answer to an earlier question today. I do not see any inconsistency in that. I am happy to say that the Premier of Victoria confirms that view, as do most other Premiers as well.
Senator Short interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short's slimy interjection is not relevant to these proceedings.
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, and ask: does the Government agree with the statement made by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate last week that it is now hard to justify the position of Australia's Ambassador for Disarmament? Will the Government abolish the position, as the Opposition proposes to do if it ever comes to government?
—Statement where?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was on Radio National last Saturday morning, if Senator Hill cannot remember it. He made absolutely clear where the Opposition stood on the subject of the future of the Ambassador for Disarmament, if ever it has a chance to influence that future. I will quote what he said:

ANSWER.PARA: The way the world has gone with the end of the Cold War, I would think it is now hard to justify that sort of position.
A little later on the presenter asked him:
So we might see the position of Ambassador for Disarmament go?

The assumption revealed in this exchange, that the end of the cold war has somehow reduced the need for Australian—and by extension, international—efforts in the disarmament area, is both naive and dangerous.

PARA.TAB: It is naive because of the way in which it comprehensively underestimates the historic opportunity which now exists in the post-cold war world for giving some practical reality to the disarmament and arms control agenda which for so long was utterly strangled by superpower confrontation.

It is dangerous for Australian security interests, quite apart from anybody else's, in as much as the achievement of a number of key objectives in that peace and disarmament agenda is absolutely necessary if we are to have a comfortable security future in what is a very much more fluid and dynamic environment in our own region now that the gridlock of that superpower confrontation has been lifted.

There are several particular aspects to this issue. The first is chemical weapons, in relation to which Senator Hill did acknowledge the Ambassador for Disarmament had done some useful work. What he failed to acknowledge was that a great deal of work remains to be done over the years ahead to translate the agreement—which has been now so laboriously constructed with a lot of crucial input from Australia—to implement it, and to make it work. Work is now being carried forward by our Ambassador for Disarmament who, among other things, chairs the international group that is spearheading the implementation of the chemical weapons convention. If Senator Hill had his way, the Ambassador would be out of a job and we would be unable to play that role.

Secondly, there is no more crucial item on the world's peace and disarmament agenda at the moment than the extension of the nuclear non-proliferation treaty, which up until now has been the world's most important single disarmament measure. It is up for review when its sunset period operates in 1995 and it is absolutely crucial to get it applied to a number of threshold nuclear states which are not presently party to it. There is no more important diplomatic task for the world than that in the present environment. That is another crucial role for our Ambassador for Disarmament to play.

Associated with that is the question of a comprehensive nuclear test ban, which again is closer to achievement than it ever has been. At the moment it is the subject of a resolution on which we are leading the charge in the United Nations, again with our Ambassador for Disarmament playing the crucial diplomatic role. A successful implementation of the resolution would in itself be the most crucial single diplomatic thing that we could do to create the environment for an effective extension of that nuclear non-proliferation treaty. Again, there is a whole range of other disarmament issues—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for the answer has expired.
—Which I shall be happy to talk about if I am asked a supplementary question.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Could the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade expand on his answer?
—I think it is important to complete the agenda of issues which are outstanding in this area.

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. A question asking the Minister to expand his previous answer is not supplementary; it has not arisen out of the answer that he has given. I ask you to bring the Minister to order. It is a clear abuse to have the Minister turn around and ask his colleague whether he will allow him an extra minute to expand on his answer. It abuses the attitude of the Senate that questions have been answered in the Minister's usual verbose form for long enough.

—Mr Deputy President, I want briefly to speak to this rather pathetic point of order. It is quite obvious that Senator Jones could have dressed up his supplementary question in all the flowery language that people get paid for—by the word if they are lawyers. Senator Hill therefore would have felt more comfortable because it would have been verbose. But Senator Jones went to the point. This has shocked and horrified people in this place. It is actually consistent with the Standing Orders to ask someone to speak further on the point which they have made for the last three minutes. Logically it must follow from the answer that has been given and therefore it is in order.
—It was rather novel, but it is a supplementary question.

—What I am saying is that, in addition to the completion of the chemical weapons convention, the nuclear non-proliferation treaty and the question of a nuclear comprehensive test ban, there is the crucial question of the further effective extension of the convention on biological weapons and the obviously crucial implementation of a conventional arms transfer register, all of which are centrally part of our security interests. In addition, I might mention the missile technology control regime.

PARA.TAB: This is the brief and the area of operation of the Ambassador for Disarmament. He operates with a staff of just three other people in Geneva. The cost-effectiveness involved in destroying that diplomatic focus of our activity in this area is palpably absurd. Yet again, it is a demonstration of the fact that the economic tinmen opposite, who think only in terms of economics, are nakedly revealed when one strips away the mirage that they know anything about economic policy, and that they stand for nothing else and have nothing to say about anything else. They simply do not understand the complex interactions between all aspects of effective government policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and relates to the Labor Loan Council cover-up. I remind the Minister that in 1988 the then Treasurer, Mr Keating, legislated to penalise the State of Queensland if that State had sought to borrow beyond the global limit agreed for Queensland at the Loan Council meeting in June of that year. Will the Minister explain to the Senate why, when confronted with an actual borrowing by the Victorian Government of an amount in excess of its Loan Council agreed borrowing limits, the current Treasurer did not at least threaten his Victorian Labor Party counterpart with the same action, even in his private correspondence with him?

—I have already referred to the situation in Queensland, but let me say it again: in the Queensland case, the Queensland government of the day asserted at a Loan Council meeting and then outside publicly—
—Order! Order on both sides of the chamber!

—Mr Deputy President, I might just repeat that: in the Queensland case, the then government of Queensland publicly asserted after a Loan Council meeting that it was going to break the borrowing limits. The then Treasurer was able to respond publicly to the State government's public threat. That is what happened. It was a Queensland government public threat to which the Treasurer of the day responded. The issue was over in a day without any question of damage to Australia's credit rating.

PARA.TAB: The issue of the Loan Council goes to the heart of the Federal system in Australia. I find it rather strange that the implications of some of the questions that we have been asked, particularly when we look at Fightback, is that there is a call for centralist bureaucratic control of State government finances. There is no need, nor much prospect, of such an approach to the Loan Council in our Federation, and neither the States nor the Commonwealth Government have been advocating that.

Over the last few years—right through the decade—the Commonwealth Government has improved the assessment of State government finances. This has happened by facilitating more rigorous assessment of State government finances by encouraging the States to be more open with their State instrumentality borrowings and financial situations. That has been of benefit to the market both here and overseas. A number of steps have been taken by the Commonwealth Government to ensure that result.

In the case of Victoria, we were dealing with excess borrowings in the past, not an announced intention, as the Queensland government had a few years ago, in 1988, to break the borrowing limits in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister but I find his answer completely unacceptable. Is not the real reason for there being no such action that in 1988 it involved a National Party government and this year it involves a Labor mates State government? Is there not one rule for the conservatives and another rule for the mates?

—That might go down quite well on some stump under a gum tree at Barcaldine or elsewhere but I doubt whether it would be accepted there. The fact of the matter is that I have answered the question. There is a distinct difference between the two situations. Everybody who knows anything about Loan Council financing understands that. If Senator Boswell does not, he can follow it in the newspapers and understand better.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce aware of conflicting claims about the effects on the car industry of a policy based on zero tariffs? Has the Minister had examined claims that motor vehicle sales could rise faster under a zero tariff scenario than under the tariff phasedown already announced for the car industry by the Government? Can the Minister tell the Senate of the results of any examination of these claims?

—As Senator Burns asked his question, Senator Hill interjected, `The issue is being revisited'. That is an extraordinary word for him to use because the Opposition announced a policy, trumpeted it throughout the country, got a lot of criticism about it, revisited it, and then said, `It's about time we had an examination by some consultants who might support our view'.

PARA.TAB: So the Opposition trotted off to the consultants ACIL to see whether it could get post facto acknowledgment of its policy which it had talked about throughout the country. What an extraordinary way for a party to present itself as an alternative government in this country—to go after the policy announcement to try to get some justification, some intellectual rationale, for a policy which it had already adopted.

As I have said in this place on numerous occasions, the Government's policy is based on a report of the Industry Commission—the body which has been recognised historically in this country by parties of all political persuasions as the body which conducts public inquiries and which produces appropriate conclusions in relation to these matters. But that is not good enough for the Opposition. It wanted a private inquiry by a private consultancy firm presided over by a Liberal stooge who had worked for the Liberal Party for years and who would produce the right results for that Party. That was the course adopted by the Opposition.

This report, which the honourable member for Barker retrieved from his saddlebag at the last breath, as it were, is an interesting document. The first thing the ACIL report tells one is that all the figures he has been giving the people of Australia are wrong. While Mr McLachlan has been going around the country saying that $350 to $400 will be saved from the price of a car by abolition of payroll tax, this report says the figure is $200 to $250. Going through each of these figures one by one, one sees that the justification for the policy and the figures which have been argued are wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —The industry will be better off under our policy.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the formerly secret AIDAB report of 22 June 1992 which found that Australian advisers are training mobile squads of Papua New Guinea police in military style operations on Bougainville, possibly in breach of the PNG Constitution. I ask the Minister whether he is aware of the Background Briefing program of 25 October, in which one member of a mobile squad said that Australian advisers had trained him to use an M60 machine-gun which he fired from an Australian supplied Iroquois helicopter on Bougainville. Did the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, Mr Kerin, approve the second phase of Australian aid to the PNG constabulary without having read that AIDAB report? Will Australian aid to the PNG police be reviewed in light of the report and the details from the Background Briefing program?

—Such training as has taken place of Papua New Guinea constabulary in their special services group, or the mobile squads or the riot control squads, has been training that in some way approximates to military training to the extent that it involves fieldcraft, weapons handling and matters of that kind. But it has not been training for Bougainville at any stage.

PARA.TAB: It is the case that some of the people so trained have obviously deployed those skills in the situation in Bougainville, but there has been no question of the Australian advisers, whether civilian policemen or military advisers, actively being involved in training people for the conditions they might confront on Bougainville.

The second point to make is in reference to the M60 machine-gun issue. Although there has been some assertion to the effect that individual police officers have been trained in the use of that weapon by Australian personnel, I am advised that there is no truth whatsoever in that. While it may be the case that some police officers, in the course of their service on Bougainville, have used M60s in their work with the military there, they have certainly not been trained in the use of any such weapon by the Australian advisers involved. That is denied absolutely by the Australian personnel. The M60s are no part of the armoury of any of the police officers concerned, and that seems to be something about which there has been some comprehensive misunderstanding.

As to Mr Kerin's approval of the second phase of Australian aid to the constabulary, the first phase has gone on for some five years and has involved the expenditure of some $30m. It has been a very important element in Australia's contribution to try to enhance the discipline and effectiveness of the law and order authorities in Papua New Guinea. The training of the special services division has occupied the time of only five of the 44 advisers involved, and that special services division is itself only a small component of the total constabulary of some 4,000 people.

The second phase of the total Australian effort is intended to go for another five years and to involve rather more substantial expenditure. It was the subject of a detailed evaluation report. The conclusions of that report were amply summarised in the material that was given to Mr Kerin when he made his decision to approve the second phase.

In light of the allegations that were made, he went back subsequently to read the full text of the report, and he satisfied himself, he assures me, that the recommendations put to him fully and accurately canvassed the issues that were relevant in that report. It was just a matter, as so often occurs, of the Minister not having time to read the details but relying on a departmental summary and reacting accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —This arises from the answer by Senator Evans to the dorothy dixer relating to the Australian Ambassador for Disarmament. What I said in the radio interview is that Australia can no longer afford three ambassadors in Geneva. There is an ambassador to GATT. I said there was a good case, in the current circumstances, for an ambassador to GATT. We also have an ambassador to the UN, and a separate ambassador for disarmament.

PARA.TAB: What I said is that the time has to come when Australia takes account of the cost of these positions. There is no reason at all why Australia's ambassador to the UN in Geneva cannot fulfil the disarmament functions that Senator Evans outlined to the Senate today. The result would be to save the taxpayer a lot of dollars, and that would have been sensible Government policy. Interestingly, a couple of years ago it was exactly what Senator Evans wanted to do and he was dissuaded from it at the last moment. So he knows the merit of the case. He knows it is an extravagance that Australia cannot afford in the contemporary circumstances in relation to disarmament.

That does not mean that the work in relation to the chemical convention treaty should not continue, as I said in that interview. I also accept the importance of the NPT and work on other such conventions, but it does not require a third ambassadorial position in Geneva. At the time that the Government is withdrawing our ambassador in Berne—bearing in mind that Switzerland is our third or fourth largest investor in this country—because the Minister said we could not afford the position, he maintains three ambassadors in Geneva, and that simply demonstrates distorted priorities.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Rehame Australia Monitoring Services Pty Ltd

SPEECH.PARA: Date: 31st October, 1992
Transcript of Item Broadcast On:
3RN Saturday National 7.14 am 31st October, 1992.

Interview with Senator Robert Hill, Shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs, discussing Australians appointed to overseas posts and if the cost and numbers of personnel are warranted; and what steps they would take, when elected to government, in the area of foreign affairs, both overseas and in Australia.
Presenter:

And it's been a week of tooing and froing for people with what we could term rather cushy jobs. The New South Wales Agent General in London Neil Peckard(?), was hastened home, allegedly as he tripped about Europe in a chauffeur driven motor, while the Federal Government was recalling its ambassador to the OECD so outgoing Tax Commissioner Trevor Boucher could have the job.
I couldn't help wondering just how many people are rattling around the world in Government backed jobs. And are they in the right place for the job that has to be done these days?

Now the Australian Trade Commission, or AusTrade which has four hundred and eighty one people overseas in fifty countries, has come in for some criticism being too heavily based in Europe and Asia, but they have strengthened Asia where there's ten regional personnel often called barefoot trade areas, because they're pretty spartan on office trappings, but strong on the hard sell local style.

When it comes to Consulates and High Commission offices a quick look at our Foreign Affairs list shows sixty two different overseas posts, who knows how many staff. And no-one would argue that we don't need representation abroad but are our people in the right places?

Senator Robert Hill, Shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs joins Saturday National. Senator Hill thanks for your time. Let's give the listeners on radio the extent of the Government payroll abroad for trade and diplomacy. How many people are we talking about and in what different areas?
Senator Robert Hill—Shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs

Well the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has about nine hundred overseas, and engaged . . . has . . . has about two thousand locally employed people overseas. Total cost to the taxpayer is about two hundred million.

The AusTrade, our trade promotion, is on . . . is on top of that, and the . . . the exact cost of their overseas operation, I'm not sure, but it would be I suspect around about the one hundred million.
Presenter:
Now do you believe that this money is being wasted? Or a percentage . . . percentage might be wasted through duplication, or say misplaced priorities?

Let's start with trade. It was week when we saw the New South Wales Agent General in London, Neil Peckard being told by his Premier to pack his bags and come home. And . . . and this position of course is being described as a . . . a colonial throw back. Do you think that each State really needs a representative in the UK alone?
I mean our pri . . . priorities have shifted to Asia, haven't they?
Hill:

Well they could probably say it's none of my . . . none of my business. But in the . . . in the old role that they played I . . . I would doubt it. Providing tickets for visits to the Royal Horse Guards or . . . or whatever. The question is, I guess, whether they are really producing a trade or economic benefit for the States and they will have to make their judgement.

There has been something of a trend in recent years to look to the opening of State posts within Asia, I mean Japan . . . that have partial successful. Some States have tried to do it through agencies. So there has been that . . . there have been that shift, but there is a concern about duplication of . . . of resources. These posts do cost a lot of money. The question is whether the Australian taxpayer is getting the best benefit from the resources when they are duplicated.
Presenter:
Well you talked about AusTrade. Could AusTrade do the job?
Hill:

Yes it . . . it . . . well that's it's function as trade promotion generally, but the . . . it's . . . there's traditionally rivalry through . . . between the States under which they have thought they have needed additional resources to, particularly represent their interest as opposed to other States.
And I'd . . . I wonder whether in the longer term Australia can afford that, but that is a decision that the States will have to make.
Presenter:

Now Senator you have been heard to use the expression, "Complete shambles", when it comes to government spending on foreign affairs. The question is, I suppose, do we have the right people in the right places in these areas?
Hill:

Well we've got very . . . very good people, but my criticism would be that the posts have been insufficiently trade(sic) and economically related. Too much of the reporting is on . . . is on other matters and basically I think too much paper is produced.

There is . . . there is . . . there is still not a totally satisfactory trade intelligence network producing for Australian industry . . . business and industry, the figures on markets and market opportunities that they would like. So I'd like to see greater emphasis in that.

We've actually talked about restructuring the whole of the department to give a greater emphasis to our . . . our trade interests by bringing, you know, bi-lateral trade experts back into the department. And . . . but apart from that I think there is also the question of orientation.
It's interesting that we still have more . . . more posts in Europe than we have in Asia, but our largest posts are still places such as London, which is the largest. I'll give you one example.

London costs . . . costs the taxpayer about twenty million dollars a year, whereas Kuala Lumpur, a key regional post costs us three and a half million dollars. And I . . . and I just think that it's disproportionate and I think it's got to be looked at.

Even within Europe I would have though these days, a key post, if not the key post is . . . is Brussels because of the European Commission and . . . and it's key role in trade policy. And yet Brussels is only about one fifth of the size, in dollars terms, of our London post. So I do think that these questions need to be looked at and . . . and looked at seriously.
Presenter:

Well it seems when . . . when you do look at the situation at first glance, it seems like a sensible cost cutting measure for some . . . some embassies to close down. I'm thinking of Lisbon now. But do you . . . I believe you're not that keen on the fact that it was closed.
Hill:

Well we closed about . . . about three closures in Europe in this . . . in this last budget, and my concern is that it doesn't seem to be developed as part of a wider strategy. We . . . we closed Bern for example, and yet Switzerland is either our third or fourth largest financial investor. And yet we . . . and yet we have three ambassadors in Geneva working to the UN to the GATT, to disarmament and to the UN generally. So, again, it seems to me that that's getting the pri . . . getting the priorities wrong.

The other thing I criticised was that we've . . . we've got into this pattern of opening posts and then closing them. We opened Prague two years ago and have now closed it. The end result of that is that we look silly. It looks as if we don't know what direction we're seeking to take in foreign policy.

We did it in relation to Berlin, the other way around. We closed Berlin and then a few years later we . . . we opened it again. And it's that sort of lack of vision that's coming through the post openings and closures that I've particularly criticised.

I've also said that sometimes it's false economy, because the costs of closing are almost as great as the costs of maintaining, because the functions are moved to somewhere else, in the case of Lisbon I think they are now moved to London, it's either to London or to Paris, and it'll be serviced by diplomats flying backwards and . . . backwards and forwards.
Presenter:
It makes you . . .
Hill:
So these issues really do need to be looked at very carefully and I don't think they were looked at carefully by the Minister or his department.
Presenter:

It makes you wonder, doesn't it, about some of these diplomatic positions. They . . . they seem to, as you say, outlive their usefulness, but they're maintained may be because that it's comfortable political appointment for a Government paying individuals, per se, a few things.
Hill:

Well there's been . . . thankfully not too many of . . . of recent times. I've been . . . I've been critical of some. My . . . my approach has been that if . . . if . . . the person who is best qualified should . . . for the job should have it, and . . . and even in the case of some of the . . . this Government's political appointments, I've said that they have been people who have been well qualified.

I can remember former President of Senate in London. I can think of another example of a diplomatic appointment of a former politician to San Francisco, which I criticised, because I said that I didn't think he was the best person for that particular job.
So these decisions should all be made based on . . . on merit. Sometimes they are and sometimes they aren't, and if they aren't they shouldn't be made.
Presenter:
I remember a few eyebrows were raised when Gough Whitlam was . . . was . . . took up that position in Paris with UNESCO. Is . . . is that position still going?
Hill:
Ambassador to UN . . . to UNESCO?
Presenter:
Yeah.
Hill:
I . . . I think we have downgraded it and now . . . and now the . . . I think the Deputy in Paris . . . for our mission in Paris has the task of leading the delegation to UNESCO.
Presenter:
Are there many other jobs like that UNESCO one?
Hill:
Well there . . . there are. I mentioned there were three ambassadors in . . . in Geneva.
Presenter:
Yeah.
Hill:

Now the . . . the Ambassador for Disarmament, whereas we are all in favour of disarmament it is . . . and there are still difficult challenges in wrapping up the chemical weapons convention, but nevertheless the way the world has gone with the end of the Cold War, I would think it's now hard to justify that . . . that sort of position.

And . . . and these . . . these have to be re . . . reviewed, I readily accept that because they do cost a lot of money and the taxpayers, particularly in our part of circumstances has got to get value for his or her dollar.
Presenter:
Well Senator if all goes well for you at the next election, would you be trimming much fat from around the world?

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to notice given at the last day of sitting, on behalf of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee I now withdraw Business of the Senate notices of motion Nos. 1 and 2 standing in Senator Loosley's name for three sitting days after today for the disallowance of the Australian Postal Corporation Regulations (Amendment) as contained in Statutory Rules 1992, No. 132, and the 24 Hour Registered Nurse and Small Nursing Homes Additional Funding Principles 1992, 24 SH1/1992, made under the National Health Act 1953. I seek leave to make a short statement about the Committee's consideration of the Australian Postal Corporation Regulations.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The regulations contain provisions that extend the circumstances under which the employees of the Australian Postal Corporation may disclose information for several purposes, including disclosure to ASIO and law enforcement bodies of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory. They also provide for the trial of a system in Queensland which, if successful, may lead to the introduction of a national change of address service whereby, as the explanatory statement notes, on the written election of a person, the person's new address is given to mailers in possession of the person's former address.

PARA.TAB: The Committee had a number of concerns about the regulations and, therefore, decided that it should hear evidence from the officers from the Department of Transport and Communications.The matters which concerned the Committee included the need for and width of the powers provided in the regulations; the incorporation of the wide provisions in regulations rather than in the principal Act; and whether the Privacy Commissioner had been consulted in respect of regulations. On 16 September, the last day for giving notice, the Committee gave notice of disallowance of the regulations for 12 sitting days after that day to enable it to examine matters further in the light of evidence given.

Having further considered the evidence, the Committee advised the Minister that unless its concerns were met, it would bring forward the notice of motion to disallow the regulations to the first week of sittings in October. In the meantime it wrote to the Privacy Commissioner seeking his comments on the matters of concern to it. The Minister then agreed to repeal and remake the regulations, to limit the period of the trial of the national change of address scheme and to narrow its operation. The circumstances in which information may be released to ASIO and law enforcement agencies would also be limited, preparatory to the introduction of a Bill in the Autumn sittings next year so that Parliament could debate this whole issue.

Although this response substantially met our concerns, the Committee asked for further clarification of several matters because of the sensitive issues of personal rights involved. The Minister provided this information and also undertook to provide a sunset clause for the ASIO and law enforcement provisions. While the Committee did consider leaving its disallowance motion in place until these undertakings were fulfilled, section 48B of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 provides that regulations the same in substance as existing regulations may not be made while a notice of disallowance is on the Notice Paper. However, the Committee understands that the new regulations will be made within a number of days.

In relation to the broader matter, the Committee draws particular attention to the general comments made by the Privacy Commissioner to the Department of Transport and Communications concerning the sheltering by certain departments behind the lowest common denominator provisions governing disclosure under the Privacy Act. The Committee foreshadows that it will be giving close attention to the principles raised by the Privacy Commissioner as they affect Commonwealth administration and the operations of the Committee, and it will report to the Senate in due course. As usual I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard its correspondence with the Minister and letters from the Privacy Commissioner which will show our concerns and the cooperation received from the relevant Minister, Mr Bob Brown. I add for the record that again the Regulations and Ordinances Committee is a truly bipartisan committee of the Senate and, indeed, is always concerned with people's rights.
Leave granted.

AUSTRALIAN POSTAL CORPORATION REGULATIONS (AMENDMENT) STATUTORY RULES No 132 of 1992
Current Legislation
Subsection 92 (1) of the Australian Postal Corporation Act 1989 makes it the duty of an Australia Post employee not to disclose any fact or document relating to:
the contents of postal articles;
postal or telecommunications services provided by Australia Post; or
the affairs or personal particulars (including any address) of another person;
that has come to the employee's knowledge as a consequence of the person's employment with Australia Post.
Subsection 92(2) creates exceptions to subsection 92(1), which enable an employee of Australia Post to disclose any facts or documents:
in the performance of his or her duties; or
as a witness summonsed to give evidence or produce documents in a court of law; or
under the requirements of a law of the Commonwealth; or
in prescribed circumstances.

Section 70 of the Crimes Act 1914 makes it an offence for an employee of Australia Post to disclose a fact or document which comes to the employee's knowledge by virtue of his or her employment and which it is the employee's duty not to disclose.
The need for regulations to create further exceptions
The Regulations were prepared to enable the disclosure of information in the following circumstances:
to an authorised officer of ASIO in connection with ASIO's functions;
where it is reasonably necessary for the enforcement of the criminal law, Commonwealth laws imposing a pecuniary penalty or protection of the public revenue; and
where the fact or document relates to the affairs or personal particulars (including any address) of another person and:

PARA.TAB: the other person is reasonably likely to have been aware that such information is usually disclosed in those circumstances;
the other person has consented; or
disclosure is necessary to lessen a serious threat to life or health.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the issues that led to the making of the regulations concerned the need for details about holders of post office boxes to be able to be disclosed for law enforcement purposes when those boxes are used for the purpose of defrauding consumers or the Commonwealth.

An example of the latter has been the use of post office boxes as contact addresses by persons illegally operating radio transmitters, or failing to pay their transmitter licence fees. The regulations will enable Australia Post to provide address details concerning such persons when it is reasonably necessary to do so to enforce offences under the Radiocommunications Act.

A second issue prompting the making of the regulations concerned Australia Post's proposed National Change of Address Scheme. This scheme will provide for an Australia Post customer's new address to be given to mailers who are in possession of the customer's former address. The scheme will only apply with the express consent of the customer. The scheme will also only apply to mailers who subscribe to the scheme. The scheme is being trialed in Queensland. Australia Post advises that since the introduction of the new change of address form in Queensland in July 1992 around 90% of applicants have authorised the release of their new address.

Additionally 40% of applicants have requested Australia Post to pass on their new address to Priority Address Notification subscribers listed on the form, ie Commonwealth Bank, Credit Union Australia, Queensland Teachers Credit Union, RACQ and Suncorp. The Queensland trial is expected to run for 6 to 9 months. The trial can only proceed because the regulations that have been put in place allow the disclosure of address information.
The width of the exceptions under the Regulations

Regulation 20(a) enables disclosure to an authorised officer of ASIO in connection with ASIO's functions. This exception, which enables disclosure for national security purposes, is in the same terms as the exception in paragraph 88(3)(c) of the Telecommunications Act 1991.

Regulation 20(b) enables disclosure where it is reasonably necessary for the enforcement of the criminal law, Commonwealth laws imposing a pecuniary penalty or protection of the public revenue. This provision is in the same terms as Information Privacy Principle ll(l)(e) in section 14 of the Privacy Act 1988 and paragraph 88(3)(g) of the Telecommunications Act.
Regulation 20(c) enables disclosure where a fact or document relates to the affairs or personal particulars (including any address) of another person and:
the other person is reasonably likely to have been aware that such information is usually disclosed in those circumstances;
the other person has consented; or
disclosure is necessary to lessen a serious threat to life or health.
This provision is in similar terms to IPP ll(l)(a), (b) and (c) respectively in section 14 of the Privacy Act 1988 and paragraph 88(3)(e) of the Telecommunications Act.
The Attorney-General's Department has advised that the regulation is legally consistent with the Privacy Act.
Were any limitations to the width of the power contemplated?
The provisions of the proposed regulations are permissive, enabling disclosure of facts or documents only in the circumstances set out.

In practice, disclosure of information under these regulations will be additionally limited by Australia Post's own internal policies. For example, under the National Change of Address Scheme, disclosure of information will occur only with the express prior consent of the individual concerned.

Australia Post is subject to the Privacy Act as it is a Commonwealth agency. The internal policies will themselves be subject to the requirements of the Information Privacy Principles (eg information storage and security systems required under IPP 4) and the jurisdiction of the Privacy Commissioner. Under IPP 2, where Australia Post collects information, it will be required to ensure that the individual is aware of its usual disclosure practices with respect to such information. It is intended that this notification would include notification of permitted disclosures for which consent is not required such as disclosures under paragraphs 20(b)(i), (ii) and (iii) and paragraphs 20(c)(i) and (iii).
Why are the exemptions included in regulations rather than in an enactment?

When the Australian Postal Corporation Act 1988 was enacted, the Parliament included a specific power in paragraph 92(2)(d) to enable further exceptions to the anti-disclosure provision to be specified in regulations. Presumably this was done in recognition that not all the circumstances in which the public interest would require disclosure could be identified in advance and that there should be the flexibility to include further exceptions as required.

However, if the Committee is of the view that it is more desirable that the exceptions be included in the Act rather than the Regulations, the Government will give consideration to the possibility of amending the Act to do so. Something similar occurred when the Telecommunications Act was rewritten last year. Regulations made under the Telecommunications Act 1989 in the same terms as regulation 20 of the Australian Postal Corporation Regulations were incorporated into section 88 of the 1991 Act.
Was the Privacy Commissioner consulted on the regulation?
The Privacy Commissioner was consulted in the drafting of the regulation. The Commissioner raised two concerns with the proposed amendments:
whether the Information Privacy Principle 11 disclosure exceptions are sufficient for defining the level of secrecy that should attach to the mail; and
whether the exceptions have the effect of ousting the oversight role of the Privacy Commissioner.

In relation to the first concern, this Department took the view that the appropriate balance for the disclosure provision for Australia Post was that agreed to by the Parliament when it adopted the Privacy Principles in the Privacy Act. At the practical level, we do not see scope for the erosion of privacy protection arising from the regulation.

The Privacy Commissioner's concern about protecting the secrecy of mail is primarily dealt with by provisions other than section 92. In particular, subregulation 3(1) of the Australian Postal Corporation Regulations prohibits opening of a postal article other than in accordance with the regulations. The regulations only allow the opening of mail in a narrow range of circumstances, such as:
opening an undeliverable article to obtain sufficient information to deliver it;
opening an article to repair it;
where there are reasonable grounds for believing the article contains contraband or dutiable items.
The disclosure regulations are expected to operate mainly in relation to address information. The disclosure regulations will not affect the existing restrictions on the opening of mail.

The second concern was that the amendments may have the effect of ousting the jurisdiction of the Privacy Commissioner. This Department has received advice from the Attorney-General's Department on this point. That Department has advised that if information is disclosed contrary to regulation 20, the disclosure would be inconsistent with IPP ll(l)(d) (that is disclosure would not be disclosure `required or authorised by or under law') and thus it would be a matter that the Privacy Commissioner could investigate if a complaint were made by the individual concerned. The making of this regulation thus does not affect the Privacy Commissioner's jurisdiction with respect to Australia Post.

In addition, as has been noted above, Australia Post employees will be required to follow internal guidelines. The Privacy Commissioner will have jurisdiction to ensure that those internal guidelines provide an appropriate protection for individual privacy.

In this regard, Australia Post has been consulting with the Privacy Commissioner on the establishment and implementation of the trial National Change of Address Scheme. In addition, the Privacy Commissioner has been invited by Australia Post to participate in an analysis of the trial results of the National Change of Address Scheme when implemented.

The Minister conveyed the specific concerns of the Privacy Commissioner to the Chairman of Australia Post on 24 June 1992. In particular, the Minister drew attention to the need for Australia Post employees to have regard for the Information Privacy Principles in implementing the regulations. A copy of this letter is attached.

Dear Senator Loosley
I refer to your letter of 8 October 1992 concerning disclosure of address information under the Australian Postal Corporation Regulations.

The Committee has sought clarification on a number of matters related to Australia Post's Queensland trial of the National Change of Address (NCOA) Scheme and disclosure of information for law enforcement purposes.
As I indicated in my letter of 6 October 1992, the earliest that amendments to the Australian Postal Corporation Act 1989 could be made would be the 1993 Autumn sittings of Parliament.

If the regulations were to be sunsetted on 31 January 1993, there would be a minimum gap of two to three months (perhaps more if current legislative priorities alter significantly, or if the Autumn 1993 sittings were interrupted) before the passage of primary legislation.

Australia Post advises that if this were the case, it would suffer financial detriment because it would be unable to provide continuity of service to individual customers and to its corporate clients participating in the trial scheme. Australia Post's has a significant investment (around $1 million) in training and network system configuration that would be reduced in value if the trial process was halted prematurely. In addition, the employment of thirteen casual staff would be terminated if the trial concluded in January 1993, with the prospect of a further five staff requiring redeployment.

In addition, because the new regulation will make clear that positive consent by an individual is required, Australia Post advises that the NCOA form will need to be modified for the trial period. (The use of the term "express consent" used in the drafting instructions, is intended to bear its plain meaning and is not intended to require people to "opt out" of the trial). There will thus need to be a further period of evaluation in view of the new form, and to enable consultation with the Privacy Commissioner on the effectiveness of the trial.

A sufficient period of time therefore needs to be provided so that any modifications can be properly assessed. I understand that the Office of the Privacy Commissioner has indicated that the operation of the trial to 30 September 1993 provides a reasonable trial period in which to assess the service. The extension of the trial to 30 September 1993 does not preclude legislation being introduced and passed earlier.

In relation to disclosure of address information for law enforcement purposes, I note the Committee's concerns in relation to the privacy implications of proposed disclosure of information for law enforcement purposes. The issues raised in paragraphs 7 to 10 of my letter of 6 October relating to disclosure of information for law enforcement purposes were canvassed with the Office of the Privacy Commissioner. The views of the Privacy Commissioner will be sought in the drafting of the proposed regulations. I note however, that the proposal is consistent with the exceptions set out in the Information Privacy Principles relating to criminal law enforcement and protection of public revenue.

In my view, it can be argued that a distinction should be made between the disclosure of the contents of mail and other information such as the ownership of post office boxes. However, in terms of intrusion into individuals' private dealings, I note and appreciate the Committee's concern about the need to control strictly the release of information about addresses or ownership of post office boxes. The Privacy Act complaint procedures would apply to disclosures made under this provision.

In particular, it is important to note that any disclosure would only be authorised to authorities with responsibility for criminal and related law enforcement, as well as to ASIO. I am advised that section 93A of the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act 1979 removes disclosure by all Commonwealth agencies to ASIO from the operation of the Privacy Act 1988. Proposals for disclosure to ASIO are therefore consistent with the Privacy Act. I understand that the Privacy Commissioner does not oppose this view.

In addition, I am advised that the Privacy Commissioner will have supervision over the disclosure of information including the contents of mail (which will only be disclosed where authorised under the requirements of a Commonwealth law or a search warrant). I also note that the agencies likely to make use of this provision have strict internal and often legislatively based disciplinary controls over the unauthorised use and disclosure of information.

The Australian Federal Police (AFP) and ASIO have advised that access to this information is essential in assisting in the identification of people in groups involved in criminal or national security related activities. One obvious application in the Commonwealth area is in the investigation of drug trafficking. In relation to State and Territory authorities such a disclosure provision could also be extremely useful in investigating for example, paedophile groups exchanging information about the availability of children and child pornography.
The Privacy Commissioner will be consulted on the drafting of the proposed regulation. The matters set out in paragraphs 7 to 10 of my 6 October letter have already been raised with him.

I intend that the proposed regulations include requirements that each disclosure be recorded and that the disclosed information be treated confidentially by the agency to which it is released. In addition, I propose that a sunset clause be included in any regulations authorising access to information for law enforcement purposes, while primary legislation is developed. Because the legislation will need to be developed in consultation with State and Territory authorities I would propose that the regulations be made for a 12 month period to allow time for adequate consultation.

Representatives from the law enforcement and national security agencies have offered to provide in camera evidence to the Committee, should this be considered useful. It should be noted that law enforcement matters relate primarily to the portfolio responsibilities of the Attorney-General and the Minister for Justice, and I would propose to seek their views before such witnesses could be made available to the Committee.
Yours sincerely
BOB BROWN

I refer to your letter of 17 September l992.
As to the three questions that you raise:
"(a)when and how you discovered the existence of the regulations;

My office was notified on 26 May l992 by the Department that it was considering amending the regulations. It provided its draft text. It requested comment by the next day, 27 May. Preliminary comments were provided as requested; and a detailed response was given on 7 July. Both letters are enclosed.

My office received no further advice from the Department as to whether it intended to proceed with its draft regulations. So, I was a little surprised to discover that the regulations had in fact been tabled.
"(b)when you received the request for advice in respect of the regulations, referred to in the first paragraph of your letter;
See my answer to (a) above.
"(c)whether as yet you have been in touch with the relevant Minister. If so, when, and is it possible for your advice to be made available to the Committee?
No, I did not proceed to contact the relevant Minister. I might have done so had I been aware that the regulations were proceeding.
I should add that I received, on 14 September, a letter dated l0 September from the Department making further comments in respect of my letter of 7 July 1992. I also enclose a copy of that letter.
