DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Select Committee on the Functions, Powers and Operation of the Australian Loan Council

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: (1)That a select committee, to be known as the Select Committee on the Functions, Powers and Operation of the Australian Loan Council, be appointed to inquire into and report upon the following matters by 1 March 1993:

TAB.TAB: (a)the functions, powers and operation of the Australian Loan Council in co-ordinating all financial transactions by all Commonwealth and State bodies, including Government business enterprises, instrumentalities and other authorities, which involve a call on the private sector;
(b)the role of all Governments in the Loan Council process, including the provision of information to the council and the advising of other council members on the activities of members;
(c)the administration of global borrowing limits set by the council, in particular, the administration of breaches and possible breaches of those limits;

(d)the responsibility and powers of the federal Treasurer, as Chairman of the Loan Council, in dealing with breaches or possible breaches of the global borrowing limits, particularly as they affect the national economy; and

(e)the powers (and limits of power) of State Premiers and Treasurers to administer borrowing agreements approved by the council and the responsibilities of State Premiers and Treasurers to notify the council about the borrowing activities of their Governments.

PARA.TAB: (2)That the committee consist of seven Senators, as follows:
(a)three nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate;

TAB.TAB: (b)two nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate;
(c)one nominated by the Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate; and
(d)one nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats.

PARA.TAB: (3)That the committee may proceed to the despatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(4)That:

TAB.TAB: (a)the chairman of the committee be appointed by and from the members of the committee;
(b)the deputy-chairman of the committee be appointed by and from the members of the committee immediately after the appointment of the chairman;
(c)the deputy-chairman act as chairman when there is no chairman or the chairman is not present at a meeting; and
(d)in the event of the votes on any question before the committee being equally divided, the chairman, or the deputy-chairman when acting as chairman, have a casting vote.

PARA.TAB: (5)That a Senator who is not a member of the committee may participate in its public sessions and question witnesses, unless the committee orders otherwise, but shall not vote.
(6)That the quorum of the committee be three members.

(7)That the committee and any subcommittee have power to send for and examine persons and documents, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives.

(8)That the committee have power to appoint subcommittees consisting of three or more of its members, and to refer to any such subcommittee any of the matters which the committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a subcommittee be a majority of the Senators appointed to the subcommittee.

(9)That the committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the committee, with the approval of the President.

SPEECH.PARA: (10)That the committee be empowered to print from day to day such documents and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.

(11)That the committee may report from time to time its proceedings and evidence taken and any interim conclusions and recommendations arising from its inquiry, and may make regular reports on the progress of its proceedings.

What has become apparent during the last several days and what has come out of the disclosure in relation to the unsatisfactory nature of the Victorian loans affair, as it has become known, is that the issue is much broader than this. The whole conduct of the Australian Loan Council with respect to the records which are kept by State governments and made available between State governments and between the State governments and the Commonwealth is totally unsatisfactory.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday two Treasury officers came before the Democrat party room, and with respect to material which appeared as supplements to the Budget Papers made statements to the effect that the figures which are provided by the States are so unreliable that they would place no confidence in them whatsoever. Indeed, the officers went on to imply that over some time they had given general advice to successive Treasurers that perhaps it would be better not to publish them at all because there was so little confidence in those figures.

We also have the situation from June until the present time, well referenced in letters between the Federal Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) and the former Victorian Government, in relation to the matter of almost $1.3 billion worth of loans. The indications are that throughout the whole of that time the Federal Government and the State Government of Victoria had a different view with respect to whether those loans fell within or outside the terms of the Loan Council. We have learnt only since last night, when Mr Kennett came to Canberra and spoke with the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Treasurer, that indeed those loans of $1.3 billion should not have been entered into and should have been included within declarations made by the Victorian Government to the Loan Council and, through the Loan Council, to other governments.

Given that the Loan Council handles large amounts of money, running into billions of dollars, and given that this country is in dire financial straits, with debts running in excess of $150 billion, it is absolutely staggering to learn that the conduct of a major part of this country's financial arrangements is left with a council best described as an old boys' network which operates in a nudge nudge, wink wink way without any proper legislative backing. Indeed, the hands of the Federal Treasurer, who one might have thought had some overall responsibility for the financial health of this country, are largely tied when it comes to obtaining information which would allow him or her, as the case might be, to find out whether loans—and in this case, loans of $1.3 billion—were inside or outside the global limits. That situation is totally unsatisfactory, particularly when we have this very large and growing foreign debt hanging over our heads. It is clearly one which needs to be addressed and tightened up.

We are of a view that clearly there must have been a presumption over some months on the part of Treasury and the Federal Treasurer that the $1.3 billion did fall within the ambit of the Loan Council, that it should therefore have been taken into account, and that Victoria should have been brought into line earlier in a similar way to the way in which the former Federal Treasurer, now the Prime Minister, brought Queensland into line when Mr Ahern threatened to go outside the limits of the Loan Council. Putting the best complexion on it, the Treasurer claims that he could not be sure, even up until yesterday, whether even a single dollar of that money was actually passed on to the private sector—that it was not all held within the public sector—therefore falling outside the ambit of the Loan Council. That situation is quite intolerable and we believe it needs to be addressed.

Now that we know that the $1.3 billion does fall within the ambit of the Loan Council, the following question, which I put earlier today, can be validly asked: what assurance and certainty did the Federal Treasurer have earlier on and before the Budget about whether that $1.3 billion was within or outside the Loan Council arrangements? Back in June was he already 90 per cent certain that he was dealing with something which fell outside the Loan Council arrangements? If he was reasonably certain—and I think the evidence now points to the fact that he could have been reasonably certain at that time—in our view he should have taken a much stronger action with respect to the misdemeanour of the Victorian Government. As also indicated at Question Time today, he could have insisted that a footnote be put in the Budget Papers and that much stronger letters be written to the Victorian Government.
We do not wish to pursue that matter in isolation because we believe that the matters are much more serious than that and really go to the heart of the whole functioning of the Loan Council itself.

The Federal Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, has said—and indeed the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) this afternoon repeated in Question Time—that at a meeting in December the Loan Council will be beginning its own inquiry into how better to manage its affairs. We find this approach quite unsatisfactory. It really is Caesar judging Caesar.

The Loan Council is an `in' group; it is a cosy little group. We believe that it is quite naive for the Federal Treasurer, or indeed anybody, to expect that the State Premiers will impose upon themselves the sorts of sanctions that clearly, in our view, need to be imposed upon them. It remains to be seen whether this is done by a much tighter agreement on the definition of what falls inside and outside loans, the way in which loans can be raised, the reporting procedures, or whether it needs legislative control. But appropriately that should be done in a much more open way than within the confines of the Loan Council itself. So we believe that the Federal Treasurer's proposal, good as it might be, simply does not go far enough; it needs to go very much further.

Addressing the other aspect involving the confidence that the public can have in the Loan Council and in the markets, one finds an enormous degree of inconsistency in the Treasurer's remarks. On the one hand, the Treasurer seems to have claimed, as I think Senator Button claimed again this afternoon, that to release information before there was a solution in place would destabilise the markets by decreasing confidence in the Australian dollar, would increase interest rates, and would make people generally less confident in the operation of the Australian economy.

On the other hand, we find that Mr Dawkins himself is writing to Mr Fahey suggesting in fairly strong terms that there be a continuous process of disclosure to the Loan Council by the various States. Clearly, under such a process those disclosures would occur before any ameliorating processes were put in place at all. Yet the Treasurer in his letter to Mr Fahey is claiming that that disclosure procedure would lead to greater confidence in the operation of the system and greater certainty in the way in which the markets responded to the information which was disclosed.

The Treasurer cannot have it both ways. If we look at evidence of concealment, we see that Mr David Parker, who was a Minister in the Western Australian Government during the Rothwell's scandal and with particular reference to the petrochemical industry in Western Australia, said—and I understand this is a direct quote—that concealment was `a necessary technique used by all governments'. That seems to be the name of the game over there. One can only point to what happened in Western Australia where concealment led to a much worse situation eventually when the facts came out, with a very great loss of confidence in both the Government and the administrative processes of Western Australia, quite apart from any effects on the economy.

We do not believe concealment is warranted. We feel that concealment for any time at all leads eventually to corruption and further corruption, and then eventually to greater destabilisation of the market. So we certainly would support the Treasurer to the extent that he is arguing for greater disclosure by the States one to another and by the Commonwealth to the States through the Loan Council so that the whole process by which loans are raised, the amounts of those loans and their purposes are much more clearly understood. That would indeed lead to a great deal more confidence in the process.

I reiterate that to expect that the Loan Council members themselves are actually going to undertake that sort of restructuring of the Loan Council is really cloud-cuckoo-land; I do not think it will happen. It is something that needs to be pressed for from outside the Loan Council through the sorts of processes of a Senate inquiry, which is now being addressed.

There are a couple of other issues I would like to just throw in here because, while they have not yet been raised, we in the Democrats think that they are relevant. The Victorian situation appears to have arisen, to some extent at least, because of the building of another power station, the Loy Yang power station. We are aware that other States have also got into problems—or potentially might get into problems—with the building of new power stations. In discussions yesterday the proposed coal-fired power station at Collie was mentioned.

It has been a source of continual upset and disappointment to the Australian Democrats that the record in relation to the building of more power stations and the effect that they have on the State debts and the national debts has been evident for some time. I do not have a current figure but not so long ago the figure for the amount owed by State electricity utilities around Australia amounted to $26 billion.

There is abundant evidence, both within Australia and from overseas, that we do not need to build more power stations; that we can in fact achieve a greater level of energy security if we pursue more vigorously the energy efficiency path. Indeed, it was one of the subjects that came out of the greenhouse reference to the Industry, Science and Technology Committee of this Senate and it also came out very clearly in the ESD process. What is required is for the Federal Government, again, to take firm control of an energy policy for Australia, an energy policy which is built around conservation and the more conservative and wiser use of electricity—a very expensive form of energy. Had that happened, some of these problems—and I stress the word `some'—may not have arisen in relation to foreign debt. A very considerable saving can be made should that procedure be followed. I urge again that the Government revisit the greenhouse committee report and the ESD committee recommendations in relation to the lack of need to build more power stations.

It is quite conceivable that in the very near future Queensland will be in a similar situation with respect to the Loan Council. In the last week that I was up there during the last fortnight break I found that the North Queensland Electricity Board wants to extend the grid into Far North Queensland up into the Daintree at an enormous cost per consumer—money which is simply going to be wasted because there are far better and far cheaper alternatives. It is about time this Federal Government developed and imposed on the States a far more sensible and rational national energy policy.

The other matter to which I turn is the advice which was given to the Federal Treasurer by Treasury and on which the Treasurer very solidly depended in relation to the Victorian loans affair. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer could make a public announcement regarding Victoria's breach of the Loan Council arrangements and distancing the Commonwealth from Victorian borrowing arrangements. However, this could have (unpredictable) adverse market consequences in respect of Victoria's debt.

We accept that, given that advice, it was reasonable that the Treasurer behaved in the way he did. However, in view of the reasonable certainty that he had that that $1.3 billion was inside the Loan Council arrangements, we believe that it would have been more appropriate for the Federal Treasurer to have been tougher in his approach to Victoria. That is our judgment, and it is one from which, clearly, one can differ; but our judgment is that he should have been much firmer with respect to that matter.

PARA.TAB: The situation, of course, is now desperate with respect to Victoria. Again, I just reiterate that had the Minister taken action much earlier, of course, we would not be in this situation. We believe that a Federal Senate inquiry is an appropriate way of dealing with this; it is a public and open way of dealing with it. That is far more appropriate than the Loan Council internal inquiry suggested by the Treasurer, and we think that this should be proceeded with as rapidly as possible. Accordingly, and in view of the very heavy legislative program we are now facing, we have suggested a reporting date of 1 March next year, which we think will allow the Committee, through the Christmas break, to deal adequately with this matter—to call the witnesses and to report. We hope that out of that we will be able to really put some cement into this very loose hole which now lies right at the very heart of the whole financial administration of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak in support of the motion moved by Senator Coulter, and I will come back to that in a moment. The reason why I have pleasure in supporting that motion is that it enables consideration of what is without any doubt, in the coalition's view, a major conspiracy between the Keating Government and the previous Kirner Labor Government in Victoria—a conspiracy to conceal the truth from the electors of Victoria, from other Premiers and Chief Ministers of the States and Territories of Australia, and from the financial markets of Australia—and, therefore, for all of those reasons, a conspiracy to conceal the truth from all Australians about a matter that goes to the core of proper government in this country.

PARA.TAB: What the Keating Government and the former Victorian Labor Government have done was to gravely damage the credibility and integrity of the Loan Council, a body which is absolutely crucial to the orderly functioning of financial markets in Australia and which, as a result of that, is absolutely crucial to the functioning of the Australian economy, the growth of the Australian economy, the provision of jobs for Australians and the growth of our export markets. Everything that happens in the Australian economy has a relevance to the functions of the financial markets in Australia, and the operation of the financial markets in Australia can be efficient and effective only if those financial markets have confidence and can trust the basic financial institutions, particularly those financial institutions of government—and the Loan Council is perhaps the most central of those financial institutions.

What we have seen quite clearly from the material that has come out up to date is that Mr Keating—both as Prime Minister and in his former capacity of Treasurer, but particularly in recent months as Prime Minister—and his Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, were parties to this conspiracy. There is no less weight, no less result, that can attach to the evidence that has already been revealed. It appears from his answers to questions in the Senate today—and I must express amazement at this—that the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, is arguably a party to that conspiracy as well.

Senator Button told the Senate today that he knew in July of this year about the matter, at least to the extent that the Government—of which he is the third most senior member—had communicated with the Victorian Government about the breaching of the global limits. For Senator Button to say as he did in Question Time today that he did not know anything more about it until it all broke in the last few days—I am glad to see Senator Button here in the chamber—is, quite frankly, something that boggles the imagination in its credibility.

Who else knew about this? We have a pretty senior Federal Minister from Victoria in the form of Mr Willis. He, after all, is the Minister for Finance of this country. He, along with Mr Dawkins as the Treasurer, are the double responsible for the economic management of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Jim Cairns was a Treasurer.

—As my friend Senator Parer points out, we had another notable Victorian—I will come back to this a little later on—in the form of Mr Jim Cairns who had one or more fingers in pies of this nature in times gone by. What did Mr Willis know about the matters that are of such grave concern as to have led to the motion for the establishment of this committee? Mr Willis is one Minister above most others who has not yet disclosed his hand and who really does need to come clean about what he knew about this.

PARA.TAB: If Mr Willis knew about the illegal breaching of guidelines by the Victorian Government, then he stands indicted of conspiracy to defraud the Australian people along with the Prime Minister and the Treasurer. If he did not know, then it is an even greater indictment of Treasurer Dawkins for not having communicated with his key colleague on the economic and financial management of this country.

That is the brief background to the reasons why the coalition supports this motion before us today. Indeed, the motion is a welcome response to the coalition's call late last week for the establishment of just such a committee. It was the proposal initially of the coalition, particularly of my friend and colleague the shadow Treasurer, Mr Peter Reith, that there be a Senate select committee established to deal with this matter. Ideally, we would have liked to see a joint parliamentary committee with representatives from both the House and the Senate, but that was obviously never going to be on since the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the Government's acolytes in the House would under no circumstances allow the establishment of such a joint committee as they have been spending the last few months doing all they could to conceal the truth of this matter.

So a Senate select committee is the only way we can go, and we welcome that. It is by no means a second choice, although it would have been better, of course, to have had a joint parliamentary committee. But Senate select committees in the past have performed very important roles indeed, and I have no doubt that this committee will do the same.

I put it on the record that, following discussions within the coalition late last week, I raised the matter on Saturday with Senator Kernot, the Treasury spokesperson for the Democrats. Some suggested broad terms of reference were provided to the Democrats. The matter has since evolved in that we had very useful and valuable discussions with the Democrats yesterday. As a result of those discussions, this motion has come forward, and I welcome the positive response of the Democrats to the initiative of the coalition for the establishment of this committee.
I draw attention to the fact that there is a 1 March 1993 reporting date. We would wish the committee to start its work immediately. The terms of reference for the committee provide in part:

SPEECH.PARA: That the committee may report from time to time its proceedings and evidence taken or any interim conclusions or recommendations arising from its inquiry, and may make regular reports on the progress of its proceedings.

I hope the committee will quickly commence its work and provide the Parliament and, indeed, the Australian people with progress reports on its activities and findings. A great deal of information may still emerge. We have only found the information available to us now by drawing it out tooth by tooth in the last couple of weeks. The Government was not going to disclose anything. Then it trickled out a few papers. We pressed the matter further and it was forced to trickle out a few more papers, and it has gone on and on. The material we have before us now is the result of about half a dozen separate extractions from the Government of material.

PARA.TAB: Heaven only knows what else is still to come. One thing of which we can be sure is that we have probably only scratched the tip of the iceberg in terms of the information about this matter. How much more has been covered up? I do not know how much more has been covered up. No-one knows how much more has been covered up—with the probable exception of the Prime Minister and the Treasurer. They are the chief conspirers. It is absolutely vital that this committee do all it can to draw out that further information. I put the Government and the officials of government—both at the Federal and, I hope, at the State level—on notice that we will be expecting the fullest and frankest disclosure and presentation of material to the committee.

The motion goes further than just the Victorian debacle, conspiracy, of recent months. It is a conspiracy that has in fact been going on for about three years now. Without getting into too much detail, the simple point is that short term, temporary borrowings by a State government are excluded from the guidelines and the requirements of the Loan Council. The Loan Council relates basically to the medium and long term borrowings that States agree each year in trust and confidence with each other in meeting with the Commonwealth to borrow for the ensuing year. It now transpires that the Victorian Government, as long ago as 1987-88, has been borrowing on a short term basis but continually rolling over those short term borrowings so that those short term borrowings have become in fact long term borrowings. In that sense, it has been breaching the guidelines of the Loan Council for all that period of time.

But the truly monumental conspiracy arose this year with the conversion by the Victorian Government of the short term borrowings of $1.3 billion—we are talking not about bikkies here but about huge sums of money—without telling anyone, although the Commonwealth eventually found out that it had converted to medium and long term debt.

The matter was not raised, as was required, at the Loan Council meeting on 12 June. Figures were not submitted to that meeting. They were submitted to the Federal Treasury five days later, on 17 June. But the Treasurer did not raise the potentiality of a breach when he was alerted by the Treasury, by his own advisers, in March of this year or when he had concern expressed to him by the then New South Wales Premier Greiner in April of this year. He did not even respond to then Premier Greiner's letter of concern.

At this point let me welcome very warmly indeed the call by the Acting Treasurer of New South Wales, Mr Wal Murray, today for precisely the type of Senate inquiry that we are now in the process of establishing. New South Wales has seen what can happen when States do not play fairly or openly with each other, when the Commonwealth engages in conspiracies with particular States to hide the truth from other States. New South Wales has seen it at first hand. Queensland has seen it at first hand.

The remarkable and disgraceful thing is the double standards of hypocrisy regarding the Keating Government's treatment of this matter and its treatment of Queensland in 1988, when Queensland sought to borrow beyond the borrowing guidelines and the global limit—borrowings sought frankly and openly from the Commonwealth Government—and was refused. Indeed, the Commonwealth passed an Act to amend the Financial Agreements Act to stop Queensland from doing so. That was, of course, a non-Labor government.

Yet we have Labor's mates in Victoria, the Kirner Government, desperately anxious to try to survive the unsurvivable—which was the last election result in Victoria—being assisted in every way possible by Prime Minister Keating, Treasurer Dawkins, and the other conspirators here in Canberra. The double standards and the hypocrisy that mark the difference between those two are absolutely incredible. I remind the Senate again of the Queensland situation in May 1988, when Paul Keating was then Treasurer Keating and when the Queensland Government wanted to borrow outside the guidelines. As I say, the Commonwealth was then prepared to insert a special clause into the State's Financial Agreements Bill to prevent it doing so. At that time Treasurer Keating said:

SPEECH.PARA: In the national interest it cannot accept that any State can seek to take financial advantage contrary to the benefit of the nation as a whole.

If Treasurer Keating believed that in 1988, when the then Queensland Government came forward openly and honestly, how on earth can he live with his conscience or credibility with the situation over the last six months, where he has deliberately worked and conspired with the Victorian Government to conceal the truth from the Australian people, from the Victorian electors just before the Victorian election, and from all the other States? Not only that—he did it in a way where he fiddled the books, where he provided a Commonwealth Budget which did not have the necessary explanatory footnotes to keep that Budget honest.

PARA.TAB: If the Prime Minister and Treasurer fiddled the presentation of the 1992 Budget and they have been caught out, how do we know how many other fiddles in that Budget there may well be? We have never been able to trust the arithmetic of this Government. It has never got it right. Now we find we cannot even trust its honesty in attempting to get its figures right. That is a dreadful indictment of the Government. It is a matter of the gravest concern because it means that no longer can the electorate, can financial markets—either here or overseas—or can the economy have any faith that what is in the Budget is honest, that it is the full truth and nothing but the truth. If one cannot have faith and confidence in what is presented in the Budget documents, if one cannot have faith that they were honestly put together, even though they may be wrong, with the best will in the world, then the consequences for our nation are really very grave indeed.

It has been argued, and Senator Coulter picked this up in his comments, by the Government and by some in the media, some of whom have been sufficiently gullible to go along with this line—fortunately, a lot of others have been much more responsible—that the Government's concealing the truth of what it did was necessary to enable markets to have confidence and not to be unsettled. Could one ever find a more monstrous distortion of reality? We have seen it happen before. I come back to Jim Cairns and the events of 1974 and 1975. Do honourable senators know what Prime Minister Whitlam said at the start of the Khemlani loans affair? I think Senator Button was around in those days. He looks as though he is going to be here for two conspiracies by one of his governments in his lifetime.

Senator Button knows what Gough Whitlam said. He said that we cannot provide the material because the markets will lose confidence—`We cannot tell them about the Khemlani affair because the markets will lose confidence'. Look what happened as a result of that. Look what happened to Australia. Look what happened to the Whitlam Government—thank heavens—as a result of it. Those events set Australia's place in the world and its reputation in the world back by, I would say, a period of time which has not yet even been erased. We are still suffering from the consequences, the events, the distortions, the untruths, the concealments and the conspiracies of that time. Markets can operate efficiently and effectively only on the basis of full knowledge and full trust and confidence. If they do not have that, then there is no way that markets can provide the basis for an effective, competitive, growing economy that is so essential for the well-being of each and every Australian.

Yet we have the actions of the Victorian Government which have concealed the true situation in Victoria. Premier Jeff Kennett and his team have inherited a situation which they knew was going to be bad—they made no bones about it—prior to the election. But they inherited a situation which exceeded their wildest anticipations of what could have been the worst scenario. They inherited a State which is absolutely bankrupt as a result of the actions of a Labor Government which was great mates with this Federal Government right throughout its nine or 10 years in office, a government which this Federal Government went out of its way to try to protect and nurture right along the way, knowing full well that it was a rotten and corrupt and improper government.

We have had in recent months, in particular, the Federal Government acting in conspiracy with the then Victorian Government to do precisely the same, culminating in it deliberately forging the true situation in the 1992 Budget Papers. I think Senator Button was trying to say that the Government's hands were tied on this matter. The Federal Government's hands were not tied on this matter. They were in the taxpayers' cookie jar and the cookie jar of the financial markets of this country for all they could get.

The result of that is going to be very grave, not only for the future of the financial markets but also for the future of our financial institutions, particularly the financial institutions erected by government, of which the Loan Council is probably No. 1. Immense damage has been done to the credibility and integrity of those institutions.

So also is the damage that has been done to the trust and confidence that one State can have in another State's dealings with the Commonwealth. If the Commonwealth Government is going to do illegal deals with State governments, conspiring to conceal the real situation and not telling the other States, then how on earth can Premier Fahey in New South Wales look Premier Goss in Queensland in the eye—or more particularly the other way around—and say, `Gee, we know what you are doing in relation to the Commonwealth; we know there is a proper basis of propriety in terms of your operations with government'. I believe that one of the most serious matters is the destruction of trust that this event has caused between the States.

The select committee will deal with vital issues. It will deal with issues that go to the very core of government, to the core of financial relationships, and to the core of integrity, credibility and community confidence. For those reasons, the coalition believes, as we have said over recent days, that the establishment of this committee will be one of the most important events to have occurred in this Parliament for some considerable time. We are dealing with the biggest financial scandal, the biggest financial conspiracy, that we have had in Australia since the days of the Khemlani affair—the loans affair of the Whitlam Government.

The events of recent days have brought out, yet again, that there is no way any Australian can ever trust Labor to manage money. There is no way any Australian can ever hope that a Labor government can or will protect the basic financial structure of this country, the basic institutions that are essential to the effective operation of a democracy. I am amazed that the Treasurer has not resigned. I should be amazed that the Prime Minister has not sacked him because he has not resigned. I cannot be amazed, regrettably, at the fact that—

TALK.START.PARA: —He was the Treasurer who was at the bottom of the harbour; he was burying everybody else, remember?

—Senator Crichton-Browne is absolutely right. I am not amazed that Prime Minister Keating has not sacked Treasurer Dawkins because—and I am very sad this is the reason—Prime Minister Keating is as much up to his neck in this whole sorry matter as is Treasurer Dawkins. I hope very much that the committee which we are in the process of establishing will get to the bottom of these things, and not just in relation to the Victorian matter. The terms of reference go wider than that, and very rightly so. They go to looking at the whole role, relations and functions of the Loan Council and the whole question of the relationship between the Commonwealth Government and the States on financial matters. That is to be welcomed. It is a broader issue and that makes it even more important.

PARA.TAB: I support this very important motion. The coalition will be doing everything in its power to ensure that the committee operates effectively, efficiently, swiftly and in the interests of all Australians, in absolute contrast to the disgraceful, despicable performance of this present Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday the Premier of Victoria and the Treasurer of Victoria met with the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Federal Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) to discuss these issues. On that occasion, the Premier of Victoria gave the Prime Minister a letter, in which he said:

SPEECH.PARA: As presently advised, it does appear that Victoria has exceeded Loan Council borrowing approvals as from May 1992.
If a committee is established, that will be the evidence of the Premier of Victoria before it. I repeat:
As presently advised—
this is yesterday—
it does appear that Victoria has exceeded Loan Council borrowing approvals as from May 1992.
That is what the evidence of the Premier of Victoria will be. The point is that that is the first formal acknowledgment of that fact from the State of Victoria to the Commonwealth Treasurer.

TALK.START.PARA: —No it is not. They told Dawkins. He was told on 17 June; don't fib.

—Senator Bishop prides herself, I think, on being a master of the language. I said it is the first formal response from the Government. If Senator Bishop listens to my words and does not misrepresent them, she will see that that is the fact.
—This is all flip flap.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I am constantly subjected to interjections. When Senator Crichton-Browne speaks, no doubt he will remind us of the bottom of the harbour days, which were most distressing to him.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition and the Democrats are fighting over ownership of Senator Coulter's motion, which has been before this place for only half an hour. There is already a disagreement as to who owns this reference. Senator Short says, `We really thought of it, and we would have done it differently from you. The Democrats have really stolen our thunder'. Secondly, there is a fundamental difference in ideological position between the two proponents of this reference. Let me illustrate that. Senator Coulter went on and on about the need for regulation of these issues. Senator Short, who spends a lot of time in here talking about Fightback!, should read pages 63 and 64 of Fightback!—

TALK.START.PARA: —I helped write them.

—Senator Short helped write them. Those pages refer to competitive federalism; to the fact that State governments should be given a free hand in these matters; and to the fact that there should be no Federal government interference. That is the essence of what is said on those pages. That is called competitive federalism. This is what Senator Short advocates. But having been given the opportunity today to seize his chance to raise this matter on the back of the Democrats' motion, he came in here and talked a lot of bluster and rhetoric about the iniquities of this whole situation. But ideologically he would prefer a situation where this was not discoverable.

PARA.TAB: From early this year, in the spirit under which the Loan Council operates—and I will give honourable senators an understanding of that in a minute—the Commonwealth Treasurer, as custodian of the Loan Council arrangements, has been pursuing the State of Victoria in relation to suspicions, of which he now has a formal acknowledgment from the Premier of Victoria, that it does appear that Victoria has exceeded Loan Council borrowings. What is the spirit of the Loan Council arrangements? This is well described in a public document that has been made available by the Secretary to the Treasury. In that document, he refers to the Commonwealth Treasury providing the secretariat of the Loan Council and contacting States about various matters. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: These discussions are based on a perceived need for mutual cooperation rather than any sense that the Commonwealth Treasury has an auditing role over State finances. The Commonwealth relies on the States reporting their borrowings that fall within the coverage of the Loan Council borrowing global borrowing limits. The Loan Council arrangements are based on a voluntary agreement and rely for their effectiveness on the cooperation of all members.

It is no secret from any State—other than Victoria—and it is no secret from the Commonwealth, that that cooperation was not extended by the State Government in Victoria in the earlier part of this year.

PARA.TAB: It is quite clear that that is now the position as revealed by the Victorian Premier's letter, the Victorian Premier now saying that it appears that Victoria has exceeded Loan Council borrowings. The Secretary of the Treasury goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: However, if any concerns are raised about actions by any Loan Council member it typically falls to the Commonwealth to take the issue up with that State or Territory on behalf of other members of Loan Council.

That was the function which was performed by the Treasury and the Treasurer in pursuit of that arrangement; that arrangement which has been honoured by governments throughout the history of Commonwealth-State relationships and the Loan Council, and which is still the preferred option today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why not put an annotation on the Budget Papers?

—I have already answered a question about that at Question Time. Perhaps Senator Crichton-Browne did not hear; I do not know. I will turn now to some of the comments made in Senator Short's speech. Senator Short has been a long time in opposition. He comes in here and he calls it, as was agreed in the party room, and as Mr Reith has said, the loans scandal.
—I said `conspiracy'.

—He has a good new word of his own. Senator Jim Short has at last invented a new word: `conspiracy'. It is not a word he would use about this matter outside with impunity, but I am used to that from him. In trying to make his point about an alleged conspiracy, he used a lot of rhetoric to illustrate what he was trying to say. Let me make it quite clear: we are talking about $1.3 billion worth of State borrowings. There was a lot of confusion about this and about it being taxpayers' money, as if taxpayers' money was being taken directly. We are talking about borrowings.
—The interest has to be paid.

—Yes, we are not talking about $1.3 billion worth of taxpayers' money. I am saying that some of Senator Kemp's colleagues deal lightly with the truth, and I would not get too excited about that. The truth in this matter has been lightly dealt with when talking about the confused issues of borrowings with taxpayers' funds. It becomes a huge sum in the hands of Senator Short. Of course governments are accountable, and in this case in the State of Victoria it has been accountable in terms of these significant sums.

PARA.TAB: Senator Short does not come in here and talk about a company like Elders Finance, because it was presided over by the President of the Liberal Party, losing not $1.3 billion of borrowings, but $2.5 billion of shareholders' funds. Where is the accountability in respect of that company? We do not hear much about that from members of the Liberal Party, and for very obvious reasons—it was presided over by the President of their party. So when we talk about accountability on these issues we have to not build it up too much in our enthusiasm to establish what Senator Jim Short has originally called a conspiracy. I understand it is an original expression from him—he claims it. It is no longer the loans affair; it is an original conspiracy in the hands of Senator Short.

A number of issues have been raised in passing, some of them by Senator Coulter. There is a comparison sought to be drawn between events in Queensland in 1988 and the present situation which has developed in Victoria. What happened in Queensland was that the Premier of Queensland announced publicly that he was going to take on the Loan Council arrangements, which I referred to in the letter from the Secretary of Treasury, and he was going to break them. The Commonwealth Treasurer, as Chairman of the Loan Council and custodian of those arrangements, said, `You are not going to break them'.

The different situation in Victoria is simply this: in response to a series of inquisitions and a series of interrogatories of the Victorian Government from the Commonwealth Treasurer, as custodian of the Loan Council arrangements, he did not get answers. He did not get the correct answers, and that is the difference between what developed in Queensland and what developed in the State of Victoria. I do not think we want to spend too much time on that point.

The other point is this confusion about short term borrowings and medium term borrowings, which has been raised by a number of speakers. It does appear that the Victorian Government of the time sought to characterise some of these borrowings as short term borrowings which would be rolled over quickly. When one talks about the global limitations of borrowings by the States, one is talking about the figure which they have to arrive at as at 30 June this year—the end of the financial year. If the Victorian Government was rolling over short term borrowings beyond 30 June in each year, then of course they begin to take on the character of medium term borrowings and from that they become subject to Loan Council discipline.

That is the confusion which the Victorian Government has presented to other governments and the Commonwealth Government in relation to this matter; a confusion between short term borrowings continually rolled over, and medium term borrowings which are, of course, subject to the global limitations and Loan Council discipline.

TALK.START.PARA: —You wanted them re-elected.

—I would not get too excited about that. When I see what we have in Victoria at present—I always warned about that. That issue was the greatest motivation in my position of that problem. Mr Acting Deputy President, could I not be interrupted by this constant chit-chat.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—Senator Button is asking that there not be interjections. It is against the Standing Orders to have interjections.

TALK.START.PARA: —The final point I want to make is simply on the issue of the Treasurer of Australia as Chairman of the Loan Council, in possession of information about which he can have no confidence at all—as he was prior to the presentation of the Federal Budget in August this year—and whether he should have recorded a figure by way of footnote in the Budget documents about the loan position of the State of Victoria.

PARA.TAB: There was some experience in the past in relation to this in the Province of Quebec in Canada several years ago. A situation of a similar kind developed in relation to the loans of the Province of Quebec. They were drawn attention to publicly before there was a solution provided as to how the Province of Quebec would work its way out of its financial problems. The result of that was a decimation of the Canadian market; the result of that was a downgrading of Quebec in terms of international ratings and a downgrading of Canada in terms of international ratings because of that information which was given out without any solution as to how the problem might be solved.

That is the situation which the Treasurer of this country was confronted with last night and in August. Last night, when he met with the Premier of Victoria and the Treasurer of Victoria, there was a discussion about a strategy for getting Victoria out of its problems and the collaboration of the Commonwealth Government was sought in that process. That was agreed, and it was as a result of that that further borrowings were agreed to. But as at the beginning of August, there was no solution publicly available as to the way in which the State of Victoria might work its way out of its problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you had put a bit of pressure on it, no wonder.

—If Senator Kemp knew anything about it, he would know that that pressure was put on and on a number of occasions. Presumably he has come in here to talk in the debate—I do not know what he is going to talk about; I never do know—but he clearly has not studied the documents. No viable solution to the problems of Victoria provided prior to the August Budget would have permitted a sensible announcing of the Loan Council problem which the Victorian Government seemed to be getting into.
—Absolute rubbish.

—No doubt Senator Kemp will be on this committee. I hope he is. It might enable him to talk there rather than here all the time. He can reach a conclusion at the end of an examination of these terms of reference as to whether it is rubbish. I think he will find that a lot of commentators more informed than he is, who think before they talk, will tell him that it is not rubbish at all. That is a matter which can be subject to inquiry.

PARA.TAB: A number of points in the course of this matter have been raised which, I think, will be seen in their proper significance as time goes by without all the windy rhetoric of Senator Short. The Government is not, in any sense, supportive of an inquiry. We do not think it is necessary, but we do not blanche at the prospect of an inquiry because when the sensible, financially literate and so on get to the committee I am sure they will present a proper understanding of what occurred.
I will conclude by saying that, in spite of that rhetoric, the public interest in this country requires that a solution be found to problems before they become—

TALK.START.PARA: —You have got one; a change of government.

—No, because I quoted from the Premier. He does not think there is a solution, yet, because he does not know the figures, yet. But the public interest requires that a solution be found to problems before they are aired in public, and that means State governments achieving a responsible level of spending and taxing to overcome problems. That is consistent with what happened in relation to the State Bank of Victoria and the State Bank of South Australia. The Treasurer could have rushed out and said, `Look, the State Bank of South Australia is in trouble'.
—Like Keating did with Nobby Clark.

—No, he did not do it with Nobby Clark. The Treasurer of the day could have rushed out and said, `The State Bank of Victoria has problems'. In each case, if the Treasurer of the day had done that, there would have been a significant financial crisis in this country. In each case, a solution was worked out before those matters were made public, and that was a proper course for the Federal Treasurer and Treasury to adopt. In these matters the Commonwealth has a responsibility to act sensibly in the national interest and not rush in and create situations which are detrimental to the national interest in terms of financial management. That is in a sense, by implication, what some of the remarks made by Senator Short would invite us to do.

PARA.TAB: So we do not support this inquiry. As I say, we are not concerned about it, but we do not think it is necessary. If it does perchance, with Senator Coulter's goodwill, throw up any more sensible solutions, they will be very welcome. But the fact of the matter is that the Loan Council has operated in the way which was described in the letter from the Secretary to the Treasury, which has been made public, and historically that has been supported by State governments and the Commonwealth Government. It is only in the last few years that this Commonwealth Government has started to lean on the States for better accountability, better reporting, better responses in terms of government business enterprises and so on. These things have brought much better results in overall financial management and will continue to do so. We do not support the reference but, as I say, we are not worried about it. I will now conclude and leave the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I begin, I take this opportunity to claim I have been misrepresented. I hope Senator Button will stay long enough to at least hear this. At the beginning of his speech, when he was clearly struggling with logic, language and persuasiveness, he implied that I was involved in some way in bottom of the harbour schemes. The truth is—little as it matters to Senator Button—that I had no company that got anywhere near the bottom of any harbour, as distinct from the present Treasurer, John Dawkins, whose company, Coomel, was at the bottom of the harbour; right down there in the slime and the sludge. Nor did I have shares in Bell and BHP or, as Mr Dawkins did, sit in on a senior Cabinet committee to discuss the purchase of BHP by Bell when it was likely to influence the operations of the steel industry of Australia. Having put that right, I will sit by and wait for Senator Button to apologise, but no doubt I will grow old and tired waiting for that.
—Absolutely.

—Absolutely. Senator Button epitomised WA Inc. and the Rothwells saga all over again. One wonders whether the Labor Party will ever learn, even in opposition. But the great excuse that Brian Burke gave to the world for his clandestine meetings on the weekend, seeking to seduce the Liberal Party, the banks and senior members of the business community of Western Australia to be part of his conspiracy, was that any public utterance about the vulnerability and the financial status of Rothwells might cause a run on that institution.

PARA.TAB: I do not need to traverse the history of that particular saga. We all know what that has done for the credibility and the credit rating of Western Australia, which has been recently downrated. Nor do we need to be reminded of what it has done to the political institution; nor do we need to be reminded of what it has done to the integrity of the Public Service; and nor do we need to be reminded of what it has done to the confidence of the people of Western Australia in collective, responsible and democratic governments.

We now have Senator Button explaining another conspiracy of silence in what is described loosely as the national interest. This, of course, has nothing to do with national interest. The fact that the disclosure has now been made and the sky has not fallen in—the world has not ended—demonstrates that we can tell the truth, we can be forthrightly honest and, ultimately, it is worth paying whatever price is necessary in terms of the market. If we want to guarantee security in the market, if we want to guarantee that the financial circles of the community will stay stable and safe, it is necessary to ensure that they always know the truth.

Whenever they are in doubt, whenever they question, we will see fragility in the market. That is why in the last day or two we have seen the dollar fluctuating down to 68.5c and back up to 69c last night—because of anxiety and uncertainty. But that is a symptom of this Labor Government. It is simply a matter of looking after its scabby, politically failed mates. I would have thought that at least when the Federal Treasurer was sworn in he would have undertaken to act in an impartial, altruistic, national interest way, particularly with respect to Loan Council arrangements which rest on good faith, cooperation and honesty.

How can any of the State Premiers or Treasurers now be expected to act in a collective and responsible way when they are dealing with Loan Council matters? How can we expect them now to sit around and accept global figures—less than they might wish, but what they believe to be in the national interest—only to find that there is some secret, grotty, under the table deal being done by the Federal Treasurer and a desperate Labor Premier hearing the death rattle in the last days of office?

There is nothing altruistic or nothing in the national good about that. It was simply a grotty deal for political survival. It is not a rhetorical question to ask what would be the circumstances if it were Greiner, Fahey or the Premier of Tasmania, the Honourable Ray Groom? Can senators imagine the Treasurer writing private, confidential notes saying, `Hey, old chap, do you think we can sort this out in due course? Let us know if I can help'. It would have been made public overnight.

The Queensland experience demonstrates that perhaps more than anything else. The former Queensland Premier, Mike Ahern, said that he was unhappy with the limitation on the global borrowings and he proposed to breach it. That was immediately followed by a press statement from then Treasurer Keating saying that if that were the case, the general grants legislation in respect of Queensland would be reduced by the amount to which he exceeded the agreed upon global limit. As if his threat was not enough, he then introduced legislation specifically aimed at Queensland which said precisely that; to the extent that the Queensland Government exceeded its global limit, its general grants would be reduced.

This time Mr Dawkins could have introduced legislation, because he knew about it in June. The legislation came into effect in October and he could have introduced legislation which said that, in respect of any State which exceeded its global limits, its general grants would be reduced by that amount. Of course, he did not.

The effect of the conspiracy to cover up by Mr Dawkins and the Victorian Government was that it allowed the State Government of Victoria to go into an election telling lies about the financial status and welfare of that State. Therefore, it campaigned on a false premise and misrepresented the truth of the financial status of that State.

That conspiracy washed through the Treasury of Victoria which refused to provide documentation to the Auditor-General of Victoria. That would never have happened if Mr Dawkins had made public his knowledge of the events.

We are talking generally in a political sense and a financial sense, but there are those in Victoria who have bought paper at an inflated price because they thought it was worth more than it really is. They did not know that there was another $1.267 billion washing around in the markets. Now their investment has been diluted as a result of a misrepresentation by the Federal Treasurer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Deliberate.
—A deliberate misrepresentation of the value of that paper when it was sold into the private sector. Recently we saw the effect on the dollar, because it was tipping up and down in anxiety also.

PARA.TAB: As was said earlier, if it were a public company and Treasurer Dawkins was the chief executive officer of that company, we can be certain that the ASC would be having a good look. The ASC would be investigating with the purpose of examining the conduct with a view to prosecuting for very serious breaches of the law.

TALK.START.PARA: —The DPP would be close behind.

—The DPP would be close behind and, if we equate the conduct of Mr Dawkins with that of a director of a public company, we know that that director would be in gaol. Mr Dawkins knows that he is protected by the shield of the Crown and his conduct goes unpunished other than by the Parliament and the voters at election time. No doubt at that time he will pay the absolute and full price.

PARA.TAB: As I conclude, I am reminded of a famous quote by an infamous ex-Deputy Premier of Western Australia, David Parker, who said when he was referring to Labor governments that of course they always govern by a conspiracy of silence. It is their modus operandi and their way of doing business. That is how they treat the public, the voters and the taxpayers' money.

The truth of the matter is that, while Senator Button bleats here about an overseas experience and the confidentiality of the Loan Council, what he is really saying is that, if one member of the Loan Council cheats and rats on the rest of them, the code of silence is such that the other members of the Loan Council are not to be told about it. It is a breach of convention to tell the other members of the Loan Council, who have agreed to certain global borrowings and confined themselves to those global borrowings, that somebody in the team is kicking goals for the other side.

There is nothing altruistic about this. There is nothing in the national interest about this. It is all about a grotty, shoddy deal and a desperate attempt to save the Victorian Government. Had it been a Liberal or coalition government, of course, the circumstances would have been totally different. I thoroughly support this inquiry so that we ultimately find out the truth of the matter for the benefit of the voters and the public of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise also to support the establishment of a select committee on the functions, powers and operations of the Australian Loan Council. The terms of reference of the committee will enable a full expose of this rather sordid affair to be dealt with effectively. I welcome the support that the Australian Democrats are giving to this need for a major inquiry into this whole affair.

PARA.TAB: Whilst listening to the debate today and to the remarks made by Senator Button and others—and I guess that Senator Button has the reputation of being one of the better debaters on the Labor side—it was astonishing to hear the very thin, pitiful effort that Senator Button put up to argue against the establishment of such a select committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —He sought refuge from the Chair because he could not cope with the interjections.

—I thank Senator Crichton-Browne for his most helpful comments. It was interesting to hear just how thin the case is against the establishment of this select committee. I believe it is vital that the public understands precisely what has happened in this case, the decisions which were made and the advices put forward by the Treasury.

PARA.TAB: I believe that, after consideration, this committee will endorse the view that I have long held—and which happily in increasing numbers the Australian public have held—that Labor cannot be trusted with the money.
The record of the eighties is littered with Labor governments which have misused their authority to advance themselves and the interests of their mates at the expense of the Australian community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Paid with the public purse.

—As my colleague Senator Brownhill says, they cannot be trusted with the public purse. Victoria is only the latest in a succession of major financial scandals which have marked this period. My colleague Senator Campbell will undoubtedly draw attention to some of the issues which have emerged in Western Australia and the issues which are now emerging in the Federal arena.

PARA.TAB: A Federal Labor Government has been in office for almost 10 years and it has allowed massive foreign debts to be run up. It has no capacity or willingness to take any real action as all previous governments have done when faced with a major balance of payments crisis. All previous governments have taken action to bring the balance of payments back into balance and deal with the structural problems in the Australian economy. This Government will not do it. It will not take the tough decisions in the hope that it will continue to be elected.

The theory of the Cain and Kirner governments was to not take the tough decisions or deal with the emerging crisis. The hope was that Labor could steal a win in this recent election and the following one. We saw what a futile strategy that was in the end with the crushing defeat of the worst government in Victorian history—a government which Senator Cook stood up day after day in this chamber to defend and one which Mr Keating, in the 1988 election, strongly endorsed and urged Victorians to vote for.

It has taken us quite a while in Victoria to learn the truism that one cannot trust Labor with the money. If it gets its hands on that money, the normal standards of propriety and proper conduct of public affairs simply do not apply. Since Senator Cook is in the chamber, I will mention the fact of the vast monetary grants to his trade union mates over which he presided. Senator Short has estimated that the figure is over $40m. I have calculated that the ACTU has picked up between $10m and $12m from the grants that Senator Cook and his colleagues have made. It is this pattern of behaviour which Senator Cook has endorsed constantly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want to tell the truth rather than lying about this? Do you want to stop lying about this and tell the truth for once in your life?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—Order! Senator Cook, it is unparliamentary to call any senator a liar. I ask you to withdraw.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I withdraw. But there is no truth being told here, and that should be shown on the parliamentary record. There is absolutely no truth being told.
—Order! Please resume your seat. The call is to Senator Kemp.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I do not think Senator Cook withdrew unconditionally. He put a condition on that withdrawal. I think he should be required to withdraw unconditionally.
—There was no condition put on the withdrawal. It was withdrawn unconditionally. Senator Kemp, I ask you to resume your speech.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I must say that I was somewhat intrigued to hear Senator Cook, the man who gets up day after day in Question Time and misrepresents the policies of the Opposition. Constantly when challenged on that misrepresentation, he fails to correct the record. There are a number of things on the record.

—I raise a point of order. I have never misrepresented the policies of the Opposition. To accuse me of misrepresenting something is a slur. It is not justified in any objective circumstances, and I ask that it be withdrawn.

—Order! There is no point of order. In terms of any misrepresentation, it is at the end of a senator's speech that it is possible for other senators to seek leave to correct any misrepresentation. I ask Senator Kemp, without distraction from interjections, to continue his speech.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. In response to Senator Cook's comments, I ask whether he has apologised to Senator Panizza for the disgraceful attack he made on him. Senator Cook should not bother to stand up; perhaps at the

SPEECH.PARA: end of this speech he can join the debate. I just raise the issue that we are all—

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want to stop lying about this? You are just a liar now. You are just telling lies now. You are a liar.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order.
—Order! There is no need for a point of order. Senator Cook, as I have said, it is unparliamentary to call any other senator a liar. It is against the Standing Orders, and I ask you to withdraw.
—I withdraw, Mr Acting Deputy President. May I also ask—
—Thank you. I ask you to resume your seat.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The speaker is addressing me directly, which is against the Standing Orders. He should address you. He is also being provocative and telling untruths. I ask you to direct him to conduct himself in a proper manner.

—There is no point of order. Senator Kemp was referring to you as `he'. It is unparliamentary to speak in this chamber other than in directing remarks through the chair. I remind all senators of that point. I ask Senator Kemp to resume his speech.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. That is the third time that Senator Cook has jumped up in as many minutes. He has had his go. If he wants to join the debate and attempt to defend the disgraceful record of the Government, of which he is a senior member, there is plenty of time for him to do that. Unless he has any major contribution to make, he should keep quiet.

PARA.TAB: One issue which has arisen in this debate—and it is very important—is who else in this Government was involved in this cover-up in Victoria. We know that Mr Dawkins and Mr Keating were involved and that Senator Button, as a result of a response to a question in Question Time, was involved. The issue is how much the Cabinet knew. That question, which was posed today, remains hanging. Senator Button was not prepared to enlighten us.

It is interesting to reflect on an editorial in the Herald-Sun that was published on Monday this week; I am sure that Senator Cook will be particularly interested in it. Among other things, the editorial says:

SPEECH.PARA: Every member of the Labor Party who was privy to their deliberations—
`their' being the activities of the Victorian Government—
and in any way involved in the disastrous financial dealings and sordid cover-up should go with them.

PARA.TAB: For the Victorian ALP will be totally lacking in credibility while remnants of the decision-making team of the Cain-Kirner government remain in positions of power in this state.

SPEECH.PARA: I put to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that there was a major cover-up in order to attempt to protect the discredited Kirner Government. No objective observer who has surveyed the record has endorsed the limp-wristed actions of the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, apparently with the approval and support of Mr Keating and Senator Button, and probably with Mr Willis as well. These men were involved in a disgraceful cover-up—an affair which has been likened appropriately, in my view, to the disgraceful loans affair of 1975. One issue that Senator Button tried to raise in his remarks was that of confidentiality—that it was important that this matter be kept under cover until a solution was established and could be released.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to read what, for example, the Executive Director of the Macquarie Bank, Mr Garry Burrell, said on the confidentiality issue. It ties in with the remarks of Senator Crichton-Browne. Mr Burrell said this:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the market has a right to know how many bonds have been issued and will be issued so that they can price those issues accordingly. You can't really have a closed shop when you're dealing with an open market.
Mr David Chessell, who was formerly head of the Treasury's Commonwealth-State relations branch and who is a man with a high degree of expertise in these areas, said:
And by not informing the other members of Loan Council about this breach of Loan Council global limits, the Treasurer has committed one of the greatest improprieties of the global limit arrangements.
I repeat those remarks of Dr David Chessell:
. . . the Treasurer has committed one of the greatest improprieties of the global limit arrangements.
That is why I believe it is important to have this select committee established.

PARA.TAB: It is important to fully investigate this disgraceful affair. As Senator Coulter pointed out, it is important that we look carefully at the arrangements which have governed the Loan Council to date to see whether new and improved arrangements can be put in place to avoid the catastrophe which has befallen my home State as a result of the disgraceful mismanagement of the Cain and Kirner Labor governments.

The need to retain confidentiality is an argument which will ring loudly to those who were involved in the investigations of the disgraceful 1975 Khemlani loans affair, which again directly involved another Labor Government. It is interesting that, on 13 February 1975, the notorious Rex Connor used exactly the same type of arguments that Senator Button put to this chamber today. Rex Connor said:

SPEECH.PARA: I noticed a report concerning this matter in one metropolitan journal. Matters relating to the currency, loans and the commercial credit of the nation should be handled with the utmost discretion. I am acting accordingly.

In other words, the need to retain confidentiality to protect the currency was the argument which was used time and time again by Rex Connor until there was a full expose of the disgraceful borrowing activities of senior members of that Labor Government. Former Prime Minister Whitlam, running a similar line about the need for confidentiality, said:

I will give the same answer to him as he would have given to any question directed to him while he was Treasurer or Prime Minister on matters concerning the credit of our country. Open government has never applied in respect of loans or valuations of the currency.

Again, the confidentiality argument that was run time and time again with the first loans crisis of the Labor Government is again being run, this time with the latest saga of the disgraceful loans affair of 1992.

PARA.TAB: I believe it is important that we establish this select committee and that we get the chance to look at all the issues involved. One issue which will be of particular importance is to fully look at all the advice that the Federal Treasury gave to the Treasurer. It is fairly clear, as a result of material which has been selectively put on the public record by Mr Dawkins, that there are a large number of other papers and advices which the Treasury submitted to Mr Dawkins. It will be interesting and important to find out just what those advices were and whether the representation and the `spin', as they say in modern jargon, that Mr Dawkins is trying to give to the Treasury material which has so far been put on the record are correct.

As I said, I think this is an important select committee. It is important for the national interest of this country. I find it quite astonishing that Senator Powell, who is standing as an independent for Victoria in the forthcoming Senate election, has actually opposed the establishment of this select committee. She opposes such an inquiry so that we can properly inquire into yet another financial scandal involving a Labor government. I suspect that voters in Victoria will be interested to learn why Senator Powell does not feel it is important to get to the truth of this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ask nurses in Victoria what they think about Mr Kennett. You ask about the silver service in Parliament House. They have a view; you go and ask them.
—There is no doubt that Labor Party senators are very sensitive about this issue. I would be too. Nothing can come out of this inquiry which will add to the lustre of Senator Crowley's Party.

PARA.TAB: I put on record my strong support for the establishment of this select committee. I believe that it is in the public interest and I believe it will produce findings which, among other things, will help us avoid the catastrophe and cover-ups that we have seen in my home State of Victoria.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to support the establishment of the select committee on the functions, powers and operations of the Australian Loan Council. I am also very heartened to see that the Australian Democrats have supported the establishment of this committee in so much as they also moved the motion today.

PARA.TAB: I am also particularly interested in term of reference (1)(d) which specifically seeks to look into:

SPEECH.PARA: The responsibility and powers of the Federal Treasurer, as Chairman of the Loan Council, in dealing with breaches or possible breaches of the global borrowing limits, particularly as they affect the national economy.

It was interesting in the past fortnight to hear the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, talking about the tabling of the Royal Commission report into the Western Australian Government's business dealings over the past decade. He said that the WA Inc. type dealings could never happen at the Federal level because we have a far better system of scrutiny. He said that the Parliament is better at scrutinising the Government's dealings. He also commended the Press Gallery for its role in scrutinising the actions of the Federal Government.

PARA.TAB: I was impressed by Mr Dawkins's comments because that morning I had written a letter to the West Australian newspaper saying that it was a bit of a joke for that newspaper in particular to say that the Liberal Party in Western Australia had also taken a bit of flak from the Royal Commission because a former Liberal Premier, now resigned from the Liberal Party, had been mentioned in dispatches when the other 2,000 pages of the Royal Commission had all been dedicated to the Labor Party. I said it was a disgrace and appalling for the West Australian to try to pretend that the flak from that Royal Commission crossed political boundaries when the whole Royal Commission report was about the disgraceful financial dealings, cover-ups and conspiracies of the Labor Party in government in Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's not true. You can't say naughty things like that.

—I said to the West Australian that perhaps if that newspaper had been better at objectively reporting and scrutinising the activities of the Western Australian Government, those scandals may not have continued as they have done. I think it is fair to say that the national newspapers in Australia have reacted quite properly to the exposure. Only a day or two after Mr Dawkins had been saying this could never happen federally, newspapers reacted quite properly to the uncovering of the Dawkins loans cover-up conspiracy.
—You are in danger of believing yourself, Senator.

—It is very hard to contribute to this debate when we have this continual cackle from Senator Crowley, who is obviously very disturbed about her factional colleague Mr Dawkins having some of his loan cover-up deals paraded before a Senate select committee. Even though I consider it must be very hard for Senator Crowley to swallow what has happened to her factional colleague Mr Dawkins, I feel she should perhaps listen to some of the debate in the Senate. If she wants to make a constructive contribution to the debate, she should seek the call from you later, Mr Acting Deputy President.

PARA.TAB: That draws me to the role of the Senate in scrutinising these things and to the reasons why I commend the Democrats and this motion to the Senate. The Senate does have an important role to scrutinise these sorts of activities, particularly when demonstrably the course of this political institution, the institution of the Loan Council, has been so undermined by the activities of its Chairman, the Treasurer, and undermined by one of its members, the former Labor Treasurer and Premier of Victoria.

It reminds us of the fact that what happened in Western Australia in the past 10 years should not be allowed to happen again, not only federally but also in any other State in Australia. It is important that parliaments resume their role in scrutinising the role of executive government and enhancing that role wherever possible. It is very important that individual members and senators take their role very seriously in scrutinising the role of the Executive, be they backbench members of the Government or the Opposition.
