Oppositions generally have a very active role in scrutinising what executive government does because there is a political motivation to do it. But it should be no less important for backbench members of a government to take their role as scrutinisers of the Executive very seriously.

The other important matter I want to raise is the matter of financial market confidence, which has been referred to by so many speakers in this debate. Senator Button, in defence of the Government, said that we had to keep this matter under cover because the confidence of financial markets would be undermined if we were to uncover it.

More than anything else during this last dismal Labor decade, financial markets in Australia have been upset by the continual undermining of Australia's political institutions in Western Australia, South Australia, Victoria—and now federally with the Loan Council chaired by Mr Dawkins. The solution for confidence in the financial markets is to go back to the situation when we had Premiers like Sir Charles Court and Prime Ministers who had the confidence of the people—

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about Mr Gray.

—Like Malcolm Fraser and his Ministers, where financial markets were able to get on with their business, Senator Crowley, without having to worry all the time about what was going on at the government level. Financial people want to get on with their business, they want to oil the wheels of business, they want to raise funds and to make sure that those funds go into productive enterprise. They do not want to have to pick up the newspapers every day and find out what disasters their Premiers, Treasurers and political players are wreaking on the confidence in their nation's economy. It does not help financial markets to have the Labor Party in government which just cannot be trusted to manage money.

PARA.TAB: Senator Button made a point about the fact that the Loan Council procedures had started to unravel in the last few years. I make what is probably a most partisan political point, and that is that the Loan Council did not have these sorts of problems before we had the Labor Party in government in most of the States and in government here in Canberra. I am referring to the conspiracies, the cover-ups, the stretching of the rules, the breaking of the rules, all of these new financing mechanisms, leasing back trains and doing partial privatisations so that the global borrowing limits guidelines and global borrowing limits agreements had to stretch from only a few pages out to these huge documents, describing all of the interesting financing mechanisms which State governments could use to try to get around the global borrowing limits. This is where this country started getting into trouble.

We started coming into this era of trouble when one had Labor governments doing what they always do best and that is just taxing and spending. When they run out of the will of the people to raise taxes, they start spending and then coming up with new and interesting ways of financing that spending. We have seen that in Western Australia. Senator Cook knows we have seen that in Western Australia where Premier Lawrence came out and said she was going to fund the massive debts for the State of Western Australia, which the poor old taxpayers of Western Australia have to find, by making payments each year to pay back those debts.

In the first year that she was meant to make a payment for those debts, she brought down in her budget complicated financing methods to show how she was trying to pay this debt back. Within a few hours of analysis of her budget by independent analysts it was found that she had turned equity into debt, debt into equity, changed various borrowings from short to medium term, medium to long term, long term to short term, and used a few complicated financing arrangements basically to cover up the appalling debt of the Western Australian Government.

Of course, the people of Western Australia are not being fooled any more, as the polls will show with the Labor Party over there rating about 34 per cent, the Liberal Party and National Party both polling about 50 per cent, and Premier Lawrence coming over to Canberra last week and saying the Labor Party federally is even worse than that. So the people are not being fooled.

When the only brake on these political institutions is an election every three years and when one cannot rely on these Labor governments to tell the truth about their financial state, then those elections are not the only way that one can scrutinise government finances. This is what this committee will be looking into. It will be examining the adequacy of the Loan Council functions, the global borrowing limit mechanisms and trying to see the role of the Commonwealth as the chairman of the Loan Council and particularly the role of the current chairman, Mr Dawkins, and his complicity in a cover-up and a conspiracy with his Labor mates in Victoria before their election.

The night the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was led down the hall by Senator Crowley after winning a narrow majority in the caucus to become the Prime Minister of this country, with the television cameras whirring, he was wearing his Italian suit and Senator Crowley was wearing something more colourful. They accompanied each other down the hallway in that historic footage, which I will never forget because Senator Crowley was there. I thought,`With advice like Senator Crowley's, he can't go too far wrong'.

Let me remind the Senate of one of the promises the Prime Minister made, and perhaps Senator Crowley whispered it to him as he walked down that hall outside the caucus room. Indeed, I think he made three promises to the Australian people, but I forget the other two and probably the Prime Minister has forgotten them as well. One promise was that he was going to tell the Australian people the truth. He was not going to tell fibs any more; he had given up all that; it had gone out when he ceased to be Treasurer, so he was going to tell the truth. Probably for the first time in his 20 years or more in Parliament, the Prime Minister was going to tell the truth.

Of course, the Prime Minister, who has admitted that he knew about this loans affair and admitted that he shared that knowledge with the Treasurer, was also complicit in covering this up and, indeed, in not telling the truth. So it is no surprise to me that he has broken one of his promises; I have forgotten the other two. Maybe Senator Crowley can tell me what they are.

Senator Kemp made the important point as to what the people of Australia must remember when they go to the ballot boxes, whenever that election may be in the next few months. One cannot trust Labor with money. One cannot trust Labor to manage the economy. One cannot trust Labor with a household budget. One cannot trust Labor with the finances of Australia or of any State. It has been proved in Western Australia, Victoria, South Australia and, with one million people unemployed, massive foreign debt and now this 1975 Khemlani style loans cover-up saga with the Treasurer and the Prime Minister intimately involved, clearly one cannot trust this Labor Government in Canberra.

It is clearly time for a change in the way that the global borrowing limits are administered in Australia because one cannot trust the way this Federal Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, runs the Loan Council. It is also clearly time for a change of government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was indeed a sad sight earlier in this chamber to see the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, attempting to defend the indefensible. One might well ask: what is the indefensible? The bottom line is that Mr Dawkins, the Treasurer of this nation, misled the Australian Parliament and the Australian people.

PARA.TAB: On 18 August 1992, Mr Dawkins brought down his Budget Speech. As is the practice when he has made that speech and moved the second reading of Appropriation Bill (No. 1), he then publishes along with that a series of documents known as the 1992-93 Budget Papers, Budget Speech, Paper No. 1, Paper No. 2, Paper No. 3, Paper No. 4 and other related papers.
Budget Paper No. 4 contains Commonwealth financial relations with other levels of government for the year 1992-93, and it is interesting to read the preface page. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Circulated by the Honourable John Dawkins, M.P., Treasurer of the Commonwealth of Australia, for the information of honourable members on the occasion of the Budget 1992-93.

This is the document where there is more than ample space for the Treasurer to have told the truth. In fact, he deliberately set out to mislead the markets. He said that it was in order to lie to protect. The bottom line is that if one feeds misinformation into the market, one corrupts the market.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's not parliamentary to say "lie".
—Mr Acting Deputy President, could you inquire of Senator Crowley whether she is choosing to speak in the debate or merely to interject?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Burns)—That is a matter for Senator Crowley. Occasionally there are interjections from either side of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have noticed, Mr Acting Deputy President, that the only speaker to defend this reprehensible act of Mr Dawkins is Senator Button. Does Mr Dawkins have no friends—no-one who will stand up and say, `He behaved in an honourable fashion, as an honourable man'? Or is he, like Brutus, without friends? When Senator Short spoke and used the word `conspiracy' there was much debate from Senator Button. A good working definition of `to conspire' is, I think, quite useful in this debate. The Oxford English Dictionary defines it as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: To combine in action or aim; . . . To . . . concur, co-operate as by intention . . .
And that has been the meaning of the word since 1538. A secondary meaning of the word is:
To plot . . . devise, contrive . . .

I think that what has happened in this affair really fits all those working definitions of the term `to conspire'. We saw a conspiracy which saw, prior to the election in Victoria, a cover-up of the fact that the Victorian Government had exceeded its borrowing limits by nearly $1.3 billion. This document—Budget Paper No. 4—refers to the gentleman's agreement entered into with regard to the global borrowing approach. It outlines in a nice narrative the way the system works. It has tables that show the reader what those limits are. It shows them as a percentage of State gross domestic product. It gives the reader all sorts of information that would be needed to make a decision about the sorts of instruments and borrowings that were being made in Victoria. And there was a deliberate, knowing omission of the fact that short term borrowings—the sort we learned about in the Khemlani affair—had been converted to medium term borrowings and therefore became outside the so-called gentlemen's agreement.

PARA.TAB: This conspiracy, or knowingly intending to deceive the Australian Parliament and the people, became obvious when Mr Dawkins admitted it from his own mouth in the press conference that he gave on 28 October. I will quote his words. He was asked by a journalist:

SPEECH.PARA: Treasurer, did you hide from the Victorian public the fact that their Government was borrowing more than was considered prudent, or wise, or both, and were you forced to release the correspondence in a vain attempt to prove otherwise?
After a bit of bluster the Treasurer said:
. . . the first time we became aware of the fact that the Victorian Government had exceeded its global borrowing limits was about the middle of June.

In fact, on 17 June, Treasury was formally apprised. Incidentally, I noticed Senator Button's very interesting dissertation earlier in the day when he tried to say that there had not been any formal notification. I think that a good look at the meaning of the word `formal' will show honourable senators that, when the Director-General of the State Treasury calls on the Treasury of the Federal Government, that is pretty formal. On 17 June that is precisely what happened. Indeed, the Federal Treasury was informed that the guidelines had been broken and that the borrowings were outside the permitted limits. Mr Dawkins himself was formally briefed about this on 6 July. Yet on 18 August the Budget Papers—I repeat: `circulated by the Honourable John Dawkins, M.P., Treasurer of the Commonwealth of Australia for the information of honourable members on the occasion of the Budget'—deliberately and knowingly omitted to include that fact. There is plenty of room in the `Notes' section to make reference to it. There is plenty of room in the narrative section to make reference to it. It had to be, and was, a deliberate act not to include it.

PARA.TAB: What we are discussing here is an inquiry as to how we will remedy this situation. Indeed, it was at the initiative of the Opposition that this inquiry was sought. We are delighted to see the Democrats not only come on board but actually move the motion today and set out very good guidelines whereby we will indeed be able to get at some of the truth of these matters.

I hope people will remember that the Democrats have indeed come out and supported the Opposition in its call on this occasion. We are happy that we are in agreement on these terms of reference. The problem we have here is that the Treasurer properly should resign—or, at worst, just as Gough Whitlam had to sack Jim Cairns, the Prime Minister should sack John Dawkins. But will he? No. Why will he not? Because Mr Keating, too, was complicitous in knowing in advance that the Australian people were to be deceived. To hear the Prime Minister of my nation say on radio, `I had to lie to the Australian people to protect the markets'—and, by doing so, corrupt the markets—makes me ashamed. I am ashamed at what is happening to this nation. When people look at the Western Australian experience and try to blame the Westminster system, I say: don't blame the system; blame the people in it; blame the people who let the executive arm of government cosy up with the bureaucracy so that matters could be hidden from the public gaze.

Why should we be surprised that the Government—both Mr Dawkins and Mr Keating—has acted in this way? Let us take a look at the record and some of the material we have been dealing with recently in another forum. Let us look at the way in which, after the Fitzgerald inquiry began, it asked the Tax Office whether it could have, pursuant to legislation introduced in 1982 by Malcolm Fraser for the purposes of the Costigan and Stewart inquiries, access to tax records. Mr Nolan, a first class officer in the Australian Tax Office, wrote a very proper advice pointing out that there was power under the 1982 legislation to let the Queensland Royal Commission have that information. One of the reasons he thought it should have it was that it could be of benefit to the revenue. However, there was further advice from the Attorney-General which said that the preferred way to go was, in fact, to enact specific legislation to allow that information to be passed on to the Fitzgerald inquiry, stopping section 16 being invoked to protect individuals. But clearly it was his view that there was power under the 1982 legislation to do that. Within one month of that advice being given we had legislation pass through the Parliament, supported on a bipartisan basis in the interests of getting to the truth of matters, and the information was passed to the Fitzgerald inquiry.

Then, on 12 April 1991, we had a similar occurrence when the Western Australian Royal Commission asked the Tax Office whether it could have similar access to that given to the Fitzgerald inquiry so that it, too, could pursue its inquiries in a proper manner. What was the response? Mr Nolan was not asked for advice this time. Mr Boucher gave the response—and he gave what can at best be described as a political response. He said that there was no power to give it and that we should protect the privacy of individual taxpayers. Yet within only a week an amendment was made to section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act which was designed to give access to that material to authorised bodies, which strangely omitted the Western Australian Royal Commission.

A little after that we had a further amendment. But at every stage none of us knew about this at all until one year later when the Western Australian Royal Commission came out and said that it was denied access to this material. At that stage Paul Keating, the then Treasurer, came out and said that he had relied on Mr Boucher's advice. But the matter had been hidden and buried from the public view until the Royal Commission came out and said itself that it was denied access. Yet the reason for giving access remains the same in each case: very simply, there is a benefit to the Commonwealth revenue.

Where was that advice dealt with by Mr Boucher? Funny thing: it was not there. So why should we be surprised that we have seen an utter cover-up of the fact that this debt existed and it is denied in the public published official documents that accompany the Budget Papers and the Budget Bills? It is no good Mr Dawkins and Mr Keating saying, `It might have been published somewhere else or someone else might have alluded to it'—no good; irrelevant. This is material published by Mr Dawkins for the information of honourable members on the occasion of the Budget deliberately misleading the Parliament. Do not blame the Westminster system for failing; blame the people in it.

TALK.START.PARA: —What would have happened if he were in the private sector?

—He would have been sacked, and sacked very speedily, and he could well have trouble dealing with various other authorities which have been set up to deal with what is dishonest behaviour. One wonders what sort of example is being set to young people when we have this cosying up between the executive arm of government and the bureaucracy and we have the leading people in our government—the Prime Minister of the day and the Treasurer of the day—misleading the Parliament and the Australian people.

PARA.TAB: There are many out there quite simply who are shocked, disappointed and horrified by the behaviour, who find the behaviour reprehensible and who draw analogies with the Khemlani affair and between the stated desire to have an honest government and having the matter dealt with only by Senator Button, the only person willing to stand up and attempt to defend the indefensible. This is an important inquiry. It is a serious matter. On the admission of the Treasurer himself, it is a misleading of the Parliament and the people. We do have conventions in this land: if it was good enough for Senator Richardson to resign because of the Marshall Islands affair—after we dragged that information out of him, Senator Evans and others screaming—it is good enough for Mr Dawkins to resign as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak in support of the motion moved by Senator Coulter. This select committee is needed not to hang Treasurer Dawkins on technicalities—because I think it can be argued that he did stick to the technicalities, although we do require more of him than that—but to look beyond those technicalities to the bigger issues: the integrity of the Loan Council, getting better public sector debt management and the exposure of the entire debt crisis facing this nation which currently is $150 billion, only 30 per cent of which is public debt.

PARA.TAB: Senator Button cited Elders Finance as an example of the private debt, which he thought the coalition was unconcerned about, compared with the Victorian Government's debt. Whether it is Elders Finance or the State Government, both have exhibited the excesses of deregulation which have resulted in this debt of $150 billion. Let us not lose sight of the fact that, while 30 per cent is public debt, 70 per cent is private debt. I do not think we should moralise therefore about the comparative excesses of some State governments exclusively.

We have not only the excesses of deregulation but also the added bonus of self-regulation whereby State Treasurers simply fax off to the Federal Treasurer the amount of their short term and long term borrowings with no auditing. State governments report what they choose to report: `Dear John, this month we borrowed $1.6 billion, but only in the short term, and our auditor does not really know the extent of this. Trust us and just go ahead and put the aggregated amount in the Federal Budget, no questions asked'. That is how this country is run.

What seems to have happened in Victoria is that debt was moved around within some sort of coalition of public sector financing funds so that the technical requirement to disclose gross new money borrowings from the private sector was complied with. Just knowing that that has happened is sufficient for me to say that it is time we had a good long look at this gentlemen's agreement. As the terms of reference state, we should ask: what are the reasonable functions, powers and operation of the Australian Loan Council? What is the role of all governments? What is the right of members to know the information which is provided to the Council? Where is the public's right to know about the information? In the administration of global borrowing limits set by the Council, what sorts of things should be included? For example, should sale and lease-back arrangements be counted? As to the responsibility and power of the Federal Treasurer, as chairman of the Loan Council, when should the Treasurer act in respect of breaches or potential breaches of the global borrowing limits? Where is his responsibility in the effect of these things on the national economy?

A lot has been said about the role of the Treasurer. To be fair, he came to this position in January of this year. I think he can demonstrate that all the way through, technically, he behaved appropriately. In saying that, his defence is that he could not take action without the Victorian State Government making formal application for a special addition of funds. His argument is that he chose to act behind the scenes in the meantime by way of letter. His judgment was that he should not disclose the amount of the debt until he had in hand a strategy from the Victorian State Government for medium term debt recovery, such strategy to be announced hand in hand with the disclosure. He has argued that this was in the national interest.

We can place some credence on that argument, but the Democrats feel quite strongly—and this applies to the explanation that the Treasurer has given about his obligation to disclose in the Budget—that the Treasurer could have been expected to go beyond meeting the technical obligations and to have exercised the sort of authority one expects of the Federal Treasurer.

It is true to say that in the Budget the Treasurer met the obligation of disclosing to Parliament the extent of public sector borrowing. Markets were able to see up or down movement and the balance between the states. In tables 1 and 2 of statement 6 of Budget Paper No. 1, we were able to see the total structure of public borrowing. However, I do not think one should have to put several reports together to work out how to disaggregate them. The Treasurer had an obligation to put a footnote to these figures.

The select committee represents a significant step in the quest for greater accountability of public and private debt in this country. This is a reform which has been made absolutely necessary by the excesses of the deregulationist 1980s and the large scale privatisation, deregulation and corporatisation of the government business enterprises we are looking at in the terms of reference of this select committee.

I think events will show that this will turn out to be a very significant select committee in the life of this Senate. I am very pleased that the Democrats have been able to cooperate with the Opposition and decide upon these responsible terms of reference. I look forward to the deliberations of this Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I reject and totally repudiate the proposition being put by the Government. Having been caught with its fingers in the till, or whatever appropriate analogy exists, it is now trying, and has been trying, to blame the coalition, of all people, for the state of the markets in Australia that has emerged from this scandal. Somehow, according to the Treasurer, it is the coalition's fault that the Australian dollar has collapsed, that interest rates for government borrowings are under pressure. It is not its fault. It is not because it told lies. It is not because it corrupted the marketplace. It is all the Opposition's fault for drawing attention to it.

PARA.TAB: I have rarely heard such nonsense in my life. The hypocritical attack by Treasurer Dawkins on the coalition, alleging that we have somehow damaged the borrowing status and so raised interest rates for Australian governmental borrowings—and, by the way, he included the New South Wales Premier John Fahey in that ludicrous attack—is so nonsensical that really it must be countered in this place.

The fact is that the market has naturally taken the view that governments that tell lies are not to be trusted in the marketplace. It is a simple, uncomplicated proposition. Governments that conceal breaches of financial agreements on borrowing limits, that conspire together to do so, naturally lower their status with lenders. That is why the markets do not like this Government, and they do not like the Victorian Government.

Forcing an inquiry into this scandal—and I commend the Australian Democrats for doing so—is not damaging to the borrowing status of governments in Australia; it is the only way to restore confidence in our governmental borrowing markets that this Keating Government has conspired with its Victorian mates to destroy. This inquiry is the only way—I underline, the only way—to restore any kind of confidence in the way this Government will be forced to act in the future because the exposure of its conspiracy will ensure, hopefully, that this sort of thing cannot happen again. That is the sort of confidence that the markets need in governmental statements. They need to be able to trust governments, and they cannot trust this Government because it has demonstrated itself to be totally untrustworthy, to tell lies in its Budget, and to conspire with the Victorians to hide a massive over-borrowing.

It is a disgrace that the guilty men—or, should I say, the guilty men and a woman—in this scandal should now try to blame the coalition for trying to ensure that it must not happen again by exposing the facts and details of this governmental misbehaviour. I totally support and commend to the Senate the proposal to have an inquiry into this scandalous affair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose the motion to establish a Senate select committee to inquire into the functions, powers and operation of the Australian Loan Council, etc. In particular, I want to comment on the contributions I have heard from honourable senators opposite. There is in psychological medicine a term called `classical transferrence'. That is when you ascribe to the opposite what is actually for yourself. I cannot think of a better example of this. Opposition senators spend a lot of time saying what I, Senator Crowley, meant. It is very brave of the Opposition to try to say what is in my mind, let alone what is in the mind of anybody else. They would be much better trying to discover what is in their own minds and, in particular, to be honest about it.

PARA.TAB: The notion of classical transferrence illustrates the hollowness of the Opposition's contribution. Its members have little to say so they spend a lot of time blustering and trying to say what I or somebody might have thought—a measure of insufficiency, particularly regarding a contribution from Senator Kemp. He claims to be otherwise. His performance today did not give one any encouragement at all.

Opposition senators mentioned things called gentlemen's agreements and conspiracies. But they did not actually draw to the attention of this place what might be seen as a conspiracy: when Mr Malcolm Fraser went out to see a Governor-General and shortly afterwards. As a result of the breaking of a gentlemen's agreement, Supply was denied in this place and Mr Fraser's visit to the Governor-General was a consequence of that. I am glad that honourable senators opposite are agitated. They can see how, depending on which story they tell, so the weight and the balances shift.

Those of us who are minded not to see a conspiracy where there is not one still find, if we listen closely to Senator Bronwyn Bishop's definition of `conspiracy', that the behaviour of Mr Fraser and the Governor-General would very much allow that definition. I am not going to say whether or not it did, but I certainly know that it was a gentlemen's agreement in this place that said that Supply was not denied. And who broke that gentlemen's agreement? Honourable senators opposite broke the gentlemen's agreement, so they should not talk to us about gentlemen's agreements. Goodness me, what a loud gaggling lot they are, carrying on over there when some of the alternative examples are put on the public record.

We have had quite bizarre contributions where most of the contribution did not go to what the Senate committee could do once it is established, because that is not clear. The Democrats proposed this motion because they are concerned to try to find out what goes on in the Loan Council. They are establishing a Senate committee which has been specifically given powers that are there in the Standing Orders. I am advised that, if they are listed in the resolution, then those powers ascribe to this Senate committee the power, I suppose you could say, to subpoena documents. However, there is very little likelihood of any State or Territory government producing those documents for the Commonwealth. The consequences of this Senate committee could be the Commonwealth's QC, on at least $2,000 a day, versus the QCs from every State and Territory, no doubt at an extra $2,000 a day, at great length arguing about who had the power to subpoena what and whether or not any State government ought to produce these documents.

What we would see run in this Senate committee would be exactly the kinds of constraints that are already there on the Loan Council. I believe that we would have no further advancement on what is already there. You may indeed have a lot of fun groping around within the documents from the Federal Office but you would not achieve the sorts of things you want to go to. That is a reasonable point of objection in opposition to this motion—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not so good on health but you are hopeless on finance—
—Notwithstanding Senator Kemp's carping over there. Another thing that interests me very much is the monstrous hypocrisy—the monstrous hypocrisy—of the Opposition—
—Say it a third time.
—Monstrous hypocrisy. Thank you, Senator. It is hard to imagine anything worse. The motion reads, in paragraph 1, that to be inquired into and reported on are:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) The functions, powers and operation of the Australian Loan Council in co-ordinating all financial transactions by all Commonwealth and State bodies, including government business enterprises, instrumentalities and other authorities, that involve a call on the private sector.

Before we go on to any of the other points in this motion, one has to wonder about exactly what the Opposition says in the Fightback package. It says that it endorses a competitive federalism, where each State and Territory will be responsible for its own revenues, including borrowings.

PARA.TAB: Members of the Opposition come in here and, in complete contradiction to their own Fightback package, say, `Let's have it all out. Let's actually move to a central government. Let's have a look at a central tabling of all the documents. Let's have a look at all the borrowings, Commonwealth and State—not some, not even the government ones, but all borrowings including borrowings by government business enterprises, instrumentalities and other authorities'. Those opposite are a very interesting lot. Do they want the States to have independence? Do they want them to have what they call competitive federalism or do they want to move to the centralism that this motion endorses?

The Democrats are consistent in their approach. This motion is entirely consistent with the approach of the Democrats. Whether or not one agrees with it is a separate thing. But the Democrats are consistent, which is exactly what those opposite are not. This is opportunism writ large. Senator Kemp should be ashamed of himself. He does not believe in this one iota. The Fightback package spells out exactly the contrary position and yet those opposite—bleeding hearts the lot of them—have the gall to stand up in here and try to convince us that they seriously believe it. To those listening to this debate—and there are not many—I report at this stage that all the Opposition senators are smiling, which means they are in agreement with the point I am making. What a hollow lot; what a lot of sham men over there, trying to pretend that they actually believe all of this. They do not.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have exposed them.
—Hollow men—shams the lot. They are critically contradicting their own policies, as spelt out in Fightback where they have actually put down some words about it.

PARA.TAB: Through this select committee, they will attempt to rewrite the Constitution. This Senate committee has no power to do that. From my reading of the terms of reference, it is very unclear what the committee will do. What on earth would this Senate committee do? What recommendations could it make? What documents and information could it have access to? One could be absolutely sure that it would receive no information of any seriousness from the States and Territories; it would have no capacity seriously to resolve anything; it could make only hollow recommendations after going through a hollow exercise. As I say, the Democrat approach is consistent and the Opposition approach is totally hypocritical. I suppose that those approaches are not without precedents.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is terribly repetitious and boring.
—I say to Senator Baume that sometimes slow, dull people have to have things repeated, and I am just making it clear to him.

PARA.TAB: Why did not members of the Opposition want to tell us about the Gray Government in Tasmania? What happened when the Gray Government's books were examined by an incoming Labor Government? The Gray Liberal Government borrowings led to a totally unsustainable debt. It never actually told anyone about that, and I notice the Opposition senators here have not told anyone about that either. Selective quoting is like the sin of omission: it is almost as bad as that terrible thing—a lie. Senators opposite did not tell us about the Gray Government and the problems it got into with its borrowings and levels of debt. They did not tell us about how that Government contravened and went outside the general rules—that it broke the gentlemen's agreement.

At least Victoria allowed Nicholls to examine its books. In fact, some other examples could be cited which the Opposition has also forgotten and overlooked. The former Premier of New South Wales, Mr Greiner, exceeded the borrowings by $1 billion in respect of the harbour tunnel. What was proper about Mr Greiner and what was proper about the process was that, having gone completely outside the guidelines—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you talking about Laurie Brereton's contract?

—Rave on now dark and deep blue speakers, rave. Check the facts. When the New South Wales Government approached the Commonwealth and admitted the problem that it was confronting, a solution was worked out. That is acceptable under the current rules. Opposition senators did not give us this example of how it can be done and has been done. No, they did not look at that—they selectively quoted. They have taken the high moral ground. Senator Kemp, with his hand on his chest, is feeling his heart beat with passion and commitment. Goodness me—they are very, very hollow!

PARA.TAB: One could give other examples of States and Territories approaching the Federal Labor Government in respect of extensions or movements of borrowings outside the Loan Council guidelines. The Ulara resort in the Northern Territory is another good example. The Country-Liberal Party of the Territory and the Liberal Government of Mr Greiner were able in negotiation to reach a resolution in respect of those exceeded borrowings. That has been perfectly well accepted and managed by negotiation between the two. That is perfectly possible and it is the process that has applied up until now. The Opposition is misrepresenting the facts. It has selectively emphasised what it thinks will make a good story. The Opposition is confusing people by misrepresenting these facts and withholding information.

The last point I would like to make is that the Opposition is very good at always ascribing motive or intent to others. That practice, which is actually against the Standing Orders, is used so often that we do not always call points of order. One cannot know what is in another person's mind. One can judge whether a person's behaviour is acceptable, but one does not have the ability to go to that person's intent unless it is expressly written down or stated.

The Democrats have said that they found the explanation as to why information was left out of the Budget Papers sufficient but perhaps not enough. There is absolutely no conclusion by the Democrats that the Treasurer deliberately intended to misrepresent or lie. But Opposition senators want to make the point that withholding the information carries with it the deliberate intent to lie or mislead. The Opposition is so good at ascribing intent to others. It is important for the Opposition to look to its own house. Opposition senators have come in here to support a motion that is completely contradictory to their own policies in Fightback. I will be interested to see how they wriggle out of that one. (Quorum formed)

That, of course, is precisely the point. Here we have, as we now know, $1.3 billion of borrowings which should have been included within the Victorian declarations to the Loan Council. They were not included, and the Commonwealth could not discover the truth over some months. That is the very point; that is why we need the inquiry. Rather than being a defence, as Senator Button seemed to be saying, really it is the point at issue—the point as to why we need the inquiry. He also seemed to question whether I and others knew the difference between the Queensland situation of 1988 and the present situation in Victoria. Again, I know very well the difference. In the case of Queensland, Queensland declared openly to the Loan Council that it would go outside the Loan Council and its rules and borrow, and it was brought smartly into line. In the case of Victoria, Victoria obsequiously and secretly went outside the rules of the Loan Council and did not tell anybody.

The point here is that once the Treasurer had become reasonably confident that that was the situation—and I think from what we now know that, at least from June of this year, the Treasurer should have been reasonably confident that that was the situation—then he should have taken much stronger action with respect to Victoria. That is the point at issue there; although he could not have actually taken action in relation to that as he did in Queensland, at least he could have threatened similar sort of action. He could have threatened that if Victoria did not get its act together then, of course, it would have its allocations through the other part of Federal allocations withdrawn or curtailed in some way.

We do not share with the Opposition the feeling that this, in fact, amounts to a conspiracy but we would certainly go so far as to say that the Treasurer, in our view, had enough reason to become much tougher with Victoria over the last few months and simply failed to do so.

The other point that I want to pick up in conclusion is this question of openness and the confidence which the public has in the financial system, in the loans system and in the borrowing system and, through the confidence which the public has, the confidence which the Australian and international markets would, or should, have.

Again, Senator Button seems to have obfuscated the issue. He has claimed yet again that it is necessary that the extent of borrowings or financial misdemeanours by the States not be revealed to the public or the market until there is a solution which can be put down at the same time. To do so would cause the markets to lose confidence and would, therefore, make the markets jittery and have effects on the value of the Australian dollar, interest rates and various other financial indicators.

But we have this letter from the Federal Treasurer to Mr Fahey, the Premier of New South Wales, dated 30 October. In it, the Federal Treasurer is speaking of potential improvements in the Loan Council arrangements, and says:

SPEECH.PARA: For instance one proposal could be that the Loan Council Secretariat be asked to scrutinise in detail all financial transactions by all State and Commonwealth bodies that involve a call on the private sector, including short term and temporary facilities and so-called "creative" financing instruments. As you will appreciate such an approach will require far more frequent and detailed reporting.

Yesterday we were told by the Treasury officials that one of the reasons why States could not reveal to the Loan Council this sort of information was that they could not have confidence in the Premiers from the other States not using this in a political way, revealing it, therefore, to the public and destabilising the market. Yet we have here the Treasurer saying that that revelation should be considered a reasonable part of the function of the Loan Council.

PARA.TAB: If that is the case, the Treasurer here is clearly identifying that that process would lead to more confidence by the public and more confidence by the financial markets, and the Treasurer simply cannot have it both ways. Neither he nor Senator Button can claim that to reveal this information would have led to destabilisation, and yet, at the same time, call for a system in which there will be regular and detailed revelation of that information, presumably including those instances in which the States have gone outside the global limit requirements.
I conclude on this point. The Treasurer goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Regular publication will make for a better informed market in this area than we have ever previously seen. This will impose its own discipline on governments which might be considered to be borrowing too heavily. Consideration might also be given to the need for more explicit penalties for any breach of agreed borrowing items including offsetting reductions as grants.

It seems to me that here the Treasurer is clearly identifying what needs to be put in place. I repeat, our remaining concern is that it is not appropriate for the Loan Council itself to attempt this sort of investigation. We feel that it is very unlikely that the Loan Council would impose on itself the sorts of penalties and strictures which would be necessary to ensure this financial accountability. Appropriately, a Senate select committee should be set up with the terms of reference which we will give to it in a moment when we vote on this motion.

PARA.TAB: Those terms of reference will ensure that there will be, on the public record, a process which will be seen to be a much better and more accountable one. It will be a process which will lead through the sorts of pressures that will then be on the Loan Council to invoke just those sorts of stringencies, just this sort of accountability and just this sort of information. It will lead to a greater level of confidence by the public and the markets and, therefore, greater certainty in relation to the financial future of this country. That is one thing that we need and one thing that we have not got at present.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Coulter's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1.The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag.

2.We therefore request that the Senate ensures that the Australian national flag, as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a national poll.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Archer (from 14 citizens), Senator Knowles (from 11 citizens) and Senator Macdonald (from 15 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:
We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia should retain the current National Flag which has flown over the country since Federation. This flag
symbolises the world's oldest democracy
represents our history, our culture and our language
enjoys the support of the vast majority of the Australian people
symbolises the sacrifice of our armed servicemen and women
Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should retain the current national flag.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Bishop (from 190 citizens) and Senator O'Chee (from 78 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Australian National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
1.We the undersigned wish to signify our strong opposition to any change in the design or colour of the AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL FLAG.
2.We believe that the current flag has served Australia well and will continue to do so in the future and represents a true manifestation of the Nation's history.

PARA.TAB: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator MacGibbon (from 37 citizens) and Senator Reid (from 259 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Quarrying at Exit Cave
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned, noting that Senator Robert Bell has introduced a Bill into the Senate to ensure that no further blasting at Bender's Quarry is permitted without the consent of both Houses of Parliament, respectfully call upon the Federal Government to support the Bill.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Australian Labor Party should return to its traditional support for the Constitutional Monarchy as represented by Messrs Chifley, Evatt and Hayden and reject support for an Australian Republic being promoted by Mr Hawke and Mr Keating.
Your petitioners therefore request that:
The Senate call on the Australian Labor Party to return to its traditional support for the Constitutional Monarchy.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note particularly that:

PETITION.PARA: Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms

PARA.TAB: Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PETITION.PARA: ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms
produced a tolerant society

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should remain a democratic constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty, the Queen of Australia as our Head of State and represented in Australia by a Governor-General.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Oath/Affirmation of Allegiance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens and residents of Australia respectfully shows:
That the current Oath/Affirmation of Allegiance made by prospective citizens of Australia pledges allegiance to Her Majesty, Elizabeth II, Queen of Australia, Her Heirs and Successors.

PETITION.PARA: Your Petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:

PARA.TAB: Legislate to change the Australian Citizenship Oath/Affirmation of Allegiance to a pledge of Allegiance to Australia and the people of Australia, to reflect the true nature of Australian Government and society.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pay TV
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the residents of Tasmania respectfully sheweth:
That your petitioners, concerning parents and consumers respectfully request that the Broadcasting Services Bill which will control Television and Pay Television, will:
prohibit all considerably violent programs,
prohibit indecent and obscene programs, (to protect the young and impressionable),
prohibit blasphemous programs which denigrate religious faith or belief,
establish strict legally enforceable standards for programs and hours,

PETITION.PARA: ensure that "nothing is included that will offend against good taste and decency"

PARA.TAB: ensure that films are judged not as a whole, but each in its several parts,
that the Bill underpins and supports pro-social media in spirit and intent,
reject industry codes that will sell out Australia's defenceless children,
exempt all classification criteria and hours from s149d,
ensure genuine consumer consultation, so that parents can have access to program criteria information, and input into decision-making for their home environment.
Because children are defenceless and helpless, because they have no vote, no power, and no advocate other than you.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

This humble petition is from the Citizens of Australia whose signatures appear below. We are believers on the Lord Jesus Christ and regard the Holy Scriptures as the absolute, authoritative and divinely inspired Word of God. Your humble petitioners seek to draw the attention of the House to the fact that the Family Law Act of 1975 (with Amendments) is at serious variance with the Law of God as contained in the Holy Scriptures.

PARA.TAB: 1)There is no allowance in the Act for adultery as a basis for divorce. God said, "Thou shalt not commit adultery" Exodus 20:14. Also Christ said "Whosoever shall put away his wife, and marry another, committeth adultery against her. And if a woman shall put away her husband, and be married to another, she committeth adultery." Mark 10:11,12

2)This is Christian country yet the Act recognises unmarried or de facto couples as equal to married couples. This is fornication or adultery and is directly opposed to the commandment of Scripture, which says, "Nevertheless to avoid fornication let every man have his own wife and let every woman have her own husband". 1 Corinthians 7:2

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners humbly pray that the Family Law Act of 1975 (with Amendments) be amended by:

PARA.TAB: 1)Allowing the act of adultery to be reintroduced as a ground for divorce.
2)Legislating to preserve and maintain the dignity and distinctiveness of marriage.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia who are believers in the Lord Jesus Christ and seek to be governed by the truth as contained in the holy Bible and practice the teachings of Jesus Christ and His apostles, draws to your attention that the practice of abortion as generally carried out in Australia is:

PARA.TAB: 1.The termination of life that God has given and is a sin against God's word that "Thou shalt not kill". (Exodus 20 v 13 & Romans 13 v 9). Abortion is therefore murder.
2.Such a practice is a denial of God's sovereign right to give life and to take life (Job 1 v 21).
3.For the Government to fund such a practice is against the welfare of this nation and invites God's righteous judgment on those who disregard His law.
4.Government is the minister of God for good (Romans 13 v 4) and as such should do his will as included in the Parliamentary prayer.

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore, as in duty bound, pray and ask the Honourable House that urgent action be taken to terminate the Medicare funding of abortion.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the President has received the following letter, dated 3 November 1992, from Senator Parer:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 75, I propose to move:
That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need for the Government to abandon its failed big unions, big government, compulsory centralised wage fixing system which has contributed to record unemployment, and adopt Jobsback, the Coalition's worker-friendly, enterprise-based, high wage new jobs policy.
Senator for the State of Queensland

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I understand that informal arrangements have been made to allocate specific times to each of the speakers in today's debate. With the concurrence of the Senate, I shall ask the Clerks to set the clocks accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

PARA.TAB: The need for the Government to abandon its failed big unions, big government, compulsory centralised wage fixing system which has contributed to record unemployment, and adopt Jobsback, the Coalition's worker friendly, enterprise based, high wage new jobs policy.

I rise today to support this matter of urgency. It is a matter of extreme urgency in view of the crisis we face in Australia. There is a need for the Government to abandon its failed big unions, big government, compulsory centralised wage fixing system, which has contributed to record unemployment, and to adopt Jobsback, the coalition's worker-friendly, enterprise-based, high wage, new jobs policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —`Jobsack'—that's your policy.

—We can hear the chirpy interjections from the Minister for Industrial Relations, who has been renowned in recent weeks for his conflicting remarks about the Jobsback policy. Before I touch on that matter, it is important that we put the background of the Jobsback policy into perspective.

PARA.TAB: Over 12 months ago, because of the economic climate in Australia, with its record unemployment, its foreign debt that was growing out of all proportion—and which is continuing today—and its record youth unemployment and with no light at the end of the tunnel, it was imperative that someone did something in this country. The Government had run out of ideas and had no policies.

Based on the country's position at that time—which has currently got worse—Fightback was introduced into Australian living rooms. The whole basis of the Fightback program was to create real jobs in this country and not the phoney or bandaid type of work that is carried out by the Government to hide the real unemployment in Australia. Fightback was introduced to give a big adrenalin injection into the private sector, because only a thriving and growing private sector—which is the wealth creator in Australia—can get Australia out of the mess it is in today.

This mess has come about as a result of 10 years of Labor and a former Treasurer who is now the de facto Prime Minister of Australia with failed policies. There are four or five major aspects to the Fightback program, but one of them is to remove some $20 billion worth of taxes from the private sector which will enable it to become more competitive, not only in regard to increasing exports, but also to enable it to produce more of the goods and services in this country that Australians want to buy.

The other part of Fightback was the well-known GST. As everyone knows, despite the scaremongering of the Labor Party, the net inflationary effect of the GST as calculated by the Treasury itself was 3.6 per cent. It was not in the order of 15 per cent, which is the figure that the Government initially tried to lie its way around the country with. The Government found it was going nowhere and has dropped it to some degree.

An equally important, if not more important, part of the package was to restructure the industrial relations system in this country. I would say that, even though all aspects of Fightback are important, if we had to categorise or prioritise them, number one would have to be the reform of the industrial relations system. Without that, and with all the other benefits offered by Fightback, there is no doubt that we will not achieve the sorts of results that we on this side want for Australia.

We want this not only for ourselves, but also for our children and their children. We do not want to leave this country to our children in a worse state than it was when we were young ourselves. That is exactly the way we are going and this is the basis of the Fightback policy and Jobsback itself. It is interesting that the Jobsback policy has been acclaimed by industry and employers throughout Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nonsense.

—Senator Cook may be able to pick up the odd one here and there, but I will come to this later when I quote them group by group. They have not just supported it for selfish self-interest. They have supported it because they know it will improve their competitiveness. By improving competitiveness, real jobs will be created and the one million people out there without jobs will be given some hope, particularly the young people. In some places 40 per cent of young people are unemployed and they will be given hope for the future.

PARA.TAB: It is a realistic policy and it is needed for our move towards the twenty-first century when jobs will be found only in those areas of the globe that are internationally competitive. This is the only way to get our country back on track and it must be done soon or we will lose forever our place on international markets.

Maybe that is what this Government wants. Maybe it does not give a damn about ordinary Australians—the ordinary men and women of Australia. The Government is interested in the power brokers at the top.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were a boss in your private life. Tell us about ordinary Australians.

—I am glad that Senator Cook has interjected. Here he is, the leader of the BWIU, the TLC and all those sorts of things! He has now said that I was a boss. He may be interested to know my own background. I started as a storeman-packer in Wellington Street, Collingwood in Melbourne, I worked my way into a factory, I worked in the trenches out between Melbourne and Sale in the mud and slush and, subsequently, I worked my way into the mining industry.

PARA.TAB: Senator Cook has asked me to respond and I am happy to do so, because I have worked in every type of industrial scene that he can imagine. I have worked in mixed union factories where some people were members of a union and others were not. I might add that back in the sixties there were no hassles with that. I have worked in a totally closed shop in the coal mining industry and I have worked with contractors who are non-unionised.

Everyone knows the hatred held by unions for contractors. They want to keep contractors off the sites. Why? Because they make more money and are more productive. There is nothing worse to a militant trade unionist than a productive worker. Senator Cook knows that and I know that. He has seen it and he engineered it in the Pilbara.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish.
—Senator Cook engineered it in the Pilbara.
—I did not.

—Senator Cook went into make work programs because he reckoned businesses could afford it. In the process this has spread throughout Australia and Senator Cook and his ilk have put an awful lot of people out of work and thrown them on the unemployed scrapheap.

PARA.TAB: It is important to say that our aim and the aim of people on this side of the chamber is not to support a particular power group. I am sure Senator Cook himself now realises—although he may not have realised it then—the damage that he and a lot of his colleagues did to the Australian economy. I am sure that he is now locked into supporting a regime in the past, even though he knows that it has failed.
I will quote a recent article in which Senator Cook said words to the effect of:

SPEECH.PARA: We have recognised there have been problems and we have addressed them.
Does Senator Cook really believe that the Labor Government has turned this country around? They have made it a little better than it was, but it was in the pits.

TALK.START.PARA: —You put it there.
—Senator Cook gets up here and has a habit of talking about honesty. For goodness sake, why does he not come to me one day and make a confession?

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8.00 p.m..

TALK.START.PARA: —Before dinner, we were debating the coalition's Jobsback program, which simply exists to create real jobs for all Australians and to result in higher real wages. The campaign has been run, not unexpectedly, I suppose, by leaders of the trade union movement, who have attempted to run a scare campaign. One claim is that the coalition's intent is to wipe out the unions. Nothing could be further from the truth. Trade unions have been with us for a long time and they will be with us for many years into the future. Of course, how long they exist and how strong they become will depend on the service they offer, because the Jobsback program opens up the union movement to competition, and that is anathema to them. I suppose that the program has the potential to break down the power base if they do not offer Australians the incentive to join a particular union.

PARA.TAB: With any group—it does not have to be a trade union—that has had a monopoly over a long time, there is a resistance to anything that opens it up to competition. I suppose that an analogous comparison would be as outlined today in the Australian Financial Review by Senator Peter Walsh under the name of `Cassandra', where he talked about breaking down the marketing authorities and the resistance there was to that. Once a group of any sort has a monopoly over any group of people, it has power over those people. It is then only a matter of time before those people become unimportant and power becomes the important thing.

As has been pointed out by Mr Howard, it is worth noting that no political party, no religious denomination and no other community group has guaranteed adherence in our society. The same must apply to trade unions. The Jobsback policy quite clearly states that we will ban compulsory membership, but that in itself does not make the policy anti-union. Over the last few years we have made it very clear that we will fight for the right of people to join a union in the same way that we will fight, and with the same passion, for those who do not wish to join a union. It is a basic freedom. It merely gives the worker a choice and the freedom to make that choice.

Unions should not have a monopoly on bargaining power on the workers' behalf. If they offer the features that people want in life, people will take them. But they will not be compelled to do so under the coalition's policy; that is the vital difference.

Remarks have also been made about enterprise based bargaining. Senator Cook said that the Labor Party opposed enterprise based bargaining in 1983 or 1984, when it was first proposed by the coalition. His claim is that the timing was not right then. However, after the passage of a few years, it was supposedly adopted by the Labor Party. The coalition's enterprise based bargaining was never adopted by the Labor Party, because the thrust of the coalition policy is that employers and employees would have the right to be able to negotiate between themselves the work conditions, et cetera, that they need to run a successful operation. The difference is that the Labor Party has introduced a Claytons-type enterprise based agreement where the worker takes a secondary role and the primary relationship is between the employer and the union.

Nothing could have brought this home clearer than the recent debacle on the Gold Coast with the Gazal enterprises. I believe that the owner of the business is Mr Chawki Gazal. The enterprise had concluded that there was a slack time in the year, which comes towards Christmas, and that the way for the enterprise to be more successful was for the people who normally work there—some 125 or 130—to work on a casual basis around that slack period and then go back to full time work when there was demand for the company's product.

This was exactly what both the employees and the management of Gazal enterprises wanted, so they formed an enterprise agreement to that effect. To the surprise of everyone, this was taken awfully seriously. Ms Anna Booth, from the ACTU, flew from Melbourne, confronted the management and workers and told them that it was not on. Here was a clear example of a proper enterprise based agreement between the workers in what I believe, from reports given to me, is a very happy workplace.

I will not forget the television program where the workers of Gazal said to Ms Anna Booth, `Anna, will you please leave us alone and go back to Melbourne; we want to go back to work'. Of course the union did not want a bar of it, because it talked of all the old things that have caused all the problems in Australia over the past 20 years under the existing system. Concern was shown by Ms Booth that this arrangement could flow on. The old flow-on problem has probably cost more jobs in past times with the exponential growth in wages that went from one to the other. Under the coalition's enterprise agreements, this would not occur.

A claim is made that workers will be exploited under enterprise based agreements. I will not go into the safety net issue, because a safety net has certainly been put within the Jobsback policy. What I will say—and I say this from the experience of my whole working life—is that I have yet to see an organisation survive which exploited its workers. One problem is that once a third party, such as a union, comes in and makes the rules for an organisation, in effect, the workers are put on the outskirts and the employer finds himself or herself in the position where he or she gives them their rights and nothing more and nothing less. This dehumanises the organisation.

One problem with unionism as we have known it over many years is that it exacerbates the `them and us' position. This attitude comes not from within the organisations; it arises because of the will being imposed from outside that what is good for the organisation is good for the employee. In other words, an expanding, growing organisation with increasing productivity reflects itself in the workers and the remuneration they get. So a growing organisation not only gives stability and continuity of work, which is terribly important in any society, but also a share in the profit increase that comes with increased productivity—not wage increases that are not based on productivity.

Support for Jobsback has come from a whole range of people and organisations. As I mentioned earlier in this speech, this is not because of self-interest but because of a recognition that, without a program such as Jobsback, we in Australia will not recover and our business enterprises will not be able to offer our young people jobs. The 1.1 million people unemployed will be entrenched and growing. Many people would argue, quite correctly, that the real level of unemployment is probably closer to two million than one million.

Support has come from the Tourist and Travel Corporation; the Gold Coast Visitors and Convention Bureau, which is a major tourist growth area; the United Graziers Association; the Australian Business Council president, Mr John Ralph, who, as I understand it, is also the Chief Executive of CRA; the National Farmers Federation; the Master Builders Construction and Housing Association; and the Queensland Confederation of Industry and so on.

One of the problems under the entrenched existing system—I know Senator Cook says that the Government has addressed it—is that the Government has a long way to go. Probably one would have to argue that it is almost impossible to handle it. Indeed, it is said that there is nothing wrong with the workers or the management, but that the system is up the spout. Before I came down here I looked up an engineering award out of Queensland and I obtained a recent copy. In addition to the normal wages and things provided, there were 44 extra allowances. I will not go into them because my time is about to run out, but they cover such items as dirty conditions, dirty timber, explosive power tools allowance and motor drivers allowance. The award is so bad that an extra employee is needed just to keep track of the additional allowances for someone working in the engineering business. Most engineering enterprises are probably guilty of some sort of default, because it is a bizarre situation.

Regrettably my time has run out, but I feel that we should continue this debate at some later stage. Jobsback is part of Fightback; it is the way to restore Australia's collapsed economy. There is no other option. It is an essential part of the Fightback program if we are to restore the—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The so-called urgency motion before the chamber tonight is shameful. The Government will not support it, we will vote against it, and we will call upon other senators, both independent and Democrat, in this place to join us in defeating it. Were it to be carried, it would be the surest sign to the community of Australia that the Parliament, including this Senate, has no faith in the people and that it wants to lower the living standards of ordinary Australians.

PARA.TAB: Two weeks ago, at a $100 a plate breakfast in Sydney, the Opposition released its much awaited industrial relations policy. We have waited for it since November 1991 when the consumption tax proposal, called Fightback, was first announced by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). We were told that the missing centrepiece of Fightback was the industrial relations policy, that all things would be explained by the industrial relations policy and that all problems would be solved when it was released. We were told that the fiscal holes that could be punched in Fightback—holes to the level of $6.3 billion—would be solved by industrial relations issues. We were told that all the damage that is done by the Fightback proposal—the consumption tax, in which 70 per cent of Australian families are worse off—would be solved by the release of the industrial relations policy. We were told that the inflation boost that the consumption tax would give the Australian economy would be fixed by the industrial relations policy. We were told all those things.

The car manufacturers in Australia, who criticised the tariff regime proposed in the consumption tax package, were told, `We'll fix that problem with industrial relations'. The Catholic Social Welfare Commission, which raised reasonable questions on behalf of people on welfare in Australia, was told, `That will be solved through industrial relations reform'. The banking and finance quarters that criticised the consumption tax were told similar things, as was the tourist industry, which was its most vehement and recent critic, and as was the manufacturing industry which worried and fretted about tariffs.

So we waited. We even heard Tim Fischer, the Leader of the National Party, tell us on Lateline one night that all the problems in trade, including the North American trade treaty, would be fixed by the industrial relations policy of the Opposition. It is a wonder it did not claim that it would fix dandruff as well. It laid claim in the lead-up to the announcement of this policy that this missing centrepiece, once revealed, would be so stunning as to sweep aside all questions and all problems.

What do we have? We have a policy which in large part has pinched some of the language of the Labor Party and the Labor Government to disguise a policy which is nothing more than a low wage, high price, low skill, high confrontation policy. That is what we have. It is not a fair policy, because it removes fairness. It is not a decent policy that respects decency among ordinary Australians; it undermines decency. It is not a policy that is coherent; it has gaping holes through which one could drive a coach-and-four. Moreover, it is a policy which probably most fundamentally protects unscrupulous behaviour by employers and enshrines that with all the panoply of protections of the common law.

If Mr Howard in dreaming up this policy is to be characterised as an alchemist, he is laboured with the lead and dross of the political theories and doctrines of the Liberal Party. But he has not produced gold; he has only produced more lead in the saddlebags of the coalition as it runs to the polls, whenever the election is called.

The centrepiece could not be explained by the Leader of the Liberal Party, Dr Hewson. On the Sunday interview with Laurie Oakes, the Sunday after the policy was released, Dr Hewson when asked about the minimum wage and protections did not have an answer. The leader did not know. He was unable to explain how the safety net worked. Nor were we helped by his spokesman, Mr Howard, who on AM the next day produced a series of alternatives, any one of which could be true. Finally he fudged it by saying that the awards could be moved and that unions could change the awards and that would provide the safety net.

The Industrial Relations Commission, the independent umpire, the body which would make the awards and issue them as acts of law, is to be made voluntary. Its powers are to be effectively undermined, it is to be marginalised and removed from the ability to make binding awards where there is found to be an industrial dispute by the proper process. But, more importantly, the awards themselves become accessible only where both parties agree. This is the abomination at the centre of this policy. If there is a hole of any sort that can be more readily identified than any other, this is it.

Is it being said that workers can be entitled to the legally determined minimums provided for in an award after due process before an arbitrator, in which both sides have stated their case, adduced their evidence, presented their witnesses, inspected the premises and completed their arguments? When the arbitrator withdraws and, using the principles of justice, equity and the substantial merits of the case, brings down a decision which is then binding, do Opposition members seek to remove ordinary Australians from the coverage of that decision and to block their access to the Commission to resolve disputes or to provide them with properly determined rights unless both parties agree? If that is the case, it amounts to a veto by unscrupulous employers on the right of ordinary Australians to have access to proper and fair minimums determined in a proper and fair manner.

Yet we are told in the doublespeak that the Opposition has perfected in selling this policy—some of the language it has pinched from us to try to make its policy more palatable, some of the salesman's gimmicks, the sweet platitudes and the honeyed words that the Opposition uses to try to reassure ordinary Australians that somehow they will be protected—that the minimums that are being offered are substantial. I make it clear to the Senate that they are not substantial; they are shams and they are false. To believe that they offer any protection is to believe a myth. There is a huge gap between the language used by the Opposition to try to sell this policy and gull the credulous and the content and the black letter of what this policy actually says. Should there be any dispute, I commend the policy and a reading of it. If we simply read what the commitment is, then we can see the fallacy of the Opposition's position.

In short, not only did Dr Hewson not know and could not explain what a minimum wage was and not only could Mr Howard not adequately cover his leader but also last Sunday on the Sunday program we saw an interview between Laurie Oakes and the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, Mr Peter Reith. What did we have from Mr Reith? Mr Reith did not even understand what his cousins in Victoria, crude though they be, were doing when it came to the removal of the annual leave loading and weekend penalty rates. When asked the direct question, he gave an answer which was just not true and which caused the interviewer, Laurie Oakes, to blanch and all viewers to wonder whether this Party knows what it is talking about and whether it follows the industrial relations debate.

But perhaps the best answer was given on the day after the policy was unveiled with a drum roll and flourish of trumpets. On 23 October the Sydney Telegraph newspaper conducted a write-in poll of its readers to see whether or not the policy had been well received. The verdict of the electors, those people polled by that newspaper, was that three-quarters of the Australians responding rejected the policy. Is it popular? The answer was no. Seventy-five per cent of the respondents in that poll gave it the thumbs down.

The Premier of Victoria, Mr Jeff Kennett, has been condemned by Mr Howard and Mr Reith as a liar—condemned by them as someone who said before the election he would do certain things and, once in power, dishonoured his word and did other things.
