In all of the sanctimonious posturing that we had here earlier this afternoon about misleading, no-one from the other side of this Parliament raised a question about the duplicitous behaviour of Mr Kennett.

Is there anything more sickening in public life than the sight of Mr Gude, the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Government in Victoria, justifying his $8,500 pay rise, put through the Victorian Parliament at 4 a.m., because, he said, he worked hard and he needed a career path? At the same time, he is ripping the annual leave loading off all Victorians; as well, he is ripping weekend penalty rates off those Australians who work on weekends. Mr Gude is saying, `One rule for me. I need to be rewarded; I need a career path. The rest of you eat cake. I am contemptuous of the rest of you'.

But it goes further: what did he do at a cost to taxpayers he was penalising with a flat $100 property tax? What did he do at a cost to pensioners in Coburg who pay the same rate as the sharp practising lawyers in Toorak? What did this man, who said that $100 for everyone was fair, do? He reinstituted the silver service, the white glove waiters in the parliamentary dining room, for the Cabinet. That is Liberal philosophy on display—`We will have the lurks. We will have the white glove waiters. We will have the silver service. Thank you. We will take our pay rise but we will tax the rest of you'.

Ever since then, the Liberal Party has been on the back foot running away from what it has done. Mr Howard, who pretends not to be associated with what has happened, is in it, as are other Federal Liberals, up to his neck. How do we know that? We know that from what has come out of their own mouths.

Before these events became known, we had a statement from Mr Howard that the policy in Victoria that the Kennett Government was about to introduce was, give or take a few commas or punctuation marks, the same policy that he intends to introduce. We have from Mr Howard, out of his own mouth, the words, `I have worked closely with my Victorian colleagues in the framing of their industrial relations policy'. If one wants to see what the policy actually means, look south across the Murray into Victoria.

The Opposition's industrial relations policy means ordinary Australians being victimised. Remember the famous words of Mr Kennett before the election. What were they? He said, `No-one will lose a cent under my policies'. Look at what has happened now. The 17 1/2 per cent loading has been, or will be, taken off all of the Victorians to whom it applies and penalty rates for weekend work will be taken off all Victorians as well.

Victorians were told, `No-one will lose a cent'. All of those people will lose hundreds of dollars. All of those people who rely on penalty loadings because they work weekends and give up access to sport and recreation, religious worship or quality family time, all of those people who work at weekends when the rest of us are at play and recreation, will lose substantial income.

I pointed out today that a registered nurse operating under the Opposition's system of industrial relations will lose 44 per cent of her income. A security officer will lose 32 per cent of his income because the Opposition will take away the penalty payments for working on weekends. That is what Mr Kennett has done. That is what Mr Howard would do were his policy applied. One does not have to be Einstein to know that. Opposition spokesmen have said so.

It may well be that Victoria is the social laboratory. But while the tragic black comedy being played out in Victoria may differ in terms of a few decimal points or a few commas or dashes, it is inspired by exactly the same ideology and is on exactly the same theme and wavelength as the so-called Jobsback, properly entitled `Jobsack', package. In Victoria we are having a foretaste of what we would see if we ever had a Federal Liberal government.

I have produced a formal detailed point by point critique of the Opposition's industrial relations policy. In order to discover the true meaning of that policy, I commend to the Senate the critique which is entitled Unfair and Unnecessary. But, more importantly, I have produced a portfolio statement entitled Best and Fairest—best because we want the best economic system available; fairest because it has to be fair to all people and not just to those who happen to be born to the purple, have some higher income or somehow are regarded by the Opposition as being among the chosen privileged few. Best and Fairest talks about fair to ordinary Australians while producing the best and most efficient economic outcomes.

The policy that is being espoused and promoted in the urgency motion that we are invited to vote for tonight—the Government certainly will not do so—picks on women because they are in a vulnerable position in the work force. It picks on migrant workers because they too are similarly exposed. How can a migrant woman worker called into the boss's top office be expected to negotiate her independent employment contract, as the Opposition would require her to? How could she be expected to deal with an employer, know her rights and even understand what was being said? How could that be regarded as a bargain struck between equals? The notion itself, the very idea, is offensive.

The Opposition's industrial relations policy picks on shift workers for all the reasons that I have mentioned. It picks on people who work overtime. Their entitlement to overtime payments would be automatically removed under the Opposition's policy. It picks on people who attract any form of penalty rates. We had it again tonight from Senator Parer. It picks on people who want to work a normal day or a normal week because one of the rights that one would lose under the Opposition's industrial relations policy is the right to work a normal spread of hours.

Mr Howard himself says one can work 12 hours a day if necessary—no special payment, just the same flat rate. And one could work seven days a week—no special payment, just the same flat rate. Is this supposed to be fair, reasonable and decent? This is disreputable. It picks on all of those people who have annual leave. It will remove their ability to go away with the family—the wife and kids—and have a holiday in the caravan park, the chalet or somewhere else because they will not be able to afford to do so. They will lose the 17 1/2 per cent annual leave loading.

The coalition's policy picks on training and skill. This is, in many respects, one of the worst sins of the policy. In this country we have been coaxing a very highly skilled, specialised work force which is able to adapt its skill to new technology so that it can produce a highly sophisticated product, get high returns for that product and be paid high wages. There is nothing, not a single word, in the Opposition's policy about encouraging the formation of skills in this country or training our young people to take their place in a highly technological future.

Is there any vision? No, there is none. The coalition will shoot the umpire, the Industrial Relations Commission, which has been responsible for nearly a century now for refereeing the combatants in industrial relations in this country, bringing fairness, conciliation and mediation into play and, where necessary in the event of an intractable dispute, arbitrating the differences and making an order binding the parties. The umpire will be removed. There will be no access to fairness.

As I said in answer to a question in this chamber a few weeks ago, what this policy means is that the person who is screwing you has to give permission for you to be able to get to the umpire in order not to be screwed and to have fairness brought in. One has to get the permission of one's employer to have access to the umpire, the Commission, if one does not agree with what one's employer is doing. If that employer is unscrupulous, as many are, then you will not get access to the umpire and fairness will not enter the bargain. That is what the Opposition's policy would do.

Not all employers in Australia are unscrupulous; many of them are very good people. Many of them have come out and made it clear what they think of this policy—and many of them have rejected it. But if you are a good employer in competition with a bad employer and he is undercutting you because he is screwing his work force's wages down, you will be faced with this awful choice: do the same or go out of business. That is what this policy does. It does not work with people to improve this country; it works against them to reduce living standards, as if visiting pain on the backs of ordinary Australians is a way to the recovery. I conclude by quoting some comments in the West Australian newspaper attributed to the company JLV. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the proposition that the following matter proposed by Senator Parer is a matter of urgency:

PARA.TAB: The need for the Government to abandon its failed big unions, big government, compulsory centralised wage fixing system which has contributed to record unemployment, and adopt `Jobsback', the Coalition's worker friendly, enterprise based, high wage new jobs policy.

SPEECH.PARA: Essentially, that motion asks the Government to abandon its system. I suggest that such an action would be irresponsible and not practical. To start with, it is not at all easy to determine exactly what the Jobsback policy is. It changes regularly, it contains many inconsistencies, it is expressed in generalities and it would be rather difficult to implement in its present form. The action that is suggested in this motion would be irresponsible in the extreme.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at the adjectival terms Senator Parer uses to describe the system. The first is `big unions'. I will not disagree with that. It is my opinion that the union amalgamation process that has led to the numbers we have in unions now has meant that the system can accurately be described by the term `big unions'. I would suggest that it is not possible to agree with the next adjectival term that is used; that is, `big government'. In the Democrats' view, we do not have a `big government'; we have a government which is deregulatory—a government which admits and takes pride in the fact that it is non-interventionist and does not want to increase its powers of intervention in either the economy or the social welfare obligations that a government should have. In fact, this Government is privatising, corporatising and backing away from its fundamental responsibilities of government. I think we should pay a little attention to that.

In fact, I will cite an example which stretches across Australia to illustrate that the Government's attitude is not one that can be described by the term `big government'. The Government's attitude is such that it is leading to a lot of government business enterprises and even government responsibilities being fobbed off and handed over to other instrumentalities—either to the private sector or, in a halfway step to that, which I do not believe is satisfactory either, to corporatised instrumentalities such as the Federal Airports Corporation. That body is being directed to adopt this corporatisation philosophy which removes it from its original responsibilities to administer airports and asks it to make a profit. Of course, in the process we see such debacles as the one in Tasmania that I know something about, whereby the Federal Airports Corporation is changing the arrangements it has with hire car firms, attempting to make a dollar out of the operation involving access to airports. We do not have government any more; we do not have responsibility for the administration of airports; we have an organisation that sees its purpose in life as being to make a profit.

Honourable senators may remember the incident of the Scottsdale Materials Research Laboratory whereby the Government's responsibility to research into foods to provide for the defence forces was planned to be subsumed under the aim of being economically efficient, rather than looking at the effectiveness and value to the community in general, to Australia as a whole, of the fine research that was done at that establishment and the fine service that was provided to our armed forces. That was driven by this corporatising, hands-off Government—this Government for removing government from the responsibilities which it should rightly exercise and for seeking to justify things in terms of economic rationalism.

So I disagree with the description of this Government as a `big government'. It is not a `big government'; it is abrogating its responsibility to lead, to provide opportunities and to direct encouragement to enterprises which can develop and create employment for Australians—yet another responsibility that is fundamental to good government that is not being accepted by this Government. It is backing away from being a big government—trying to wash its hands of its responsibility, trying to get smaller and to take on fewer responsibilities. It has abrogated its responsibility to use all of the economic and trading levers at its disposal to nurture and protect Australian enterprises. We see evidence of that in its attitude towards tariffs. Aided and abetted by the coalition, the attitude has developed that we should be looking for some sort of international level playing field. That is a faulty attitude or philosophy, and it has been demonstrated as being to no advantage to Australia. So I submit that the `big government' description contained in this motion is a wrong description and that this Government is one which is backing away from its responsibilities.

The next adjectival phrase used to describe this system is, `compulsory centralised wage fixing system'. This is another myth which has been perpetuated by certain members of the coalition. In this regard I can refer to no greater authority than Senator Walters, who made that claim recently in the Hobart Mercury. In her letter she said that there is `no flexibility to allow work outside normal hours without penalty rates applying'. I think Senator Walters has been misled there. That is not true. There is considerable flexibility within the present system to negotiate and to in fact work outside normal working hours without penalty rates applying. In fact, there have been several enterprise agreements registered with and certified by the Industrial Relations Commission, many of which contain exactly those provisions.

We are reminded of that in an article in the Canberra Times of yesterday—that is, Monday 2 November—by Mr Mike Taylor. In that comprehensive article about industrial relations he points out that a considerable number of major Australian companies—including Broken Hill Pty Ltd, ICI Ltd, ANZ, Ford, Bridgestone Australia, Toyota Motor Corporation, Mayne Nickless, National Australia Bank and Taubmans, to name but a handful of the several hundred—have enterprise agreements in existence. He points out that virtually all of them `have been achieved in highly unionised and organised areas', with trade unions playing `an integral part in achieving those agreements'.

He goes on to tell us that there have been broad similarities in the way those agreements have been achieved and the way agreements have been struck in Japan, Germany and the United States. It seems that many big Australian companies like the sorts of results that can be achieved. Then he editorialises to some extent to tell us:
The problem with the Opposition's policy is that it does not offer them—

SPEECH.PARA: that is those companies I quoted earlier—

a continuation of what many of them now perceive as being a successful and versatile system. For this reason, some of the companies who have successfully managed to negotiate enterprise agreements will be looking to a Coalition government to accommodate them.
By `them', I assume he means those very agreements that have been previously negotiated. He continues:

PARA.TAB: If that accommodation cannot be made, then the Coalition may find that its policy cannot command 100 per cent employer support. More importantly, it will find that its policy lacks the necessary commitment from some of Australia's largest companies.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Parer quite rightly observes, the author of that article is there speculating. I pass no judgment of my own, but those agreements actually exist and the editorialising that the journalist applied is there for all to see.

PARA.TAB: A number of further enterprise agreements exist in which there is flexibility to work outside normal hours without penalty rates, which is the matter Senator Walters mentioned. We have several hundred examples of other flexibilities: changes to the hours of work, whether there are production processes—previously the subject of demarcation disputes—changes to work processes, whether the hours provide a basic core arrangement or a certain number of hours a day. Even the infamous rostered day off has been dealt with. For example, the Toyota agreement introduces a number of innovative changes to hours of work and rostered days off. These can now be scheduled to coincide with festivals or community events that may affect the majority of employees and which would previously have impacted on absenteeism. These sorts of flexibilities are in existence. It is foolish and narrow-minded to deny their existence and even perverse to suggest that it is now a system that does not allow flexibility.

We have to be very careful when considering the coalition's proposal that Jobsback would provide a suitable replacement to that which exists now. As I mentioned earlier, the Jobsback proposition contains its own internal inconsistencies. One of the early statements made by the Opposition spokesperson on industrial relations, Mr John Howard, was the fundamental suggestion that the Opposition would move away from a centralised wage fixing policy. It has been demonstrated that the coalition would need under this proposition to find a basic minimum, whether that relates to the awards or is a minimum determined by some other means.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is there.

—We are told that it is there by Senator Parer, but we are not told the mechanism for altering, improving or changing in any way those basic minimums which are proposed at the moment. We suspect, of course, that any change would be determined by nothing other than a centralised system. Whether that centralised system would be with reference to the system which has established the basic minimum awards for Australians for almost a century, as Senator Cook told us, or whether it would be determined with reference to the ultimate centralised system which the coalition has not yet identified, it would remain the centralised system. To me, that is a huge inconsistency which has yet to be addressed by proponents of this arrangement.

PARA.TAB: While the present system is far from perfect, the Democrats will continue to seek its improvement. We believe we achieved that in June by inserting a clause in the Industrial Relations Act to allow individuals the right to take their case to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission without union involvement. We also strengthened the legal sanctions which already existed against coercion to join unions and we will continue to work for industrial democracy where workers become more closely involved in the management decisions of their enterprise. Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, and on behalf of Senator Coulter, I move:
That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Coulter moving an amendment to the motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of Senator Coulter, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Omit all words after ``The need for the Government'', substitute ``to accelerate the pace of industrial relations reform from adversarial systems towards a system of flexible and streamlined enterprise agreements which encourage co-operation and conciliation between all participants in the labour market, whereby enterprise agreements would function in a system which safeguards minimum award wages and conditions and ensures the larger public interest is maintained, and guarantees the general social welfare of all citizens by distributing to them their share of the wealth of the nation''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot accept this amendment moved by Senator Bell to the urgency motion. It is just a glossy way of putting what currently exists. The amendment will do absolutely nothing to address the serious problems in this country in industrial relations of lifting productivity to anything like world competitive standards. I will refer to that later. The motion before us reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to abandon its failed big unions, big government, compulsory centralised wage fixing system which has contributed to record unemployment, and adopt `Jobsback', the Coalition's worker friendly, enterprise based, high wage new jobs policy.

We must look at a number of things. What has this Government delivered to employees in this country during its term in office? It has delivered a 2 per cent fall in real wages. One cannot walk away from that. Across the water in New Zealand, since it went that further step and introduced real reform to industrial relations, a real wage increase of 1.3 per cent has been delivered in less than six months. That is what we are here to talk about and that is what Jobsback is all about.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at a specific example of the meat industry, which has been absolutely paralysed by big unions, big government and the compulsory centralised wage fixing system. It is worth noting that back in 1990 the Harrison inquiry was put together to try to overcome the problems existing in the meat industry. The meat industry has the potential in this country to be huge, to value add in a meaningful way and to supply those markets very close to us in Asia. The Harrison inquiry reported over 12 months ago. What has happened since then? Very little.

Let us look at some of the figures. Despite the Harrison inquiry into the problems of the meat industry, we are still looking at $65,000 a year to provide a meat inspector for the meat industry. We are still looking at almost $93,000 a year to provide veterinarians to service the industry. Back in 1990, in the United States—and the situation is similar in South American countries and in other competing countries—its cost of processing beef was 10c a kilogram. In Australia it was 45c a kilogram.

Let us look at the current figures and what the industrial relations policy of this Government has delivered to us, along with a fall in real wages of 2 per cent. In America the cost of processing beef has increased to 13c a kilogram. Yet in Australia our costs are still 42c a kilogram. When it comes to the big ticket items, the big issues, the areas where we can make real gains, little or nothing has been done. Each time attempts have been made to tackle this situation, because of the AMIEU and Wally Curran—with the support, unfortunately, of the ACTU and others—those attempts have failed totally. When we look at this in the broader perspective we find that we can bring up case after case.

Let us look further at what happened with the Harrison inquiry and the Full Bench when the decision was made. The AMIEU was instructed by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission—and this is where the Industrial Relations Commission is powerless—not to break any of the agreements that were put in place between MATFA and the ACTU and the AMIEU, and they turned their noses up at it. They turned their noses up at President Joe Riordan. The Australian Industrial Relations Commission, when looking at the Harrison report, once again recommended that a consultative committee be put in place. What happened with regard to that consultative committee? It was torpedoed once again by Mr Curran and the AMIEU—a repeat of what happened three years ago. Then Senator Cook and Mr Crean decided they would set up their own private little consultative committee—it is a pity that the Minister has left the chamber—and one might well ask what has happened to that. It has been torpedoed once again.

So when people get up here and pick out small examples of areas where they claim their policy is working, they are not looking at the total picture. They are not looking at what can be done on an industry by industry or broader basis. They just pick a selective little case in most instances where many of the employers have been coerced into a position where they have no option but to go along with the forces that the big unions apply to them at a particular time. Their other option is to go bankrupt. And of course that is what has happened to many of the export abattoirs around this country, particularly in Victoria. Victoria now has less than half the number of export abattoirs that it had 10 years ago. Yet not long ago, when the wool crisis was on, many stock in this country were shot because there was not a competitive processing industry that could take them.

All Senator Bell's amendment will do is facilitate our current problems. The problems of the meat industry in Victoria extend to Western Australia, South Australia, the Northern Territory, Tasmania, New South Wales and Queensland—right across this whole nation. They have not been addressed by the so-called conciliatory process of the current Government, nor will they be addressed by Senator Bell's amendment.

I wish to talk about some of the changes we have to make to our current position, a position that Senator Cook regularly misrepresents. We have put in place a number of safety nets to allow much more freedom of choice in industrial relations, freedom for individuals to work out their own arrangements. The first safety net is that, if both parties wish to stay in the current system, they may—but both parties must wish to stay in. The second safety net is that, if one or other party does not or cannot reach a workplace agreement, then the award conditions of that day will remain as if a contract had been formed and will not be varied until both parties agree.

The third safety net, which has already been enlarged on here today, is that where a workplace agreement is formed, that will be subject to some minimum standards. The first one is the minimum hourly rate, the second one is in terms of holidays, the third one is in terms of maternity leave and the fourth one is in terms of sick leave. I shall enlarge on those at another time. The fifth one is something which does not exist now, and that is an employee's advocate. The role of the Office of the Employee's Advocate will be to look after problems regarding unpaid wages, agreed entitlements or people unfairly dismissed or treated. So there will be protection there; a safety net will be in place. The sixth one is that, in the event of the breach of a contract or a workplace agreement, a $5,000 maximum will be put in place on which any action under common law can be taken. That, once again, is a first in terms of safety nets.

Our industrial relations position is such that, unless we are prepared to face the issue of lifting productivity in Australia, not only will we continue to see the fall in real wages that this Government has delivered to employees in this country but we will also continue to see one million people unemployed. That is what this Government—those people on the other side, the Minister Senator Cook and others—has delivered and will continue to deliver. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating as a matter of urgency the motion moved by Senator Parer in which he urges the Government to adopt Jobsback—as he puts it, the coalition's `worker friendly, enterprise based, high wage, new jobs policy'. It is quite interesting tonight to watch the metamorphosis of Senator Parer. He has gone from being a decent bloke to a salesman. Senator Parer as a salesman is a unique thing in this place. Sure, he might starve as a salesman, but still, it is a new job he has taken on. It is to sell this new package, this new product called Jobsback. It is worker friendly—as if it is cuddly, it is lovable and it is so good and so safe that you can even give it to your kids. That is what he has tried to sell—Jobsback.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting that in Senator Parer's attempt to sell this proposal he has no option but to move further to the right, just as the whole Hewson Opposition has moved further to the right of industrial relations matters at a time when the rest of the world, the USA, the United Kingdom—those countries that have experimented with the sorts of things that the Hewson Opposition is proposing—have moved away from the sort of approach that Dr Hewson wants to take.

Obviously, it is a bit of a problem for the Opposition because the timing is not so good. Jeff Kennett ends up being elected as Premier of Victoria. The worst thing about the election of Jeff Kennett in Victoria is that Jeff Kennett has put into place exactly the sorts of industrial relations propositions that the Liberals have been floating in Fightback and Jobsback. That is embarrassing because, as Peter Reith said the other day, `we had a deal'—and I know what the deal was. Peter Reith, representing the Federal Liberals, had a deal that, presumably, Jeff Kennett would not implement its so-called hard-line industrial relations reforms, the sorts of things that are contained in Fightback and Jobsback, before the next Federal election.

The worst thing about it is that if Premier Kennett introduces them, the people of Victoria—and now the people of Australia—will suddenly start to realise what the industrial relations policies of the Liberals look like in practice, rather than in some thick book which presumably all the Liberals take to bed with them each night and read for comfort.

What stands out clearly about the way Jeff Kennett has approached industrial relations? The first thing that stands out that has so much similarity with the Hewson package is the need to take away the sort of things that people have held to be important and to take them away overnight. The second thing that stands out and is related to the first is the Opposition's disdain for one of the essential components of successful industrial relations. I refer to the need to consult and to bring all sides into the discussions. The Opposition's whole package—theoretically or in the practice that Jeff Kennett has put into place—has shown that the Opposition looks down on the concept of discussion and negotiation.

The third feature of the Opposition's package and the package that Jeff Kennett is putting into place is that those opposite look down on the necessity to negotiate with people. Opposition members look down on labour because they treat it just like any other commodity—money, computers, products. Somewhere along the line labour gets put into the cost arrangements. Those opposite think that somehow or other dropping wages, depressing the power of the union movement, depressing the workers into a position where they have no bargaining power, are essential components of a new economy. They think that we can follow the trail of Indonesia and all these other low wage countries. That is not the future for Australia.

When those opposite look at the record of this Labor Government, obviously they are embarrassed. They are embarrassed because we have listened to some of the things that Opposition members used to say. We have even listened to people on the other side who have shown sensitivity in this area and a certain degree of sensibleness. We have said to them, `Okay, some of the things you have said in the past have been right'. Unions have even listened to what management has been saying, to what those opposite have been saying, to what some people in our Government have been saying and they have said `Yes, enterprise bargaining is an acceptable way to go'. But the difference is that this Government has brought about those changes or encouraged those changes at a pace which is acceptable to the Australian community and to the players in the industrial relations world. I refer to the workers, unions, management, and also government. We have been prepared to preside over an evolving industrial relations system.

Everyone recognised in 1983 that the industrial relations system in this country had to change; I do not think anyone had any doubts about that. The difference was that we said that change has to be at a pace which is acceptable to the community, that one cannot impose change by government decree or by Fightback or by son of Fightback. Those opposite cannot just take some sort of dogmatic prescription laid down in their little book Fightback!—which they take to bed with them every night—as the way to go and say, `This is what we will impose on the community', especially those people in the industrial relations arena.

If those opposite think this is just a member of the Government speaking, then they should look at what some other people are saying. I am thinking of people who have had long experience in this area, people who have to employ other people, people who have to create jobs, people who have to have a decent bottom line and of what they have had to say about this Government's industrial relations policy. For example, on 21 October, Bert Evans from the MTIA said on 2CN:

SPEECH.PARA: We've got the most flexible award in Australia, the metal industry award.
That award covers thousands upon thousands of workers. He continued:
We've made significant changes to it over the last few years.

Our enterprise bargaining agreements we've made, and things like hours of work, being able to work extra hours in the peak periods and a lot less hours in the off peak periods, have been a major breakthrough . . .
Brian Loton, the Chairman of BHP, said on the World Today:

BHP has for a long time advocated enterprise agreements. We believe that we've made very great progress with our people and with the unions under the present Government and we think that there's a great element of what we're doing included in the Opposition's Fightback package.
The point is that it has been done already under this Government. The reporter asked Brian Loton:
Does that mean you're quite happy for a weakening in the IRC, and indeed the unions?
Brian Loton said:

No, I'm not talking about a weakening in unions. I am talking about enterprise bargaining where the people in the enterprise are able to have an adequate say in the arrangements that obtain in their workplaces, which is what we do in BHP right now and have done it for many years . . .
I can add to that `and under a Labor Government'. It happened because we encouraged it, the union movement sought the opportunities and because it was prepared to talk.

PARA.TAB: Goninan's General Manager, Chris Higgins, believes forcing an accelerated pace of reform on the company would endanger this progress already made. Warren Haines, the Chief Executive Officer of ICI, said on Lateline:

SPEECH.PARA: We started workplace reform about four years ago, about 1988/89, and we have spread it around most of our sites now. We have got 28 sites that have now got an enterprise agreement in place . . .
He further said:

The union leadership at the top has been very enlightened and helpful and supportive of these sorts of moves. Obviously union officials at the local level occasionally feel threatened when we take this sort of change because it means a different role for them. It's more of an advisory role than it has been in the past . . .

Garry Brack of the New South Wales Employers Federation was the most dubious about the Fightback proposals. He said that the coalition policy was neither a necessary nor a sufficient condition for industrial progress and improved productivity. He said that making laws is not relevant, but that changing cultures is. That is exactly what we have been talking about in this Government for a long time. Cultures are changed not by imposing them from the top, by government, but from beneath—from the middle and from the top, altogether. That has been achieved under this Government. This Government was the first anywhere in the world to set in place a social contract, a social award, called the accord. That accord has lasted, in various ways, over nine years.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been a failure.

—It has been regarded as a success by many people around the world. They say that Australia, a country in great difficulties economically for all sorts of reasons—and I will not even go back and blame Fraser for it; I can say that it is something that all of us should have addressed about 15 years ago—has managed to be in a position for take-off. One day it will take off again, because we have been in a position to have unions and management working together.

PARA.TAB: If those opposite want to set the record aside and change everything for a pig in a poke, then they should say so now. If they want to go into a brave new world in which there is a jungle out there in industrial relations, in which the lawyers do the best of anyone, then they should say so now. That is the logical implication of the Opposition package. For once those opposite could have said, `The Labor Party has been right, the Labor Party has done the right thing; we will offer other policies in other areas where we think change is necessary'. The point is that we have been on a winner and those opposite know it, so they have to go further to the right to look after their constituents.

We have achieved a very low level of inflation, we have the lowest level of industrial disputes for 30 years and we have had an overhaul of Federal awards. For example, in the metal industry 388 job classifications are now in 14 skill categories. The door has been opened for multi-skilling in so many industries. We have had workplace agreements proceeding positively around this country. In the last 12 months 360 individual workplace agreements have been approved by the Industrial Relations Commission. Superannuation, as part of the increased wages component, has given many more people in the Australian community—many more workers—an opportunity for superannuation and a decent retirement than ever before. We have also, as those opposite well know, helped to create a pool of investment funds available for Australia's future benefit.

When one looks at our industrial relations system, one sees that many things have flown from it—stability and a reputation overseas amongst our major customers, such as those in Japan, for delivering on time. We have achieved workplace agreements which, in many ways, are setting a pattern for other parts of the world. It is coming into place and we are doing it at a pace at which everyone feels, not comfortable, but relatively satisfied.

The Opposition bases its industrial relations system on the need to be different from us. Therefore, firstly, it moves further to the right and, secondly, does so on some ideology which makes some of the rigid doctrinaire people in the Labor Party of the 1960s look like pussy cats. That is what those opposite have done. They have tried to prove that they are different. The trouble is that they are now hampered with Fightback and Jobsback. No matter how they try to sell it as a soft, cuddly and warm package that will not frighten the kids and that can be given to the next generation, Jeff Kennett has proved in practice that it does not work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great pleasure to speak on this urgency motion because Australians want to work, and they want to work effectively, but under this Government they cannot. That is an acute personal problem, not only for the million that are a consequence of the policies that Senator Aulich has labled as having been successfully implemented by this Government, but it is also an acute national problem. This motion states:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to abandon its failed big unions, big governments, compulsory centralised wage fixing system which has contributed to record unemployment, and adopt `Jobsback', the Coalition's worker friendly, enterprise based, high wage new jobs policy.

The reason for the motion is the very serious failure of the industrial relations policy of the Labor Government. It is always disappointing in a debate like this, where there should be some content, to follow a speech as devoid of content as that that we have had from Senator Aulich. I just hope that in his new career as a writer he does not suffer from the same sort of block when he is writing his novels, because things would be a little hard for him if he did.

PARA.TAB: The point is that Australia is now at one of the great change points in its history. We have seen a similar situation in the last 45 years. We saw the period after the end of the Second World War, between 1945 and 1949, when Australia had become an industrial country. We had a Labor Government in place and it was totally unable to get its affairs organised and to maximise, for the benefit of Australian citizens, the great advances made industrially throughout the Second World War.

The Labor Government was voted out in 1949 and we went into the golden age of Australian politics of this century under the Menzies Government. We had in place a system which gave rising living standards, year after year; a greatly expanding population; and zero unemployment. Throughout that period of great economic growth we had social stability and we did not have the crime levels that we have now plaguing the Australian society. We have a similar change point before Australia at present. There are great changes in the international trading pattern. We have seen the end of the Cold War and the breaking up of the trading blocs. We need to change. We have got to be competitive, in the jargon of the times, with best international practice. We must change the way we do things. If we do that we can prosper, and we certainly could do it if the Government would move.

We have seen the end of the labour intensive manufacturing industries and the growth of the service industries—the tertiary sector. That requires a totally different management scheme to the big jack-booted, big unions, big government style that this Government knows so well. People have to be treated as individuals and provided with incentives in order to get the best out of them. In fairness to this Government, I do think it recognises that to some degree. The problem it has is that it only went halfway down the path. It did deregulate the financial markets but clearly did not do that properly because the checks and balances necessary in that system were not implemented. But what it can never do is deregulate the labour market, and these two changes must go hand in hand.

The power of the union movement is still paramount in too many industries. We have the archaic systems that Senator Parer talked about with a centralised wage system. No other country in the world sets a wage for a similar task right across the country. To do so, means that many industries do not get started. People working in country towns can afford to work for less because their rates, travel expenses and property values are a lot lower than in the centre of a capital city.

If one looks at what has happened in the United States this century, one will see that many world giants started in small towns. A small town, Cedar Rapids, produced Collins Radio, which is now part of the Rockwell Corporation, one of the giants in the international communications world. That started because of the cheap workforce in a country town. Those sorts of things clearly cannot happen under Labor's policies.

We had 20 minutes of Senator Cook. He was talking about the problems as he saw them with the coalition's policies. I have to say that my mind turns to an article in the Age dated 22 October which was headed, `Assault on coalition's IR policy damaged by Cook'. The first paragraph reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The federal Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, yesterday badly hurt the Government's assault on the coalition's industrial policy by first arguing it would greatly disadvantage workers and then accusing the Opposition of stealing the Government's ideas.
Senator Cook's speech tonight showed that that confusion still exists in his mind, and that there is no coherent policy coming from the Government at all.

PARA.TAB: In the 10 years that we have now had a Labor Government, we have seen no changes in Australia's productivity. We still have one of the lowest increases in productivity, year by year, of any country in the Western World. Certainly we have seen some change on the waterfront, and the waterfront is crucial to us. We are moving more containers an hour, but the cost to the shipper is still the same—the money has not gone back in the form of lower charges for shippers as a consequence of that change. We still do not meet the movement rate for containers that is met in Singapore, and do not let us have any of this business that Singapore is a cheap, low wage, sweated labour country. Average weekly earnings now in Singapore are higher than in Australia.

The big problem has been that the Labor Party is the political wing of the union movement, rather than the union movement being the industrial wing of the political party. The union movement tells the Labor Party what is to be done. In fairness, too, to the leaders of the ACTU, they recognise the need for change but they have been hamstrung by the huge, inert, uninformed mass of the Labor movement. They have tried to move the Labor movement along a bit, but the load is just too great for them to bear, so nothing much is happening.

The big chance for us is the production of the Jobsback policy by the Liberal and National parties. It will go most of the way towards reforming the work practices in Australia. If all the procedures are implemented in government, we will see a reformation in work practices in Australia. We will see the return of rising living standards instead of the falling living standards which have characterised the years of this Government. We will see a high productivity, high wage policy. We will see the removal of restrictions on working hours and, most importantly, we will see the end of compulsory unionism. People will be able to join a union if they want to and they will not be discriminated against in any way at all for exercising that right. But those who do not want to join a union will be able to take up workplace agreements and they will be subject to compulsory minimal standards.

In everything that will be done to change industrial relations under a Liberal-National Party government there will be a secure and complete safety net so that people will not be held to ransom by unreconstructed eighteenth or nineteenth century capitalistic employers. As well as the other procedures, we are going to set up an Office of the Employee Advocate which will give free advice to any worker who feels he has a grievance against his employer.

When those changes are implemented, we will see Australia start to develop, to grow, and take its rightful place in the world, and we will see a reduction in that huge legacy of one million unemployed—which is only the consequence of the failure of the Labor Party to deal with a changed Australian and international industrial scene. We can do it; we are well able to do it. The only obstacle between Australia and the goals that we have been outlining is the Labor Government. Come the next election, the Labor Party will go just the way the Labor Government did in 1949, and it will go for precisely the same reason: a total inability to react to demands placed on it by a changed society.

The Labor Party might be all right at running the status quo—and I have great reservations about that—but, given the magnitude and scope of change that is before us now, the Labor Party has proved in the last 10 years that it is utterly incompetent and inadequate at coming up with anything that is satisfactory for the needs of Australia. The fact that we have over a million unemployed out on the streets today is living testimony to that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion moved by my colleague Senator Parer, which states:

PARA.TAB: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for Government to abandon its failed big unions, big government, compulsory centralised wage fixing system which has contributed to record unemployment, and adopt `Jobsback', the Coalition's worker friendly, enterprise based, high wage new jobs policy.

I strongly support this motion because I strongly support the need to pay higher wages and salaries to Australian workers. I strongly support the need to create more jobs and a more competitive Australian economy.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to contrast that with the attitude of the Labor Party. I was interested in the concession, albeit a small concession, that Senator Aulich made in his remarks that the Labor Party had listened to the comments that we and many other people had made on its policies and had moved to address those concerns. I remind you, Madam Acting Deputy President, of what Mr Keating said just some three years ago, almost to the day, about the Metal Trades Industry Association. On 31 October 1989, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Those organisations know what enterprise bargaining means: it means that they get cut to ribbons. They are in the eye of the storm.
Senator Childs will remember that all through the campaign leading up to the last Federal election there was this constant attack on enterprise bargaining. Again, Mr Keating said in the Parliament:

Does anybody believe that in an economy with any growth, particularly such as we have had, the enterprise bargaining model would do anything other than lift wage rates and inflation way beyond the levels at which they are now?

It is interesting that enterprise bargaining in 1989 was going to lift wage levels. Senator Childs will remember that. The Opposition was attacked because, under its policy of enterprise bargaining, as it then was, wages would supposedly rise too far. The 1992 attack is that under the workplace agreements real wages would fall.

PARA.TAB: We can see, once again, the big scare tactics of the Labor Party. But I think it goes a little further than that. We now have a government that has been in office for some 10 years. We have a government whose model of managing the Australian economy has been tested. It has had the time to show us what its policies will deliver.

I started my remarks by saying that I am concerned about the need to lift the living standards of Australian workers. I have had some statistics pulled out by the Parliamentary Library to see what has happened to the living standards of the average Australian worker under the union controlled Keating Labor Government. What has that done to the average incomes of Australian workers? One way of measuring this is to look at what has happened to real average weekly earnings. It is interesting—and these are in 1989-90 dollars, so we are comparing like with like—that in 1982-83 real average weekly after tax earnings were $24,718. Almost 10 years later, in 1991-92, the comparative figure is $24,346.

So over this period of the accord—it is the Labor Party's accord; it is the Labor Party's policy; it is what the Bill Keltys and Martin Fergusons of this world developed to run the Australian economy—what did it do for Australian workers? The first measure is: what did it do for living standards? We find that over that period, on the latest figures that are available to me, real average earnings did not stabilise or increase marginally under the policies of the Labor Party; they fell. That is why I believe the Australian public will reject the Labor model.

But we know there is some debate about whether average weekly earnings is the best measure of living standards. I have discussed other measures in this chamber, and Senator Cook has repeatedly failed to take up my challenge because he knows the fact is that the Keating Labor policies have cut the average weekly earnings, the living standards, of Australian workers. That is one measure.

The second measure is: what has the Bill Kelty-Martin Ferguson-Paul Keating accord done for jobs? It is an important issue, and we can see that unemployment in this country has risen to record levels under the Labor Party's policies. A table published in the latest Economist measures the unemployment statistics of 24 countries. Where does Australia come? I will just go through the main ones that have a better unemployment record than Australia: Japan, Ireland, Switzerland, Portugal, West Germany, Greece, Austria, Sweden, Norway, Holland, Turkey, United States, Belgium, Italy, Britain—Britain has a better unemployment rate, at 10.1 per cent, despite all the comments by Senator Button—New Zealand, which also has 10.1 per cent, and France. Then there is Australia. Australia has an unemployment rate of 11 per cent under Labor Party policies. All those countries I mentioned have done infinitely better running their economies than the Labor model has done running this economy. So the Labor Party has failed to increase living standards and lower unemployment.

Let us look at productivity and see whether Labor Party policies are making us more competitive. I can draw on the very extensive work of the Australian Chamber of Commerce. It has noted during the 1990s that the productivity growth in Australian industry has been about half that of other industrialised countries. So when we take those three statistics—the fall in living standards, unemployment, the miserable productivity growth—and compare them with the disastrous foreign debt which has grown up under the Labor Government, we can see what Labor policies have produced. Jobsback is a policy which is designed to tackle that problem effectively.

Yes, the Government has made some gains and has moved—albeit very marginally—towards our policy. The trouble is that, as the Australian Chamber of Commerce says, even though Australia may be running faster in a number of areas, our competitors are running even faster and Australia is therefore still falling behind in commercial, economic and trading terms. That is what the Government's model has produced—failure, failure, failure. That is why Australians need new hope and a new policy and Jobsback offers that policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with the following matter of urgency proposed by Senator Parer:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to abandon its failed big unions, big government, compulsory centralised wage fixing system which has contributed to record unemployment, and adopt Jobsback, the Coalition's worker friendly, enterprise based, high wage new jobs policy.

I reject that motion, but I want to thank Senator Parer for the opportunity he has given to Senator Cook, Senator Aulich and myself to describe the steady progress of the cooperative industrial relations system that has developed under this Government; a system that has built multiskilling, training and education into the work force for the first time. It has created career structures in industry for the first time and changed the industrial culture of this country.

PARA.TAB: The consistent reduction of industrial disputes is one of the best indicators of our success and in the last decade we have seen more positive change in this country than in the previous 40 years. During many of those years the conservative parties occupied government.

I want to congratulate Senator Parer for not smiling when he described the coalition's Jobsback proposal as `worker friendly'. I really want to congratulate him because the phrase `worker friendly' is really creative, but it is a creative camouflage. If this coalition were ever to be successful and become the Government, it would introduce a GST led increase in prices and an industrial relations system that would reduce wages. The term `worker-friendly' is as sincere as Premier Jeff Kennett's election promise. Jeff was worker friendly before the election and, of course, he breached those promises, as others have pointed out. He is now following the coalition's real program of prices up and wages down.

Senator Parer has said that that is a number one priority of the coalition. I welcome that, because industrial relations is, under the coalition, a key part of their program. Of course, the other part of it is something Dr Hewson and Premier Kennett are devotees of, that is, trickle-down economics. This is the style of the coalition. It is to help the rich and belt the battlers. It does not work.

The policies of greed and selfishness are being rejected across the world. Tomorrow Clinton will become the President of the United States because the Reagan-Bush policies which Hewson and Kennett have followed have left American industry stagnant. In the United Kingdom Prime Minister Major has followed the same slash and burn ideology as the coalition and he is in a terminal state as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom. The coalition is still going on with the same big bang policies and economic fundamentalism which has been abandoned elsewhere in the world.

I would like to draw attention to Jobsback and Fightback and the policy that the coalition is putting forward of moving people away from the award system. New contracts only have to contain minimum requirements and for annual leave, sick leave and maternity leave the lowest minimum award rate will apply. Therefore, employers can present employees with agreements which cut people's pay by reducing hourly wages, abolishing annual leave loadings and eliminating penalty rates and shift and overtime allowances.

Senator Parer talked about where he worked in his previous employment. I have done shift work and, as far as I am concerned, when people have to work shift work or work over the weekends and their life is disrupted by those conditions, then they are entitled to be recompensed for that. They should not have those conditions arbitrarily taken from them.

Of course, eliminating penalty rates and shift work and overtime allowances is absolutely scandalous, just as removing the limits on daily working hours is unfair and unjust. That is what the coalition is setting out to do and, in addition, it will reduce casual loadings.

The minimum wage proposal does not protect employees' existing incomes. Apart from putting overtime, penalty rates and shift rates up for grabs, it is only the lowest minimum base rate in the award which is guaranteed. In a typical minimum rates award, the base rate, plus any supplementary payment, are added to produce the award rate of pay. The term `base rate' is used in Jobsback and the Victorian legislation. For many workers, the difference between their classification rate and the lowest base rate in the award is significant. It would be financially devastating for them. This is not worker friendly; there is no way it can be. For example, the minimum award rate for a metal industry trades person would fall from $417.20 per week, including supplementary payments, to $284.80 per week with no supplementary payments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on!

—Admittedly, that is the extreme, but there will be cases where, under this coalition proposal, that will happen. Perhaps that assumes that the worker will be offered a full 38-hour week. When workers understand this there will be a riot, because of the unjustness of reducing wages from $417 to about $284. Moreover, once the term of the initial contract has expired, employers will be able to withdraw from the agreement and so remove any lingering legal necessity for an employee's existing entitlements to be preserved.

PARA.TAB: From the day after an employee is forced on to an individual contract, he or she will be worse off. The value of their frozen wage declines. They have no right of access to the Commission. They have no means of improving their wages and conditions, except by reaching an agreement with the employer. Subsequently, I will show how unfair that process is. It is on the employer's terms and that is what this policy is all about.

John Howard, the spokesman for the Opposition, has stated that he expects an employer's terms to be the abolition of penalty rates and shift and overtime allowances, as I have said, and the expansion of working hours. Today Senator Cook has pointed out that the Opposition has never attempted to reconcile its claims that no worker will be worse off with its proposal that employers should be able to run their business 24 hours a day, 365 days a year without penalty, because they are irreconcilable. This is the hidden agenda that Premier Kennett introduced. We have had a taste of what it would be like if the Federal coalition were to be elected.

In contrast, I wish to refer to the Government's focus on industrial relations which is based on fairness and a central distinction between its approach to industrial relations and that of the Opposition. The `no disadvantage' test that is central to the new certified agreement provisions in the Act at the moment ensure that significant freedom is now available, but it cannot be used to exploit employees.

I am interested in this talk of enterprise agreements, which the Opposition thinks it has discovered. I was negotiating enterprise agreements as a union official in a cooperative way over 30 years ago. There is nothing new about enterprise agreements.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thirty years ago things were very different from today.

—That is the point. What I did 30 years ago involved having a fair, proper and reasonable approach where the union participated in working out those enterprise agreements with employers. They often involved the shake of a hand and were not even registered agreements, but they were honoured as though they were law. The point about it is that the agreement was voluntary on everybody's part, but the union was involved. State agreements, in particular, were honoured in a very proper way.

PARA.TAB: In exactly that same spirit, this Government this year has ratified 440 enterprise level agreements in the last 12 months. These agreements cover matters such as a change in the organisation of work; introducing more flexible conditions of employment to match fluctuations in demand and workloads; assisting workers in balancing work and family responsibilities; and improving the working environment.

Most significantly, these agreements cover the acquisition of skills and training. As Senator Cook has pointed out, the Opposition just does not comprehend that point. There has to be trust and an agreed arrangement. It is something that has to be done between equals if the skills of the work force are to be upgraded. It is a glaring omission in the coalition's package.

Other features of the Government's approach include the better use of plant and machinery. Therefore, there will be an increase in flexibility in the current industrial relations system of this country. The flexibility the Opposition wants is to drive down earnings. That is what Jobsback is all about.

Changes in the Industrial Relations Act by the Government this year were designed to encourage and facilitate the use of certified agreements. There are simple criteria to be met: there will be no disadvantage to the employees; dispute settling provisions; consultation by unions with effective members; and, unlike the policy of the Opposition, the Government allows flexibility in bargaining arrangements while protecting the socially desirable minimum standards. These new certified provisions of the Act ensure that a significant freedom is now available.

The Opposition policy ignores the question of who has power in the employment relationship. It assumes that individual employees are in a position to bargain on an equal footing with an employer. Around the developed world, systems of labour law have been established to overcome the natural power imbalance between employers, who have the power to hire and fire, to direct investment and design the workplace, and employees, who have only their skills to sell. That is really the key to it. It is a worldwide phenomenon.

The Government's industrial relations system is designed to overcome this obvious power imbalance. By abolishing mechanisms that exist to ensure that bargaining is relatively fair and equitable, the Opposition policy undermines the ability of employees to bargain effectively and defend their interests. With high unemployment, many workers will not be in a position to bargain with their employer but will be forced to accept whatever employers offer. That applies particularly to young workers, women workers in many situations and people with a migrant background. It is the opposite to industrial democracy.

Unfortunately, when speaking tonight, many Opposition senators indicated a lack of understanding of how people exist in industry at this moment. They believe and postulate that people with a migrant background, often with little English, could go into negotiations with an employer, with all the resources of the employer at his disposal, and negotiate fairly. That is just not true. The Opposition policy of trying to undermine trade unions and prevent them from being the voice and the weapon of workers to gain a fair result is just unacceptable.

I oppose the proposal that has been put by Senator Parer. This Government will not abandon the centralised but flexible industrial relations system because it is fair. Jobsback is not worker friendly and will be rejected by the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to wrap up this debate. In urgency motions, we normally expect the Australian Democrats to come in here and make some sort of a pious amendment that normally neuters the urgency motion. I was somewhat intrigued to see what they would do in this instance. In view of their past practice, which means they really do not support one party or the other, and the fact that they never come up with any of their own policies, much to my surprise when I read this amendment and following discussions with my colleagues, particularly Senator Crane, it was apparent that, with very minor semantic exceptions, the amendment moved by Senator Bell totally supports the coalition's Jobsback program. For that reason, we will support the amendment that was moved by Senator Bell.

PARA.TAB: I thought it was best to point this out. Senator Bell's amendment talks about the need to accelerate the pace of industrial relations reform. That is what Jobsback is all about. The current system, the system that is promoted by the Labor Party, is adversarial. It promotes the proposition that East is East and West is West and never the twain shall meet, because it promotes unions negotiating instead of relationships being built up between workers and their own employers.

The Democrat amendment talks about streamlined enterprise agreements. We use the word `workplace', but that is a question of semantics and I am happy to accept the use of the word `enterprise' instead of `workplace'. But that is exactly what Jobsback is all about. It encourages cooperation between the participants.

Who are the participants in any factory or workplace? The management and the workers. That is exactly what occurs, for example, in successful countries such as Japan. The attitudinal position is such that there is a recognition that if an organisation succeeds, so too will the people who work in that organisation. If it fails, they fail. So there is a common interest in promoting the success of the enterprise itself. The amendment goes on further to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in the labour market, whereby enterprise agreements would function in a system which safeguards minimum award wages and conditions . . .

Again, Jobsback is all about safeguarding minimum award wages and conditions. That is the starting point for any workplace-type agreements. Naturally, there are benefits to both sides in being able to increase productivity and having everyone share in that increased productivity, be it the workers at the plant or the shareholders themselves. Of course, it ensures that the public interest is maintained.

PARA.TAB: By way of summary and reinforcing what I have said, the Jobsback policy restores people to the heart of the industrial relations process. Australia's future lies not with institutions but with individual working men and women. The policy is a high productivity-high wage policy. Workplace reform will be driven by the enhanced personal freedom and flexibility contained in this policy. There will be the largest personal income tax cuts in Australia's history under the Fightback program.

The removal of restrictions on working hours will make it easier for parents to blend their family and workplace responsibilities, which is a cry we have heard for years. But, because of the inflexibility of the current system, people have not been able to go along with those sorts of changes. The coalition policy ends compulsory arbitration. Employers and employees will be able to choose between awards or workplace agreements. That is their choice. What is wrong with giving individuals that freedom?

Workplace agreements will be subject to compulsory minimum standards. Employees will be given a free grievance service through the new office of the employee advocate. Where an employer and an employee cannot agree on either an award or a workplace agreement, the award will terminate but the employee will continue to enjoy all the benefits of the award until further agreements between the parties are made.

I will not go into the final issues because I am running out of time. However, I should point out that membership of all organisations will be voluntary. Likewise, those who join unions will be protected against victimisation, the closed shop will be prohibited, as will union preference clauses in awards and agreements, and the convenient `belong and roping in' features of the present system will disappear.
Amendment agreed to.
Motion, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to bring to the attention of the Senate a number of factors relating to the 1991-92 annual report on the operation of the Bankruptcy Act and highlight what I would term a tragedy equal to unemployment in this country. We have just had a debate on the need for some effective change in the industrial relations area. Page 15 of the annual report sets out what has occurred in Australia and the blame for this must rest firmly and squarely with those opposite and their State counterparts, particularly in Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: If we compare the bankruptcy figures in 1991-92 and 1990-91, we find that there has been an overall increase of 28.2 per cent. The only area in Australia that has escaped this tragedy is the Australian Capital Territory, where we see a reduction from 391 to 362 bankruptcies.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are already bankrupt; there is no-one left.

—As Senator Reid says, they have already gone bankrupt; there is no-one left. The number of bankruptcies in Tasmania has risen from 480 to 638, an increase of 32.9 per cent; in Western Australia, from 1,846 to 2,314, an increase of 25.4 per cent; in the Northern Territory, from 81 to 99, an increase of 22.2 per cent; and in South Australia, from 1,653 to 2,031, an increase of 22.9 per cent.
—It doesn't include all those who folded up just beforehand.

—Senator Reid is correct—it does not include those who folded up just beforehand and those on special arrangements who are trying to hang in there for all they can. In Queensland, bankruptcies have risen from 2,460 to 2,914, an increase of 18.5 per cent; in Victoria, from 3,189 to 4,081, an increase of 28 per cent; and in New South Wales, from 2,991 to 4,341, an increase of 45.1 per cent.

PARA.TAB: In 1990-91 under this Federal Government there were 13,091 bankruptcies and in 1991-92 there were 16,780, which is very close to 30,000 bankruptcies. That figure should be put alongside the one million people who do not have a job and the one-third of youth who are unemployed. At a hearing on youth unemployment last week in Perth in Western Australia, we were told that 35 per cent of youth are unemployed and 33 per cent are underemployed, which means that 31 per cent of youth there have a full time job. This is the legacy that this current Federal Government has left the Australian populace.

I do not know how this Federal Government thinks that by continuing its current policies it will overcome either the number of bankruptcies or unemployment. My only comment on this particular Government is that it is bereft of ideas, it has no idea where it is going and it is totally bankrupt. The sooner the Australian public sends this Government on its way the better.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
