DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO ARGENTINA AND BRAZIL

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I present the report of the Australian Parliamentary delegation to Argentina and Brazil, and move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I table the report and wish to make a statement in relation to it.

PARA.TAB: It is worth noting that the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade recently tabled in this place a report on Latin America. Indeed, I had the opportunity to present some very fresh-off-the-press copies of that report in Argentina and Brazil. So the report of our delegation is closely related to that report, and is timely because it reinforces the message of the Latin American report and also strengthens ties between Australia and Argentina and Australia and Brazil.

From my point of view the delegation was very successful, enjoyable, informative and friendly. As far as I know, the only book that will be written about this trip is the one honourable senators have in front of them. I should particularly like to thank the secretary, Ilze Svenne and Jessie Byrne-Hoffman who accompanied us from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and also the staff and ambassadors at the embassies, as well as our parliamentary liaison people who helped set up a very useful and busy schedule for us.

My view of Argentina and Brazil is that they are first world countries with third world underbellies. They have great wealth and natural resources, but the wealth of both countries has been squandered over recent years. Both countries confront a very challenging time in their own history of trying to regroup their political and social resources as well as their natural resources to try to create better prospects for their peoples to participate in that wealth.

Both countries have experienced military government. The Argentinian Government is of more recent history and it was a much more brutal one during its time in office. As a consequence of that recent history, both countries are very strenuously opposed to the return of the military. Although in view of the more recent history and the crueller nature of the military government in Argentina, I felt people in Argentina were just a little clearer in their messages of total opposition to return to military government.

Both countries are very strongly committed to democracy, and both made that very clear to the delegation. Both too are committed to reforming their economies, in particular trying to hold down inflation. It is fair to say our delegation found that Argentina was managing this better than was Brazil. Both countries are looking to privatise some of their service provisions and moving towards a mixed economy much more than they have at the moment. Both countries are acutely aware that if they cannot hold down inflation and send coherent strategies for managing their economy, then they will not draw in the foreign investment which they desperately need.

It is also important to know that both countries are supporters of Australia, particularly in the GATT Round. They also support the same position in terms of the chemical weapons ban and the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. So there are many reasons why this delegation enjoyed a particularly useful time in both countries.

While Australia, Argentina and Brazil line up as friends, particularly in the face of the common enemy of the United States and the European Community in trade in commodities such as wheat and primary produce, my view is that the present is a useful time for Australia to work out its future relations with these two countries because that would be better facilitated while we are friends.

Once international trade changes, we will certainly find ourselves in competition with both Argentina and Brazil because we provide and supply very much the same commodities to international markets. But the delegation can certainly report that we were made very welcome, we were taken very seriously, and the points of discussion were not marginal to any of the countries involved.

In Argentina, President Menem gave the delegation a session with him of almost one hour and he was very free and open in strengthening the message we had been getting from many parliamentarians and Ministers of their commitment to democracy and an open economy.

In its visit to Argentina the delegation was particularly focused on meeting with parliamentarians and people at ministerial level, so we perhaps did not have a quite sufficient opportunity to talk with non-government organisations or to get a flavour of the country or the people themselves outside of the main government buildings and the parliament. One thing that very much entertained and delighted me was our visit to Cordoba, which is about an hour's flight from Buenos Aires. When we went there we visited its parliament—a provincial parliament very much akin to our State parliaments. Cordoba is a town which was established in the time of the first forays of the Spanish and Portuguese into that country. It has a university which was established by the Jesuits way back then—some 400 years ago—and a parliament to match. But these people have a bicameral parliament and only one chamber—and they were delighted to tell us that the lower house sits on Tuesday and the upper house sits on Thursday and on Monday, Wednesday and Friday they have committee meetings. It struck me that this would be a particularly useful way of tackling problems in other countries, but I do not know that it will be adopted in too many other places. The other interesting thing about that parliament is that one had to approach it through a mall to get to some of the entrances, so quite clearly one had to rub shoulders with the people whose parliament it was.

If this debate continues at another time, there will be more opportunity to spell out the flavour of the countries. They are countries of great energy, optimism and liveliness. Certainly if one goes to a soccer match in Buenos Aires one comes away with the sense that music, song, dance and ceaseless movement and energy are particular characteristics of that place—and I think very much the same applies to Brazil. We were there prior to the decision by the Brazilian Parliament to move to the impeachment of President Collor. Certainly a flavour of that was in the air, so it added, if you like, an air of excitement to our visits to the Brazilian Parliament, and certainly some anxiety as well.

I would like to briefly mention the concerns I had about the huge tracts of slums inhabited by poor people. In Argentina the poor areas or slums were called `villa miserias'; in Brazil they were called `favellas'. Nobody could tell us how many people were in those tracts or slums, and therefore we could not be sure of what government finances over the years would be committed to expenditure in terms of housing, schooling, provision of health services and so on.

One statistic that stays with me—and the figures that we have in the report give a higher number—relates to the number of illegal abortions. We were told in Brazil that there were 150,000 deaths from abortions over 10 years. That is 15,000 women who die each year in Brazil from illegal abortion, and I am very concerned that those numbers seem to be not a matter of concern or international recognition. Indeed, some would put the figure higher than that, but I wonder what would happen if 15,000 men were dying of AIDS in Brazil. I suspect we might have a different international recognition of the tragedy involved in that number of deaths.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who gave those figures to you?

—I might say again for Senator Harradine that they are qualified figures; one cannot be sure. In Argentina we talked about the very significant changes with the foreign Minister, Dr di Tella. He told us that in Argentina they had conducted a significant debate about a referendum to delete the requirement for the President and Vice President to be catholic. I would have thought that that is very significant in a catholic country and a matter of ongoing debate in terms of its constitutional reform. Apparently the country can cope with that. It has also been able to cope with the debate about divorce law reform and decriminalisation of homosexual rites between consenting adults. But, as we say in our report:

SPEECH.PARA: He did not believe that the country was yet mature enough to enter into a debate on abortion.

That is a matter of great concern when, as we were given to understand, so many people in those tracts of slums, particularly women, survive by prostitution. No-one is sanctioning that, but one of the consequences of living with that sort of poverty is that there may be many unwanted pregnancies and decisions about abortion. I would hate to leave you with the sense that our delegation was overwhelmed by that tragedy, but it could not ignore it.

PARA.TAB: In the time available to me I have not been able to say anything about the concern and commitment we picked up in relation to things environmental. It was very useful for the delegation to go to Manaus on the Amazon River and get some sense of the size of the environmental concern and problem. Cutting down trees is a worry in the Amazon Basin but not nearly as much of a worry as the gold mining and mercury poisoning that comes from the many gold panners, with that amount of mercury now beginning to accumulate in the tributaries of that great river system.
It was an enormously rich visit, one which I think honourable senators will benefit from if they look through this report. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: MIGRATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1992
Effective management of the migration program is essential in ensuring that planned program outcomes are not exceeded.

The Act currently provides for two broad program control mechanisms. Namely, the power to suspend processing in specified classes and a system of passmarks for the Independent and Concessional Family categories. This passmark system, which is currently in operation, controls visa issue by allowing for the approval, "pooling" and rejection of applications.

The suspension power in Section 28 of the Act has not been exercised but it forms a powerful administrative tool in ensuring that program levels are not exceeded. However, it is also a very blunt one. There is no facility to set a numerical limit. It also unnecessarily suspends all processing, even where that processing would not result in the program being exceeded. Resorting to an across-the-board suspension power would cause very uneven workload patterns at overseas posts and, given the processing delays involved, would lessen the capacity of the program to be increased readily.

This Bill will remedy these problems by supplementing the visa suspension powers. The new provisions permit the imposition of numerical ceilings, or caps, for a class or classes of visas and allow the processing of applications up to the point of grant. The cap would be gazetted by the Minister for a financial program year. Once the cap is reached, no more visas in the capped class or classes will be able to be granted although other processing would not be impeded.

In order to ensure that the cap is not inadvertently exceeded the Bill permits the Minister to implement an effective administrative mechanism which allows the orderly grant of visas while the cap is in place. This mechanism will, for instance, allow the Minister to impose ceilings on the number of visas that can be granted at overseas posts.

The Bill will allow the Minister to determine orderly release of visas to fill places when the cap is lifted. The Minister may target the grant of visas in accordance with the priorities of the migration program.
Consistent with section 28 the new capping provisions will not apply to certain classes of visas in the Preferential Family category.
The Bill also corrects a minor technical error of reference in the Migration Amendment Act (No.2) of 1991.
I present the explanatory memorandum for the Bill and present the Bill to the Senate.
CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992

Sections 3(1) and 3(2) of this Bill contain consequential amendments to section 26 of the principal Act resulting from changes in schedules 7 and 8 to this Bill. Section 26 allows consumer price index adjustments to be applied to beer, certain spirituous liquors and tobacco and petroleum products.

Schedule 1 to the Bill is operative from the first of January 1988 and contains amendments to correct anomalies which were created upon Australia's accession to the harmonised tariff. It provides a free rate of duty for aquarium aerators, transmission shafts and cranks for outboard motors and master recording blanks.

Schedule 2 corrects an anomaly caused by the implementation of the concessional tariff provisions of the Florence agreement on the first of July 1991. This change provides a free rate of duty for instructional books for certain games.

Schedule 3 is operative from the seventh of May 1992 and reduces the customs duty on aviation gasoline by 1 cent per litre. The decrease in duty begins the phasing out of the collection of that part of the duty on aviation gasoline attributable to the aerodrome cost recovery program.

Schedule 4 is operative from the first of July 1992. It contains changes to schedules 3 and 5 to the principal Act to put in place government initiatives to assist footwear manufacturers. The changes remove quota restrictions from certain parts of footwear and introduce a new 10 per cent duty for the subject goods. These changes are accompanied by the accelerated phasing out of preference for goods from Hong Kong, the Republic of Korea, Singapore and Taiwan Province.

This schedule also contains the extension of quota restrictions on certain types of cheese. Administrative changes have been made to the duty free importation of pick-ups and utilities of thirty years or more of age and to components for passenger motor vehicles.

Government initiatives to assist food packaging and food processing industries are also contained in schedule 4. These changes will provide new duty free concessions to allow processors to import the latest overseas technology for use in these industries.

Schedule 5, which is operative from the nineteenth of August 1992, increases the duty on certain tobacco products by $5.00 per kilogram, as announced by the Treasurer in his Budget speech. The duty on aviation gasoline is further reduced by 1.1 cents per litre. This results from the phasing out of the collection of that part of the customs duty attributable to the aerodrome cost recovery program and reductions in civil aviation authority costs of providing rescue and fire fighting services at airports.

As announced by the Government in March last year, quota arrangements for textile, clothing and footwear goods will be abolished from the first of March 1993. Schedule 6 contains a series of amendments to give effect to this policy. Goods previously subject to quota will be subject to ad valorem rates of duty. Concessional treatment of industrial crafts will also be abolished from the first of March next year.

New concessional item 61 is inserted in schedule 4 to the principal Act to give effect to the Government's overseas assembly provisions scheme. This scheme will allow designated manufacturers to export Australian made textile parts and to re-import the exported parts duty free in made-up articles.

Schedule 7 is operative from the first of July 1993. It redefines the rate of duty applicable to certain spirituous liquors of chapter 22 from Hong Kong, the Republic of Korea, Singapore and Taiwan Province.

The customs component of duty on imported beer is to be removed in schedule 8 to this Bill. In future imported beer will attract the same rate of duty as does locally brewed beer. This change will operate from fourteen days after this Bill receives royal assent.
Other changes contained in this Bill are of an administrative nature and in the main combine those national subheadings where the same rate of duty applies.
Summaries of the amendments contained in this Bill have been prepared and are being circulated for the information of honourable senators.
I commend the Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CENTRE FOR INTERNATIONAL AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 19 August, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research Amendment Bill 1992. The Opposition will be supporting this Bill. We actually think that the Centre has done an excellent job to date. The Centre was established in 1982 by the Fraser Government with the aim of creating a small, tightly focused organisation to coordinate the creation of cooperative projects in agricultural research. A sunset clause built into the legislation was an indication of the intention to create an organisation with a clear charter rather than just another bureaucratic body which would grow and take on a life of its own.

PARA.TAB: The review of the operation of the Centre which was carried out recently by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade with the specific purpose of making recommendations relating to whether the Centre should continue found that it had achieved many significant results within its modest budget.

There are many examples that can be cited of the immense benefits of well targeted research. I pick up one which I note the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) also referred to in his second reading speech—the CSIRO's well known expertise in entomology used in a cooperative project in Sri Lanka to control the salvinia water fern which had infested many ponds and irrigation channels. In less than 12 months the introduction of a beetle feeding on salvinia was able to destroy the dense mats that choked irrigation channels and reservoirs. I understand that, for expenditure of funds of $800,000, it is estimated that there will be returns of $25m over the next 25 years.

The beneficiaries will be rice farmers, fishermen and rural people generally who will suffer less from diseases spread by mosquitos breeding in the salvinia infested waters. There are many other examples that can be cited. The benefits to Australia should also be noted. The opportunity to work with scientists in other countries with conditions similar to ours can bring benefits for Australian agriculture.

Another example—coincidentally, I notice this was also mentioned in the Minister's second reading speech—is where Australian scientists were able to work in Thailand on projects developing tests for foot and mouth disease. That is one such instance which has helped to prevent the spread of foot and mouth disease in our region while providing Australian scientists with the opportunity to gain experience in fighting the disease without introducing the virus to Australia.

The benefits of this to Australia are obviously considerable. It has been estimated that the potential cost to Australia of an outbreak of foot and mouth disease would be $5 billion in the first year. What is particularly pleasing about such benefits is that they are in no way at the expense of benefits to the recipient government, and this is a characteristic of so many other ACIAR projects.

Another pleasing aspect of the Centre's mode of aid delivery is that it is extremely cost effective. Australian research institutions are required to contribute resources of their own, as do developing country partners. This gives incentives to the research organisations in both countries to select projects only of the highest priority to both sides. Such a commitment is an important ingredient of success.

Noting the success and cost-effectiveness of ACIAR, the Joint Committee review recommended that the Centre in fact receive an increased share of global aid budget from a level of around 1.3 per cent to 1.4 per cent, as it is at present, to 3.5 per cent in 1997. In dollar terms, the funding of the Centre is only about $17m, as I recall it, which against a foreign aid vote of somewhere around $1,400m gives an indication of what a small part it is of that considerable sum of money.

In principle, we would accept that the share of the aid vote appropriated to this organisation in light of its record to date should be increased, and that would be the approach we would take into government after the next election. We think it is an example to other organisations to exist on such a modest budget with a staff of only about 30, yet be able to achieve so much for recipient Third World countries, as well as bring such credit and also practical returns to Australia.

We do stress that in increasing the Centre's funding we would not wish to see it lose its lean, tightly focused method of operation. We believe that the tight funding which has been imposed on the Centre has no doubt acted as a discipline in sorting out priorities. However, it may also have meant that some valuable opportunities have been lost. Therefore, any increase in funding we hope will pick up the lost opportunities rather than contribute to any growth in a bureaucracy. We therefore wish to see ACIAR's funds expanded but not beyond its capacity to engage in the careful groundwork needed for the planning and development of successful projects. Under this Bill, the capacity of the organisation—
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CENTRE FOR INTERNATIONAL AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH AMENDMENT BILL 1992

TALK.START.PARA: —My contribution is nearly complete. I think there will be a few other succinct contributions. If we can cooperate to help the program, we are happy to do so, provided that it does not take too long. The Bill also gives the power to the organisation to expand its function in a couple of ways. One is to implement development activities arising out of its research work. Another is to engage in training activities that, in effect, carry its research work further into practical application as well. The third area is to expand its capacity for dealing with other international agricultural research organisations.

PARA.TAB: With regard to the first two, we support that extension but we do so with some caution. We wonder why it is necessary, and whether it is as a result of AIDAB having failed adequately to take up the opportunities for Australia's aid program through the research work of this organisation. Therefore, although, as I said, we support that expansion of function, we do so with that caveat—that we hope that it is not going to seek to become an aid delivery body when there are already existing aid delivery bodies that have been designed for that function. That is an issue that should be looked at carefully as the organisation proceeds in the future.

In summary, we have recognised that to be, as the Minister says, a lean, professional and efficient organisation with an excellent approach to its task. That has been the determination by the Joint Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee of this Parliament. This body has, therefore, certainly earned the right to continue after exhaustive examination of its performance and, as I said, it seems to have provided a lesson to other organs of government, particularly those within the foreign aid, research and delivery areas. I certainly wish the Centre well for the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats also believe that ACIAR has done an excellent job, as Senator Hill has just said. Indeed, on recent visits to South East Asia, the benefits of ACIAR's work in these areas have often been pointed out to me. The benefits to Australia are also very substantial. ACIAR gives very good value for expenditure. We would agree also with Senator Hill that perhaps the budget could be increased to some advantage to Australia and, indeed, to our region.

PARA.TAB: We also note on the sunset clause the Government's response to recommendation 14 of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade when it looked into ACIAR. That recommendation was that the appropriate parliamentary committee inquire into the role of sunset clauses for statutory authorities, as the sunset clause in this Bill was quite useful. The Government's response is that it would be appropriate for the Joint Committee to draw the matter to the attention of the Presiding Officers of Parliament. I can only say that the Democrats believe that that is a very good idea, that sunset clauses should be in with statutory authority legislation. We look forward to seeing it in far more of the Bills that we see.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in support of this Bill and in support of ACIAR. I was Chairman of the subcommittee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade that conducted the inquiry under the reference given to us by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to review the work of ACIAR in view of the sunset clause that operated on ACIAR. The Committee's recommendations, we are delighted to note, were overwhelmingly accepted by the Government, and that is why the legislation is before us.

PARA.TAB: In my view, ACIAR is one of those good news stories that does not get the coverage in the Australian media, unfortunately, that organisations like it should get. The evidence we had before us was overwhelming that, on a cost-benefit analysis, for an expenditure of relatively modest amounts of money, substantial benefits were given to both Australia and overseas to developing countries. I draw the attention of the Senate to the report that was tabled earlier this year by the Joint Committee. At appendix 4 on pages 85 onwards there is a list of selected projects by ACIAR that have been so successful. We saw a number of those projects as members of the Committee. I remember the description of the project called `The Biological Control of Salvinia Water Weed in Sri Lanka, 86-89'. The project that was undertaken there involved Australian scientists with CSIRO. We met those scientists and were very impressed with their dedication. One of them spent a couple of years in the swamps of Brazil trying to find the appropriate beetle that would destroy the salvinia and was successful in that. We saw plenty of evidence that there had been a startling improvement in the destruction of the salvinia weed in Sri Lanka and other places in the South East Asia region.

It is clear that many members of the Committee believe that the issue we had to deal with, the sunset clause, had made ACIAR a lean and hungry organisation. The sword of Damocles, in a sense, hanging over it, I suspect made it a better organisation than many other public bodies that do not have such a sunset clause operating. But in the end, the Committee recommended that the sunset clause should go because it would be unfair to have one statutory authority with a sunset clause continuing when the great value of its work was clear and when practically every other statutory organisation did not have a sunset clause. So although we recommended the removal of the sunset clause we also recommended that an appropriate parliamentary committee should conduct a wider investigation to see whether sunset clauses in general should become a major part of the operation of other similar statutory authorities. I hope that the Government and the Parliament can take up that inquiry some time in the near future.

Again, as Chairman of the subcommittee on ACIAR and on behalf of the Joint Committee, I say that we are delighted that the Government has accepted all of our recommendations to ensure that such an excellent body that has done an enormous amount of good for Australia and many countries overseas is going to continue.

We also note that in the recent Budget the Australian Government increased the funding for ACIAR, and the figure has increased quite significantly over a number of years. We hope the recommendations we made for increased funding over a longer period of time can be met by the Australian Government as it is quite clear from the report that we get enormously good value for every dollar spent by ACIAR. Indeed, we get back tens of dollars for every dollar that is spent. I support the legislation before the Parliament and hope that it will be passed unanimously.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am mindful of the hour, so I shall be brief. The coalition will be supporting the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research Amendment Bill 1992, but we in the National Party have some reservations about the way in which funding is currently provided in this nation for agricultural research. Whilst the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research is a worthy project, and we fully support the comments that have been made by Senator Hill, we in a coalition government would expand its budgetary allocation while expecting it to remain lean.
—You are going to cut it by $50m in your Fightback package.
—And we will cut foreign aid.
—Where are you going to cut it?

—Rather than rave like some lunatic on the other side of the chamber, we in a coalition government would seek to ensure that the aid budget is much more focused. We are very concerned that at the moment we are funding many aid projects which are not quite as focused as we would like them to be and which do not give as much of a benefit to this nation as we would seek. It also highlights the dreadful problem of the general lack of funding for agricultural research in this nation.

PARA.TAB: If we are to increase the prosperity of our agricultural sector, if we are to remain a dominant force in world agriculture, it must be absolutely incumbent on future governments to ensure that there is decent and adequate support for the agricultural sector of this nation. We must maintain our competitive advantage over our opposition in the international trading environment by ensuring that we have adequate research funding to keep us ahead of every other trading nation with which we compete.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also am pleased to support the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research Amendment Bill 1992, which will extend the life of the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research. In common with Senator Schacht, having been a member of the subcommittee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade which undertook the review of this very worthwhile organisation, I strongly support the conclusions and recommendations that came out of that inquiry which are contained in the report of the Committee. It is on the basis of those recommendations that this legislation has been introduced by the Government, and I certainly welcome that.

PARA.TAB: This body is a very lean and efficient organisation for the delivery of a section of Australia's foreign aid. Indeed, with a budget in the order of $17m, it provides undoubtedly high quality aid to various countries overseas. Some 82 per cent of the annual funding of the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research is delivered directly as research and is of a direct benefit to those countries receiving the benefits of that research. Less than 17 per cent of the total budget of the organisation is eaten up by administration and other expenses. That indicates the efficiency with which this body has operated since its introduction in the early 1980s by the then Fraser coalition Government. It is on that basis that the Committee recommended that its life be extended and that the Government has responded in a positive way with this legislation.

However, I do have a concern about the amount of research and the amount of funding which is allocated to certain institutions in Australia. As a South Australian, I would like to see some South Australian institutions have a greater opportunity to participate in the research that is undertaken on behalf of the Centre and be involved in the foreign aid that is delivered through the Centre. On that basis, I particularly draw attention to recommendation 4 of the Committee's report which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that ACIAR's primary focus remains South East Asia and the South Pacific.
If they do remain the primary focus, institutions in Queensland in particular will retain the lion's share of involvement in research. That recommendation continues:

However, as funding permits, ACIAR should foster collaborative projects of mutual importance in other parts of the world, including Africa, the Middle East and South America. North Africa and the Middle East, in particular, should be a priority because of Australia's expertise in dryland farming.

It is the research institutions and consulting bodies in South Australia in particular which do have a high level of expertise as far as dry land farming is concerned. Therefore, I would particularly like to see ACIAR, as it continues its worthwhile operation under the legislation which we are debating tonight and which will extend its life, take heed of that recommendation and become involved in research and aid beyond South East Asia and the South Pacific, although I agree they should be its primary focus. Thereby I trust that South Australians who have particular expertise in dryland farming—which will be of benefit to those other areas that I have just mentioned, namely, North Africa and the Middle East—will also become actively involved in the work of ACIAR. While ACIAR delivers benefits to the countries receiving the aid which its research provides, there is also undoubted benefit to Australian scientists and research institutions because of their capacity to be involved through this institution.

PARA.TAB: In particular, I commend the scientists who have been involved in the programs of ACIAR for their dedication and contribution. As a South Australian, I would like to see utilised the undoubted expertise which South Australia has in the area of dryland farming and to see that benefit exploited by this institution.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking briefly to the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research Amendment Bill 1992, I add my support for the work done by this institute. By any modern standard it is an efficient organisation and has been established so that it remains that way. Its charter gave it an initial life spanning from 1981 to 1994, with a review to be undertaken in 1991. This review was undertaken by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, whose activities have been mentioned by Senator Schacht and Senator Chapman.

PARA.TAB: The importance of agriculture to a country like Australia does not need any clarification. The work that ACIAR does is an extension of the research capacity of Australia; it provides leadership to the region in an area that Australia ought to be in as a pathfinder. It provides an end use for our research efforts through over 60 new projects each year, in places like China, Thailand, Indonesia and in various South Pacific countries. It helps to establish better relations for Australia with our near neighbours in a productive and cooperative exercise and it provides consultative and advisory roles for Australians to expand and develop their expertise in their chosen field. That is to be commended. All this has to be of direct and relevant benefit ultimately to Australia.

In terms of sound financial management, ACIAR by any comparison is lean and streamlined. This Bill will not impede this efficiency, but will provide security for those engaged in the projects associated with it. In addition, the Bill will allow ACIAR to operate its own training projects and to implement projects which apply the results of research initiated by collaborative programs. Some concern has been expressed that the Bill could adversely impinge on the role and the function of AIDAB. My personal view is that any activity that gives particular focus to strengthening and improving Australia's role in agricultural research needs to be supported and encouraged. Whatever concerns or conflicts have arisen or have the potential to arise between AIDAB and ACIAR, I hope that agricultural research per se does not suffer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of the time, I will be brief. However, that should not be regarded as a reflection on the importance of the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research Amendment Bill that is now before us.

PARA.TAB: As honourable senators will know, I have spoken about the crucial importance of agricultural research in the area of overseas development assistance. Agricultural development is a, if not the, crucial factor in the development of underdeveloped countries or, as they are sometimes called, less developed countries. Besides providing the basis for food production, which is absolutely essential in these areas, it goes to an industry which clearly, many, if not most, people in those developing countries are intimately associated and familiar with.

I will just zero in on a couple of things. The range of activities of ACIAR has been quite impressive. Its definition of agriculture, as has been indicated previously in this debate, covers crops, animal sciences, forestry, post-harvest technology, plant nutritions, soil and water management, land use, economics, farming systems and fisheries. Undoubtedly, this organisation has had considerable success.

I also point to its support for international agricultural research centres. The research that has been conducted in a number of those centres is quite outstanding. I refer, for example, to the technology that has been developed for rice, wheat and maize production. As has been indicated already in this debate, around three-quarters of Australian wheat sown today comprises varieties derived from international research, that research supported by Australia and ACIAR.

The value of increased wheat productivity since varieties were introduced in 1974 is conservatively estimated at $2 billion. In anybody's language, that is an important contribution. It is not only an important contribution to the less developed countries, but it is also an important contribution to Australia's capacity in food production. This is a clear example of where the best interests of Australia are served, as well as the best interests of the countries which, I suppose, the agricultural research is primarily intended for.

I am not suggesting in any way that our overseas development assistance should necessarily, or even less, always, have an aspect of benefit to Australia. Not at all. I think our overseas development assistance should be on the basis that we have a number of gifts which should be shared with other less endowed countries and people. But in this particular instance, clearly, there has been a benefit to Australia resulting from ACIAR's work. So in anybody's language, this has been a successful organisation.

Despite what has been indicated in the debate about possible conflicts with AIDAB, I believe that credit should be given where credit is due. I believe that AIDAB, particularly its Director, Dr Dun, has realised the significance and importance of agricultural research in the whole focus of overseas development assistance. The support that has been given to the centres that I have mentioned, and to ACIAR, has resulted in what we now have before us, and that is, a Bill which has the unanimous approval of this chamber. I support the second reading, and I will support the passing of this Bill into law.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise simply to thank all honourable senators for their support for the ACIAR and the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research Amendment Bill 1992 and, indeed, for the many complimentary things that were said about the organisation. I think those compliments were thoroughly deserved; it is an admirable organisation with a track record and international reputation to prove it.

PARA.TAB: I noted a number of constructive suggestions made by a number of individual speakers—for example, Senator Chapman, who has spoken since I came into the chamber. I am sure they will be taken into account very positively by the organisation and by AIDAB.

Also in a constructive spirit, may I mention to those Opposition senators who were so enthusiastic about ACIAR, that however lean and efficient an organisation it may be, it still costs money to run—and it is very difficult to do that when one is talking about chopping the aid budget by $209m over the next two years, as I understand is still the Opposition's position. I ask them, should they ever be in a position, God forbid, to implement such a policy, to think long and hard about its implication for aid organisations like ACIAR.

The only caveat I enter, finally, is in response to something that Senator Schacht said, also on the subject of leanness, when he described ACIAR as a lean and hungry organisation. My own recollection, which I have just checked with the Clerks, is that the first body of which that description was uttered was Cassius and he ended up committing suicide by running onto his sword. I do not think that would be an appropriate fate, nor is it a likely fate, for ACIAR, particularly in the aftermath of this legislation being passed. I thank honourable senators for their support and wish the Bill a speedy passage through its remaining stages.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
Motion (by Senator Evans) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tomorrow in Parliament House a seminar will be conducted by the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, the National Consumer Affairs Advisory Council and the Trade Practices Commission. The topic will be reform for consumers. Therefore, I thought it might be appropriate tonight to raise a challenge, or make some observations, about what is the appropriate level of funding for superannuation liability.

PARA.TAB: On 8 October, speaking on the report of the Senate Select Committee `Super and the Financial System', I raised the question of the extent of the funding of the Queensland Government funds. Tonight I wish to canvass the question of what constitutes a fully funded superannuation fund and, in so doing, use this opportunity to examine the Queensland Government funds. The issue is important because I believe the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation may unintentionally have been misled by a witness when appearing before the Committee, and that witness came from Queensland.

I remind the Senate that in the late 1980s there was an inquiry headed up by an eminent Queensland chartered accountant, Sir Ernest Savage. That committee was concerned that the real cost of government funding of State service superannuation was ill-defined and led to misinterpretation by the public. That committee went on to recommend an in depth review of superannuation arrangements in the Queensland State public sector. To my mind and from my examinations, little has changed since that report. I believe that statements that have been made by successive government Ministers, actuaries and others have not been all that reassuring.

As I indicated earlier, in that previous debate on superannuation I foreshadowed that I would bring to this chamber some of the concerns about public sector superannuation funding in Queensland. I remind the Senate that on 21 March 1992 at the Brisbane hearings of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation the Director of the Queensland Government Superannuation Office, Mr Trevor Hennessy, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Our Government funds are fully funded, both from the employee and the employer perspective, and the funding is kept up-to-date. Both the employee and employer funds and contributions are assessed by the State actuary every three years.
After some examination, I believe that this statement is not a completely true reflection of the arrangements in that State.

PARA.TAB: The Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, in both its second and third reports, has traversed the issue of unfunded public sector superannuation. In its third report Super and the Financial System, the Committee stated that under a fully funded arrangement money is set aside by both employers and employees and invested to generate benefits for retirees.

The Committee concluded that most public sector schemes in Australia are unfunded or only partially funded. I believe that perhaps we gave Queensland some credit it may not have been entitled to at the time. In other words, no fund exists into which the employer component is contributed as a superannuation liability for an employee accrues. If we use this logic it is natural that one would be able to point to a fund into which the Queensland Government employer contributions—and I put the emphasis on `employer'—have been deposited. I have had some difficulty in finding such a fund.

Employee contributions are, however, paid into one of the following easily identifiable funds: the State public sector fund, the Government officers superannuation fund, and the State service superannuation board fund. Each of these funds then transfers moneys designated for investment to the Queensland Investment Corporation, which has a statutory obligation to carry out the funds management role. The Queensland Investment Corporation also holds moneys arising from the activities of the workers compensation fund, the motor vehicle insurance nominal defendant fund and the Queensland Government. It might interest honourable senators to know that during the past three years the fund has actually returned 11.8 per cent to investors, compared with an InTech survey average of 9.7 per cent for pooled superannuation funds for the same period—which is a good result by any standard.

The Queensland Government Superannuation Office annual report for the year ended 30 June 1991 stated that $1.465 billion had been invested by the QIC on behalf of the three major superannuation funds. The annual report states that in the case of the State service superannuation fund, the largest of the funds, the employing authority is required to remit employer contributions to the Treasury for credit to the Consolidated Revenue Fund fortnightly.

The rate of employer contributions for the year was 2.31 times the standard rate of employee contributions. These employer contributions, together with investment earnings, finance the remaining (5)/(7) proportion of members' benefits and are transferred to the State service superannuation fund at the time the benefit payments are made. This is consistent with the statement in the financial statements appended to the 1991 annual report, which notes:

SPEECH.PARA: Employer and member's contributions comprise amounts due and receivable to the close of the financial year. The employer's share of contributions is not payable to the State Service Superannuation Fund until the emergence of the benefit and is brought to account in the period in which it is receivable.

Therefore, according to the publicly available statements, the Consolidated Revenue Fund appears to be the mechanism by which full funding is actually achieved. The Consolidated Revenue Fund, as at 1 July 1992, had an accumulated surplus of $3.6 billion. There is no indication in the Budget Papers that this surplus has been accumulated to cover future superannuation liabilities. So it would appear from what we have said that no separate and quarantined fund exists into which employer contributions could be deposited to cover future liabilities.

PARA.TAB: Therefore I believe that it is very difficult to sustain the case that full funding has been achieved, certainly in respect of employer contributions. Until there has been a publicly declared actuarial examination of the level of accrued liabilities relating to public sector superannuation in Queensland and until clarification is given on the extent to which the surplus on the Consolidated Fund for that State is designed to cover superannuation liabilities, questions can legitimately be asked about how fully funded government superannuation in that State really is. If the surplus on the Consolidated Fund, which is expected to reach $4.095 billion in June 1993, has been earmarked to cover superannuation debt, it is difficult to cover all past service liabilities for those members who have retired and are still in receipt of a defined benefit pension as well as those who will retire in future years.

As there is no publicly available actuarial or audit information on the extent of past service liabilities, one is therefore placed in a position of having to approximate roughly their possible level. Using a factor—and this could be dangerous—of 2.5, or a (2)/(7) to (5)/(7) level of contributions, to calculate the level of employer support relative to members' contributions, one could multiply the $1.4 billion of member funds in the QIC by this factor and conclude that an approximate accrued liability to those members still in the Queensland Public Service is in the order of $3.5 billion.

However, that figure would not take into account those who are in retirement and have taken their contributions from the fund but who are still in receipt of a defined benefit pension which has been paid from consolidated revenue. One can only guess what this figure would be over the next 20 to 30 years.

Unfortunately, the lack of an actuarial assessment of future superannuation debt is serious and the comment of the Queensland Auditor-General in his report on public superannuation funds is something which causes even greater concern. In his first report for the year ended 30 June 1991 he said:

SPEECH.PARA: As I have indicated in previous years, and reiterated in section 8 of this report, not all audits performed on superannuation funds are carried out under legislative authority. A number are performed on a by arrangement basis.

PARA.TAB: The matter of the unfunding of the Queensland public sector was naturally taken up by that keen accountant and prolific writer on such matters, Professor Bob Walker from the University of New South Wales. In an article in Australian Business on 23 December 1987 he noted:

SPEECH.PARA: Some Queensland public service managers involved with the schemes deny there is any problem: they claim the State has already set aside funds sufficient to meet its commitments. But the identity and value of those investments is a Treasury secret.

PARA.TAB: In its third report, the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation has recommended that a super summit be convened by the Commonwealth Minister for Finance to discuss the matter of unfunded superannuation. The summit would come to an agreed position on what constitutes superannuation debt, publish comparative cost data and, hopefully, set in place a strategy to reduce debt levels.

I remind the Senate that the United States Government Accounting Standards Board provides one with some guidelines for reform. For example, under its guidelines, public sector schemes have to disclose pension benefit delegations or defined benefit funds, and further require disclosure of pension liabilities representing the actuarial present value of credit projected benefits pro-rated on service considering both salary progression and step rate benefits. In addition, the US rules require reporting of a 10-year summary of information about net assets available for benefits, accrued liabilities and a comparison of revenues by source to expense by type.

The question that is frequently asked, but which still remains unanswered, is why has there not been a proper pooling of the employee and employer contributions into some identifiable funds? The identity and value of the investments and the liabilities today remain, as Professor Walker said in 1987, still very much a Treasury secret.

One has the feeling that the Commonwealth Select Committee may have been misled by this witness and in our report and utterances we may have given recognition which may have been misplaced. I am aware of one letter to the editor in one notable paper where the Queensland Government was commended for fully funding its liabilities.

I remind the Senate that estimates or calculations by actuaries of surplus are not the same as funded assets in a trust account or separate independent entity supervised by properly constituted trustees and audited and assessed on a regular basis by the actuary. I believe that this is perhaps an appropriate issue for this seminar which is being conducted in Parliament House to examine, because governments have to set a standard and certainly set a better standard to ensure a proper funding of all their accrued liabilities in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to make reference to some comments in the West Australian newspaper today made by Mr Dawkins, the Treasurer. Of course, the comments relate to the goods and services tax debate and, naturally enough, Mr Dawkins's comments bear no relevance to the truth of Fightback and the reality of what his own Government tried to do but failed six years ago. I wish to highlight some of those things.

PARA.TAB: Mr Dawkins is trying to say that the time and money it will cost small business will be extortionate. I will come back and answer some of these comments by evidence we have received during a visit to New Zealand where the evidence was in fact quite the contrary to what Mr Dawkins is saying. Of course, the evidence provided to the Tax Summit convened by Mr Keating and Mr Hawke was also quite contrary to what Mr Dawkins and Mr Keating are now saying for political purposes.

The fact is that we must realise where the Government is coming from today. The Government's political master, the ACTU, will not allow it to change the current anomaly ridden tax system to a more simplified and rort free tax system such as that which we are proposing. The only way the Government can overcome this problem is to try and scare the electorate witless. It is trying to tell the business community that its compliance costs will be extreme and it is trying to tell low income earners, pensioners and welfare recipients that they will be worse off. It is trying to say to people that they will have to rush out to buy new computers and equipment and spend hours of administrative time completing tax return forms. The reality is quite the opposite.

The matter gets really serious because there are so many deliberate misrepresentations, contrary to that which is written and contained within the 700 pages of Fightback. It is absolutely staggering to think that Mr Dawkins and Mr Keating in their positions have never even read it. I have given them the benefit of the doubt, but they have not read it. I do not believe they could go around and misrepresent it to the tune that they have if they had read it.

Last Wednesday night Mr Ron Edwards, the member for Stirling and Deputy Speaker in the House of Representatives, had a debate in the seat of Stirling in Western Australia, which is Labor's most marginal electorate. He had a debate against the endorsed Liberal candidate, Mr Eoin Cameron. It was interesting because not only did Mr Cameron answer absolutely all of the furphies put up by Mr Edwards, but he also performed exceedingly well and won the evening.

However, the fact remains that, only a matter of days after our industrial relations policy was released, Mr Edwards had the temerity to stand up in that debate and say that, if people did not enter into an enterprise agreement with their employers, they would be sacked. This is a total and utter misrepresentation of the package.

Mr Cameron was trying to be generous and give the benefit of the doubt, after the audience had loudly groaned at this misrepresentation, but, as he said, obviously Mr Edwards has not read the policy, because he would know that it is quite the reverse and no such thing is contained within Jobsback. The same applies to Fightback.
In today's article Mr Dawkins says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition's economic reforms focused on the second order issues and proposed big cuts to the social security and health safety nets.

Wrong, wrong, wrong! He knows full well that we are increasing benefits for those on social welfare and providing incentives for people to take up private health insurance while retaining Medicare and improving upon it, so that people who need to get into hospital can do so.

PARA.TAB: Mr Dawkins goes on to say that there is a shift away from negotiation toward confrontation in industrial relations. His own Industrial Relations Minister, Senator Cook, blew the whistle on that the other night by saying that it was his idea to have enterprise bargaining agreements. Whose idea was it? Does it really matter? If the system works, it works. But now Senator Cook is trying to claim benefit from it by saying, `It was my idea. Am I not a smart little Cookie?'—pardon the pun.

Nonetheless, smart little Cookie has been gazumped yet again, because Mr Dawkins is now saying that what smart little Cookie has done is wrong. But the fact of the matter is that this Government, the ABC and Laurie Oakes are bitterly disappointed with our industrial relations policy because it did not abolish minimum awards, leave loading, holiday pay, maternity leave and sick leave and all those things. So what were the counteracting remarks of the Government? Just fib about it; it does not really matter. Just tell fibs and try to scare people.
In this article today, Mr Dawkins said:

SPEECH.PARA: The new tax will also tilt the economic balance away from small business in favour of big business.

What nonsense! Mr Dawkins, as Treasurer, really should know better. If he should not resign over a whole raft of things that he has already done wrong, he should at least resign over the fact that, as Treasurer of this country, he does not know the difference between small and big business and their compliance costs and how they are spread and amortised across all their operational activities.

PARA.TAB: Mr Dawkins said that business would face an administrative burden because it would have to keep detailed tax records. Dear, dear, dear! Someone has just dropped the penny in the slot and he has realised that business should keep tax records. One big advantage of the goods and services tax is that people would now keep better records than before.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did Brian Burke ever keep records?

—That is a very interesting interjection from Senator Kemp. Mr Burke should have really kept many more records than he did, but he has had selective amnesia through the WA Inc. inquiry. He is probably bound to have a lot more selective amnesia in the future.
—Perhaps it was due to bad filing.

—Well, heaven knows what Mr Burke was on about, but he has certainly forgotten a heck of a lot. His records are not all that flash either. He should have had a chat to Mr Dawkins, or perhaps Mr Dawkins had a chat to him and said, `There is no need to keep records'.

PARA.TAB: Mr Dawkins went on to quote Mr Anderson from Arthur Anderson and Co. The worst thing that Mr Anderson could say was that the goods and services tax would take some time to get used to. Well, wacky do! Is that not a good reason to vote against a goods and services tax. Who said that it would not take time? It might take time, but does that mean that we should not stop and get rid of a system that is full of anomalies and that we should just keep on with the same?

The thing that fascinates me about this Government is that it is full of criticism for every solitary thing we do. Not a day goes by in the whole of Question Time in both this chamber and the other which is not consumed by the fact that this Government is full of criticism for what we do. This Government has seen this country go to its knees. It has seen many more than a million people unemployed. The official statistics indicate a figure of one million people. How about those who work one hour a week or less? How about those who have a spouse working, because they do not come on to the files? How about those who have been shoved onto sickness benefits or other benefits to take them off the unemployment queues? If those people are added on, the total comes to many more than a million.

Not on one occasion on one day out of seven days every week do we hear this Government, which spends every waking hour criticising our policies, say, `We cannot go on like this. We have to change. Our alternatives are these'. The only alternative of this Government is more of the same economically, educationally and on the health basis. You name it—it is more of the same.

This article by Mr Dawkins that was published today also says that British tax analysts made a detailed study of the costs to British business arising from consumption tax paperwork. He found that, for the biggest businesses, these costs amounted to only 0.003 per cent of turnover and 0.78 per cent of turnover for smaller businesses.

But what Mr Dawkins does not say in this article is that the British tax system and the VAT system are not the same as the one that we are proposing. But to say that would be to tell the truth and to make it clear, and we cannot have that. He also tries in this same article to draw the similarity between what we are proposing and the Canadian system. Our system is nothing like the one in Canada. But to say that would be to tell the absolute truth. We cannot have that, because we have to blur the subject and try to make people believe that what the coalition is advocating is the VAT or something similar to the Canadian system or whatever.

What Mr Dawkins judiciously does not say in this article is that the VAT system is multi-rated, multi-exempted and everything else and that the VAT system has tried to go through the hoop of trying to exclude various essentials of life. Let us not forget that there was the celebrated case of McDonalds a number of years ago. It went to court because bread was exempt from the tax but meat was not. It said, `But all we are doing is selling the buns and giving away the meat'.
This Government tries to say that the system we are proposing is full of the same anomalies. It is not. Therefore, the compliance costs are reduced.Mr Dawkins went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: When you see the accountant, the lawyers and the computer salesmen rubbing their hands with glee at the prospect of a GST—remember it's all your pockets they expect to thrust their hands into . . .

That would be a jolly sight different from what they have had in the last 10 years, would it not, because all they have had in the last 10 years is Mr Keating and Mr Dawkins thrusting their hands into their pockets.

PARA.TAB: But this snide little comment presumes that many businesses still do not have some form of computerisation or accounting system. That is just nonsense. I do not know too many businesses today that do not have some form of accounting system and even the most elementary computing system of one form or another.

But Mr Dawkins was not satisfied with that little lot. He went on to say that `they'—meaning `we'—propose a dramatic cut in tax concessions for contributions to superannuation schemes. The tax rate on superannuation fund earnings would also be increased from 15 per cent to 25 per cent.

Here he is; the saint from on high. This is the guy who has been putting businesses out of operation at the rate of 38 a day for over 10 years. Part of the problem now arises because he has imposed this superannuation levy on businesses and employers, yet he criticises our superannuation policy. Why does he not look at the effect that it is having on businesses? Why does he not look at the fact that he is sending 38 businesses broke per day and that he has been putting 55 young people on the dole queues every solitary day for the last 10 years? Why does he not look at the fact that his and Mr Keating's youth jobless army is 130,000 while the regular army is 30,000? Why does he not look at some of those facts before criticising our policy? Why does he not also look at the reality of what Mr Keating said in 1985, which is:

SPEECH.PARA: I would argue that if this tax—
He was talking there about a goods and services tax—

were to be contemplated with exemptions in significant areas, that would make it complex and administratively costly and would substantially delay its implementation. I would not want to proceed with it.
That is a remarkable statement. The same day he was quoted as saying:
I am killing it—
that is, speculation on exemptions—

stone dead. There is no prospect of the Government ever buying exemptions in this tax. It is not open to negotiation, it is not a matter of a negotiating ploy, it is just not on. I would rather not have the tax than have it with exemptions, but we must stop dealing with symptoms. The tax laws are in need of radical surgery.
They are Mr Keating's words.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, I will quote a few words about the reality of what has happened in New Zealand. We should remember that New Zealand only abolished the wholesale sales tax system and reduced personal income tax levels. It did not abolish seven taxes, as we will do, and reduce personal income tax levels. Yet this is what New Zealanders say. One of the chief executives of Westpac said:

SPEECH.PARA: GST is the most simplistic tax available. I love it.
The fundamental planks were, in his opinion, wide in its embrace, certain in its impact, simple in its application and easy in its administration. He said:
The fear of high cost compliance has not come to fruition.
In relation to completion of the form, he said:
Four hours every two months.
He also said:
If you structure your accounting system right there are no problems at all.
And later made the point:
GST has increased business record keeping, making it much better—one of the biggest boons of all.
Then there was a GST accountant from the Auckland Chamber of Commerce, who said:

There were miles more anomalies in the wholesale sales tax system than GST. It is much more equitable from a manufacturer's point of view. The cost of compliance to manufacturers would be $500 per year.

That is not per week or per month, but per year. The accounting profession has not blossomed since GST. In his words, it has probably slimmed down. He also made the comment that business keeps records up to date, which is a huge advantage. He said:
The best thing that's happened to the accounting profession in decades. It has flushed out the total black economy.

Then there was a gentleman who used to be the head sherang of the tourism industry. He is still very much involved with the tourism industry. He said that it fought tooth and nail with the Government before the introduction of the GST to get the industry exempt, and it is pleased it did not. He said:
There should be no exemptions; it makes it clumsy.
He also said:
It is a very fair tax because we get it back.
Then we go on to the Salvation Army. A Salvation Army major said:
It became more efficient because they went to computers.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is getting late.

—I realise that it is getting late, but if his Treasurer decided to tell the truth on the goods and services tax, Fightback and Jobsback, it would be unnecessary for anyone to do this. If Senator Evans had a little whisper in the Treasurer's ear, we would not have to sit here this late. The Salvation Army also said that it:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . would not abolish GST because it is a fair tax but had difficulties on introduction.

With each quote it will be noticed that everyone says how fair it is. Yet here is this Government trying to say that it is the same as VAT and the same as the Canadian system. The future competitiveness was predicted at a Christchurch business breakfast. The competitiveness prediction for Australia was 12.8 per cent and New Zealand was 65.6 per cent. That is a bit indicative of something. One of the vice-presidents of the Christchurch Chamber of Commerce mentioned that the whole system had improved the quality of accounting and that the opportunity to avoid the tax was very difficult.

PARA.TAB: One of the other things that was significant was that the growers and manufacturers did not have any problem with it. An electrical manufacturer and wholesaler said it was the most efficient tax to collect. The New Zealand public had accepted it as a way of life because it was a `fairer tax system'. Macfarlane and Growers also said to us:

SPEECH.PARA: It's a fair tax; I like it.

The electrical manufacturer and wholesaler used to have a manufacturing plant in Melbourne but closed it. The reason it closed it was that its oncosts in New Zealand were 17c for every dollar it spent and its oncosts in Australia were 51c. That is absolutely remarkable.

PARA.TAB: Quite clearly, Mr Dawkins's little expose in today's West Australian is as fallacious as are all the other utterings that we get from the Government on the goods and services tax. I presume that it will not stop them. I wanted to put on the record the fact that people are starting to wake up to it. By the time the election comes, whether it is 12 December, 12 May or any place in between, we will be ready for it and so will the public of Australia.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Mr Donald McKinnon Geddes, OAM: Death

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to pay tribute to a great man and a great Novocastrian, Mr Donald McKinnon Geddes, OAM, whose funeral I attended on 27 October. Don Geddes was a former acting Lord Mayor of Newcastle and the longest serving alderman on the Newcastle City Council. He held that office and many others with such distinction and dedication that he became much more than a representative of the people of Newcastle; he became a true friend of the people of the city.

PARA.TAB: Don Geddes was a true believer in local government and he put enormous effort into representing Novocastrians. Having been elected to Newcastle City Council in 1977, he served until his death on 24 October 1992. Don Geddes' contribution to his city was great because he cherished Newcastle and he believed that he had something to give it. In addition to his work as an alderman, he also carried out a practice as a barrister and solicitor. It was in this occupation in particular that he showed he believed in and was prepared to work for the underdog. At the time of his death he was the honorary legal officer for more than 400 city organisations.

He also accepted the position of controller of the Newcastle State Emergency Service and still held that position at the time of his death. When honourable senators put this in the context of the Newcastle earthquake, they can appreciate the time and effort he gave unstintingly to his city. To quote the Newcastle Herald:

SPEECH.PARA: History will probably record Don Geddes' greatest contribution to Newcastle as the cool-headed command he displayed in the hours, days and weeks after the 1989 earthquake.

Leaving his home—where his family had been entertaining friends—immediately after the earthquake hit, Mr Geddes holed up in the SES Newcastle headquarters. In the first seven days after the earthquake, he worked for more than 100 hours making up to 20 decisions every few minutes and supervising over 1,000 people. His friend and SES colleague, Mr Allan Bryant, said that volunteers would catch a few hours sleep during the earthquake clean-up only to return to find Mr Geddes still on deck after 20 hours. Service to people in need was indeed his hallmark.

PARA.TAB: This also applied to his professional life. A former legal partner said that Mr Geddes was `notorious for taking cases where he often did not have a snowball's chance in hell of getting paid', particularly in the days before legal aid. Half the time he did not even render a bill.

In addition, Don Geddes was a wing commander in the Royal Australian Air Force Reserve, a judge advocate and a Defence Force magistrate. He was involved with many ethnic groups in Newcastle; he was president of the Newcastle Australian Football League and president of Charlestown Skillshare; and he was involved for more than 20 years with police youth clubs and ex-service groups.

At his funeral, eulogists and mourners repeatedly described Don Geddes as everyone's friend. The 1,500 people who attended his funeral, the largest seen in Newcastle in 60 years, ranged from convicted criminals to police inspectors, migrant women to politicians, bikers to dignitaries, schoolchildren to pensioners.A close friend and former alderman, Mr Ian Campbell, was quoted as saying about the funeral:

SPEECH.PARA: Everyone here was his personal friend; he was a man who generated friendship.
Among the tributes was a letter from the Awabubal Aboriginal community who simply wished to place on record that they had lost a great friend.

PARA.TAB: Don Geddes was a family man. His wife and four children heard at the funeral of the pride that Newcastle had for Don Geddes.

I thought I should register a tribute tonight to a great Novocastrian who loved his city and its people, and I am sure honourable senators join with me in expressing condolences to his wife, Maria, and their four children.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, upon notice, on 9 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: What progress has been made in regard to the following wilderness protection issues: (a) establishment of a register of Australia's wilderness areas; (b) adoption of a national code of management for wilderness; and (c) development of a federal wilderness protection Act to incorporate both a register and code of management of wilderness.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: A discussion paper on wilderness entitled Wilderness in Australia; Issues and Options was prepared by consultants to the Australian Heritage Commission in January 1992, in fulfilment of a commitment made by the Government in the environment statement Our Country Our Future. Topics covered in Wilderness in Australia included the definition of wilderness, the assessment of wilderness quality, the management of areas to protect wilderness values, and the implications of Aboriginal ownership and management of those areas which are seen as having wilderness values.

After reviewing State and territory wilderness legislation and the constitutional basis for Commonwealth involvement in the identification and conservation of wilderness, the discussion paper presented six options for future government action in this area. These range from purely State-based measures and Commonwealth-State co-operative measures, Commonwealth funding for State initiatives and Commonwealth action at the Executive level, to a new Commonwealth Wilderness Protection Act, and finally constitutional reform.

Copies of the discussion paper were distributed to a wide range of government, industry and community organisations in January 1992, with public submissions being invited over the following two months. I am currently considering a detailed report on the submissions which have been received, and am awaiting a comprehensive briefing on policy options. The issues referred to by the honourable senator, which were also referred to in the discussion paper, are under active consideration as part of this process.
