TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 14 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to Senate Question on Notice No. 2043:

(1) According to the National Health and Medical Research Council (NH&MRC) and many other authorities, is chronic toxicity (hence the dosage, during and frequency of exposure) most important in the case of the extremely persistent organochlorin pesticides, which can build up in the fatty tissues; if so, is it misleading and deceptive to describe the toxicity of any of the organochlorin pesticides, for example aldrin and heptachlor, only in terms of their acute toxicity, as was done by Mr Peter Meadows, Group Technical Sales Manager for WA Flick, past president of the Australian Environmental Pest Managers Association and a member of the NH&MRC First Aid and Safety Directions Panel.

(2) Has Mr Meadows also misled readers of the magazine Building Trades Connections (Autumn Quarter 1992) by his statement that it costs `about $250 for organochlorin treatment of your average house', or, alternatively, is Mr Meadows advocating chemical applications contrary to specifications, since: (a) the size of an average house is about 150m(2) or more; (b) the cost of even the cheapest organochlorin pesticide applied to such a structure's footings and slab as specified in Australian Standard 2057 is about $430 for 20 litres, 11.5 litres of emulsion being required (925 litres at 0.5 per cent), that is, the cost of these stages of the treatment therefore is about $250; (c) the cost of the trench treatment required according to Australian Standards 2057 at a rate of 10 litres of emulsion per linear metre being applied to the outside perimeter of the house amounts to about $140; and (d) presumably a company like Flick incurs overheads and wishes to make a profit beyond the cost of the chemical alone.
(3) Does the public have a right to expect an appropriate standard of behaviour and honesty from individuals on NH&MRC committees who are entrusted with matters of public health and safety.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Both acute and chronic toxicity are important considerations in relation to the toxicological properties of a chemical. Chronic toxicity is of particular importance in determining the potential hazard posed by chemicals with high persistence and high lipid solubility such as the organochlorine pesticides. In the establishment of first aid and safety directions, however, considerations of acute toxicity may become paramount.

First aid instructions are aimed at treating overt symptoms of acute poisoning, which usually manifest themselves within a short time of exposure to the poison. Safety directions are aimed at minimising acute exposure, and these precautions are usually sufficient to limit chronic exposure. Therefore the possibility of chronic poisoning is considered during the establishment of safety directions.
(2) I do not have the information available to verify either Mr Meadows' reported statement or the honourable senator's figures.
(3) Yes.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 14 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the final report of the National Health and Medical Research Council on Cyclodiene Insecticides:

(1) Would it be of concern to the Minister if: (a) the final report failed to take into account the high exposure of the Australian population to these chemicals as evidenced in large-scale published adipose tissue and breast milk studies; (b) the final report ignored published peer-reviewed research which showed chlordane/heptachlor and dieldrin to be tumour promoters (the draft report ignored this research); (c) the final report failed to take into account case reports involving central nervous system effects, blood dyscrasias and neuroblastoma in children with pre-postnatal exposure to chlordane and heptachlor (the draft of the report ignored these reports); (d) the final report, when assessing increased cancer mortality in epidemiological studies of chlordane/heptachlor manufacturing workers, failed to take into account `the healthy worker effect', as was the case in the draft of the report; (e) the final Duggin report ignored the well-documented arguments and criticisms made in submissions on the draft report, including criticisms by several government instrumentalities; and (f) the executive summary of the final report, like the executive summary of the draft report, were not substantiated by, supported by or based on the body of the report.
(2) Were more than 90% of the submissions on the draft Duggin report severely critical of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) I would be concerned if major issues relevant to the assessment of cyclodiene insecticides were not considered in the final report. The NHMRC advises that a draft final report prepared by the Committee set up to review public comments was presented at the September 1992 meeting of the NHMRC Public Health Committee (PHC). Members of PHC are presently considering the report and it is expected that the report, incorporating any amendments recommended by members of PHC, will be considered at the next meeting of the full Council in November 1992.

(2) The Committee received submissions from 59 individuals and organisations which were considered at three day-long meetings held in Sydney on 13 May, 25 May and 15 June 1992. As would be expected for a document released for the purposes of public comment, a majority of these representations made suggestions concerning matters which were felt to require further consideration in the report.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 16 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the answer to Question on Notice No. 2062 (Senate Hansard, 18 August 1992, p.155):
(1) Does current expert medical advice state that the duration of treatment by growth hormones should be ten years.
(2) On the basis of (1), are the estimates correct that the likely total cost for the recommended ten year treatment program would be in the order of $250,000.

(3) In relation to the treatment of familial short stature of children with growth hormones, why has the Government not sought a detailed scientific study of the use of growth hormones on this group before approving their use.

(4) In relation to the treatment of Turner's Syndrome with growth hormone, why does the Government not advocate the use of androgens which have been proven to be just as effective and which are available at a fraction of the cost.
(5) Is there widespread concern amongst Australia's general paediatricians regarding the increased use of growth hormone treatment and the resultant high cost to our medical system.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Some children are treated with growth hormones for up to 10 or 15 years if they are diagnosed with growth hormone deficiency at an early age, but as the average age children enter the program is between 9 and 10 years, the average duration of treatment will be approximately five years.
(2) Based on (1) the likely average cost of treatment for a child on the program is $110,000.

(3) The development and support of the OZGROW data base (a system designed to audit the use of growth hormone in Australia) by Australian Paediatric and Endocrine Group and the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services, is helping to address the scientific issues raised in this question. At the meeting of Paediatricians and Endocrinologists in Canberra in May 1992, OZGROW data was presented on the effect of growth hormone therapy on different diagnostic groups. It was found that children diagnosed with partial growth hormone deficiency had identical responses to children with genetic short stature.

The result of a five year study examining the effect of growth hormone on slowly growing children is due to be published in October 1992. Analysis of the first three years of this study showed that the estimated mature height increased by between 6 and 8 cm depending on the dose (0.6 units/kg/wk to 1.2 units/kg/wk). Although long term effects have still to be ascertained, there clearly has been a short term benefit for these children. It must be noted that a rigorous scientific study is actually extremely difficult to perform because of the ethical issues.

(4) There is no evidence that androgens are as effective as growth hormone in the treatment of growth problems present in girls with Turner's Syndrome. Androgens have been used since the 1970's to promote growth in girls with Turner's Syndrome and when the literature is examined it is difficult to document any significant effect on the final height of these girls.

Androgens, in particular Oxandrolone, however have been shown to be most useful synergistic agents with growth hormone in Turner's Syndrome by causing an increase in growth velocity compared to growth hormone alone. This may have the benefit of achieving a final height at an earlier age so that other medical therapy can be instituted at a more appropriate age.

(5) Yes. The major concern relates to the issue of what will be the long term effect of growth hormone on these children. The importance of OZGROW cannot be too highly stressed in evaluating these long term effects. Currently, Australia's use of growth hormone per head of population is identical to that of Japan, France, Spain and less than Sweden. It is greater than some small countries where figures are known including New Zealand, Belgium and Finland.

The issue of cost to the medical system does concern all the physicians who prescribe growth hormone and every effort is made to maximise the effectiveness of growth hormone by regularly reviewing the Guidelines that apply to the program. A central administration helps to maintain a high standard of control over the prescribing and use of growth hormone throughout the country.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 16 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to a sugar substitute called sucralose which is manufactured by substitution of three chlorine atoms for three hydroxyl radicals in sugar:
(1) With reference to the history of chlorinated organic compounds being linked to adverse health and environmental effects, why should we take the risk of introducing sucralose.
(2) Assuming the product is approved for use in Australia, how do individuals who do not want to ingest this material ensure that it is absent from foodstuffs they purchase.

(3) As the product will be imported, why would government authorities want to cause further deterioration in our balance of trade while simultaneously decreasing demand for a natural material which is locally grown and processed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Sucralose is a chlorinated carbohydrate and is therefore not directly or chemically comparable with the classes of chlorinated aliphatic or aromatic organic compounds linked with adverse health and environmental effects. Extensive testing of both the potential health and environmental effects of sucralose has been undertaken, with particular regard to this concern. Expert evaluation of this data by toxicologists of the Commonwealth Department of Health Housing and Community Services, the former Food Science and Technology Sub-committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) and of the National Food Authority and consideration, twice, by the Committee on Toxicity of the NHMRC has resulted in the establishment of an Acceptable Daily Intake (ADI) for sucralose.

This corresponds to the daily level of consumption, taken over an entire lifetime, which is determined, on the basis of the data available, to be without appreciable risk. A similar conclusion has been reached by the Joint FAO/WHO expert committee on food additives (JECFA) and the Canadian Department of Health and Welfare. In addition, the Food and Drug Administration of the USA (USFDA), in consideration of the environmental effects of sucralose has issued a finding of no significant impact. The use of sucralose, as proposed, does not present any appreciable health or environmental risk.

(2) The Australian Food Standards Code requires that the label on, or attached to, a package containing food shall contain a statement of the ingredients and components of the food contained in the package. This requirement extends to all foods in which the approval of sucralose is proposed. In addition any food which contains an artificial sweetening substance must be labelled "artificially sweetened". Consumers are therefore able to determine from the label whether food they wish to consume contains sucralose and may make an informed choice.

(3) All intense sweetening substances permitted in Australia, including sucralose, are approved, in line with Codex Alimentarius guidelines, to enable the production of foods for consumers with special dietary needs. These include low joule foods and reduced joule foods for consumers on energy controlled diets and carbohydrate modified foods for those, such as diabetics, who cannot tolerate glucose. Because of its high energy value and intolerance by diabetics, sugar is not a suitable sweetener for such products. However sucralose is unique amongst intense sweeteners currently permitted as it is manufactured from sugar.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 23 September 1992.

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the original Appendix H of the Woodward Royal Commission Report into the Australian Meat Industry of September 1982 contain a list of names of individuals and companies involved in the meat substitution racket of 10 years ago.
(2) Did the substitution of kangaroo meat for beef cause our beef exports to the United States of America to come to a halt.
(3) Are any of the individuals and companies named in the report still involved in the kangaroo pet food and skin trade; if so, are several of these based in New South Wales (NSW).

(4) If the NSW Government is successful in passing legislation to allow the human consumption of kangaroo meat, will companies involved in the meat substitution scandal also be allowed to deal in kangaroo meat for human consumption.
(5) Could a copy of the original Appendix H, which was removed from the report, be provided.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Royal Commissioner, Justice Woodward, in his report of the Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry said that Appendix H to the report contained findings of fact, and some comments, on nearly all the specific instances of malpractice investigated by the Royal Commission. He further indicated that, with the exception of the investigation of allegations of pet food substitution for export meat, most of those persons investigated have not been named but their identity would be readily ascertainable in the public records of the Commission.

(2) The substitution of kangaroo meat for beef did not cause our beef exports to the United States to come to a complete halt. Following the discovery of horse meat in beef, immediate steps were taken to retain, both in Australia and the United States, meat from the establishment in question. Further quantities of horse meat were found, as were quantities of kangaroo meat. The United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) then took steps to locate, examine and sample all Australian boneless beef in the country. As a result of this testing, which continued from 25 August until 30 October 1981, a total of 3 establishments were delisted by the USDA.

A further 6 establishments were delisted by the then Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon, following investigations in Australia. Access to the United States market for other establishments was not affected other than by the requirement for product to be tested during the period mentioned above.

(3) Some people who gave evidence before the Royal Commission (although not necessarily named in Appendix H) are still involved in the kangaroo trade in NSW. However, none of these people were charged with offences arising from the Royal Commission.

(4) As the licensing function currently rests with the NSW Government it will be a matter for that Government to determine the eligibility of companies or persons to be involved in the production of kangaroo meat for human consumption in NSW. The Compliance Program of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) will continue to provide any assistance required to contribute to the continued integrity of Australia's meat industry.

(5) In making his recommendations the Royal Commissioner, Justice Woodward, ordered that "Appendix H to the report should not be published until any criminal proceedings against persons referred to in it have been finalised". To date Appendix H has not been publicly released as criminal proceedings have not been finalised. As the Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry operated under Letters Patent issued by the Governor-General together with the Governors of Victoria and the Northern Territory, the decision to release Appendix H is one to be made jointly by the governments of those jurisdictions.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 23 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: Has there been any allocation of money to the New South Wales Maritime Services Board by the Department of Transport and Communications or the Federal Airports Corporation as recompense for landfill to be dredged from Botany Bay for the Third Runway proposal at Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Yes. Under an agreement reached between the Commonwealth and the New South Wales State Government, the New South Wales Maritime Services Board is entitled to nominal compensation of one dollar for the compulsory acquisition by the Federal Airports Corporation of dredging rights in Botany Bay. However, the agreement also entitles the State of New South Wales to compensation estimated at $5.4 million as a result of the compulsory acquisition of the dredging rights. The Federal Airports Corporation has made provision for the amount of compensation involved.

A proportion of the dredging that will be carried out to provide material for the third runway will be in areas that would have required dredging to enable the future expansion of Port Botany. There will be substantial long term benefits to the Maritime Services Board from this dredging work.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 23 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Will legislation be introduced which contains provisions for the mandatory labelling of products that have been derived from genetically modified organisms; if not, why not.

(2) Is the Minister aware of any circumstances where products derived from genetically modified organisms have been released on to the market for human consumption without an information label; if so, what were the products, where and when were they sold, and have the products either been withdrawn from the market or labelled as being derived from genetically modified organisms; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The report presented to Parliament in February this year by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, entitled "Genetic Manipulation: the Threat or the Glory?", made no specific recommendations regarding labelling of products derived from genetically modified organisms (GMOs), but did conclude that:
". . . there should be labelling of some products which contain GMOs or are produced by GMOs. However, this should be decided on a case-by-case basis. . . ".

Although the Parliamentary Committee did not make any formal recommendations on the basis of that conclusion, the Government considers labelling an important and complex matter requiring active consideration and consultation with the community as well as various Federal and State agencies. This will be made clear in the Government's response to the report, which is expected to be presented to Parliament on 15 October 1992.

In Australia, the National Food Authority (NFA) is responsible for advising the government of food safety issues. The NFA is currently developing guide-lines for foods produced using genetic manipulation.
(2) As far as I am aware, there are no products derived from GMOs on the Australian market for human consumption without an information label.

Under NFA guidelines, no food product may be produced for consumption unless the foods/additives used in its production are covered by the Australian Food Standards Code. No GMO products containing whole or viable genetic material are listed in the Food Standards Code to date.

Processing aids, however, are generally not covered by the Food Standards Code. This is because they are not an additive that will form part of the final food product but are only an aid used to cause a certain reaction in manufacture. However, companies themselves do approach the NFA to seek approval and cover under the Food Standards Code for processing aids.

The NFA has advised that the only case in which approval has been sought and given to use a GMO derived product was in relation to a processing aid. Amendment 11 to the Australian Food Standards Code (Gazette No. P22, 14 August 1991) permits the use of chymosin. This coagulating enzyme is produced from three GMOs and can be used in the production of Standard H2—Cream and Cream Products (thickened creams), and Standard H9—Cheese and Cheese Products (general cheesemaking). The chymosin is an alternative to rennet from bovine stomach extracts or to a lesser extent from bacterial sources. The approval for its use was given by the National Health and Medical Research Council, before the NFA took responsibility for this area on 19 August 1991.
The NFA is not aware of any Australian cheesemakers using the product at present.
Only food additives are required to be listed on product labels—there is no requirement to list processing aids. There is therefore no labelling requirement to list the use of chymosin.

Chymosin is a processing aid and no viable genetic material is transferred into the finished product. It is not possible to detect which coagulating agent (chymosin or rennet) has been used by analysis of the finished product. Indeed, the only significant difference is that the GMO derived chymosin is considerably purer. As such, foods produced with the aid of chymosin could ultimately be perceived to indicate a significantly better product. Given these factors, there is a possibility that the use of GMO labelling could also be used fraudulently by cheesemakers using non-GMO rennet, and vice-versa. In other words, labelling cannot be policed effectively in this case and was not, therefore, deemed to supply the consumer with useable information.
